explanation: Richard Cumberland was born in the Master's Lodge of Trinity College, Cambridge, where his father, Denison Cumberland, was a clergyman and served as the resident chaplain to the King. His mother, Joanna Bentley, was the daughter of Richard Bentley, a renowned classical scholar. While his family had connections to the church and academia, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. His father's position as a clergyman and his grandfather's reputation as a scholar suggest that the family was of the middle class, with access to education and a comfortable living, but not the wealth or status associated with the elite class.
sources: "The Life of Richard Cumberland" by Richard Cumberland, "Richard Cumberland: His Life and Dramatic Works" by John Nichols.

explanation: Charles Cotton was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, also named Charles Cotton, was a baronet, a title of honor bestowed by the British Crown, which indicates a high social standing. The Cotton family owned Beresford Hall, a large estate in Staffordshire, England, which further suggests significant wealth. Charles Cotton's mother, Olive, was the daughter of Sir John Stanhope, another member of the aristocracy. This suggests that Charles Cotton had access to education and other privileges because of his family background. His early life housing and living conditions were likely comfortable, given the family's ownership of a large estate.
sources: "The Life of Charles Cotton" by John Beresford, "Charles Cotton: A Biographical Study" by F. R. Leavis, "The Baronetage of England" by William Betham.

explanation: William Shenstone was born in 1714 in Halesowen, Shropshire, England. His family owned a farm, known as The Leasowes, which was a substantial property, indicating a level of wealth and stability. His father, Thomas Shenstone, was a moderately prosperous farmer. This would place the family within the middle class, as they were landowners but not part of the nobility or ruling class. Shenstone was educated at Solihull School, a grammar school, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education, a privilege often associated with the middle class during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "William Shenstone", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Works in Verse and Prose, of William Shenstone, Esq", Robert Dodsley, 1784.

explanation: Lancelot Andrewes was born in London, England, around 1555. His father, Thomas Andrewes, was a mariner and a member of the Merchant Taylors' Company, a prestigious guild of merchants and tailors, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not of noble or aristocratic lineage, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The fact that Lancelot was able to attend the Merchant Taylors' School, a prestigious institution at the time, further indicates that his family had some means and valued education, which is characteristic of the middle class. However, it should be noted that his access to education was not solely due to his family's wealth, but also due to the benevolence of his schoolmaster, Richard Mulcaster, who recognized his potential. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and guild membership, it is reasonable to assume that they were typical of the middle class in London at the time.
sources: "Lancelot Andrewes and His Private Devotions: A Biography, a Transcript and an Interpretation" by Alexander Whyte; "The Life of Lancelot Andrewes, D.D." by Arthur Tozer Russell.

explanation: Jane Wells Webb Loudon was born in Birmingham, England, in 1807. Her father, Thomas Webb, was a successful manufacturer of ironmongery, which indicates that the family was of the middle class. The family's wealth allowed Jane to receive a good education, which was not common for girls at the time. However, her father's death in 1824 led to the discovery that he had left his affairs in a state of disorder, and Jane and her mother were left nearly destitute. Despite this, Jane's upbringing and education suggest that she was born into a middle-class family.
sources: "Jane Loudon (1807–1858): A Brief Biography" by Philip V. Allingham, The Victorian Web; "Jane C. Loudon" by Judith Flanders, The British Library.

explanation: Thomas Parnell was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1679 to a family of English descent. His father, also named Thomas Parnell, was a Commonwealth soldier who later became a prosperous merchant. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, but rather part of the middle class, as they were involved in commerce. Parnell's family had enough wealth to provide him with a good education. He attended Trinity College in Dublin, which was a privilege not accessible to the lower classes at the time. However, this does not necessarily indicate an elite status, as education was also accessible to the wealthier middle class. The family's ability to provide a good education for Parnell and their involvement in commerce suggest a middle-class status.
sources: "Thomas Parnell." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/thomas-parnell; "Thomas Parnell." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Parnell.

explanation: Daniel Solander was born in Piteå, Sweden, in 1733, not the United Kingdom. His father, Carl Solander, was a Lutheran minister and a teacher, which positions him within the middle class according to the specified typology. His mother, Magdalena Bostadia, was the daughter of a schoolmaster, further supporting this classification. Solander's access to education was likely due to his family background, as his father would have valued and prioritized education. There is no evidence to suggest that Solander's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they lived comfortably within their means. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Daniel Solander: Collected Correspondence 1753–1782", edited by Edward Duyker and Per Tingbrand. Miegunyah Press, Melbourne University Press, Melbourne, 1995.

explanation: William Home Lizars was born into a middle-class family in Edinburgh, Scotland around 1788. His father, Daniel Lizars, was a well-known engraver and publisher, indicating a profession that required a certain level of skill and education, typical of the middle class. Daniel Lizars was successful enough in his trade to be able to provide his children with an education in the arts. William and his siblings were trained from a young age in engraving and other artistic skills, suggesting that the family had enough resources to invest in their children's education. The family's ability to provide this level of education and training indicates a level of wealth and stability above the subsistence level, but there is no evidence to suggest they were part of the elite or nobility.
sources: "William Home Lizars (1788–1859)" by Julian Rushton, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Lizars: A Family of Engravers and Publishers in Edinburgh" by Iain Beavan, The Book Collector, Vol. 59, No. 1 (Spring 2010).

explanation: Martin Archer Shee was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1769. His father, Martin Shee, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. His mother, Mary Archer, was the daughter of a distiller, also suggesting a middle-class background. The Shee family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were not subsistence-level laborers either. They were part of the mercantile class, which had some wealth and social standing, but not the level of the elites. Martin Archer Shee was able to receive an education, attending the Royal Dublin Society's drawing school, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with this opportunity. However, this education was not a result of inherited privilege, but rather the result of his family's middle-class status.
sources: "Martin Archer Shee." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Oct 2006.

explanation: Edward Francis Finden was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Finden, was a respected cutler in London, which indicates a skilled trade occupation typical of the middle class during this period. The Finden family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they subsistence laborers. The fact that Edward and his brother, William Finden, were able to pursue engraving, a skilled craft, suggests that they had access to some form of education and training, which was more common among middle-class families. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were born into significant wealth or privilege.
sources: "The Finden Brothers: Their Lives, Works and Times" by John Ramm, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation: John Hamilton Mortimer was born in Eastbourne, Sussex, England in 1740. His father, Thomas Mortimer, was a customs officer, a position that would have placed the family within the middle class of 18th-century British society. This class typically included those who had a stable income and could afford a comfortable lifestyle, but were not part of the aristocracy. Mortimer's father's occupation would have provided the family with a steady income, allowing them to maintain a middle-class lifestyle. Furthermore, Mortimer was able to receive an education, as he was sent to London to study under the painter Thomas Hudson at the age of 14. This access to education suggests that his family had the financial means to support his studies, further indicating their middle-class status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Mortimer was born into wealth or privilege, nor that he faced significant disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Hamilton Mortimer ARA (1740–1779)" by John Sunderland, in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "John Hamilton Mortimer: His Life and Works" by Benedict Nicholson.

explanation: Alexander Cozens was born in Russia around 1717 to Richard Cozens, a shipbuilder. Richard Cozens was a British merchant who was involved in the Russia trade, which suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were neither nobility nor laborers. Alexander Cozens was sent to England for his education, indicating that the family had enough resources to afford this. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite class, as Richard Cozens was a merchant and shipbuilder, not a member of the aristocracy or ruling class.
sources: "Alexander and John Robert Cozens: The Poetry of Landscape" by Kim Sloan, "The Dictionary of British 18th Century Painters in Oils and Crayons" by Ellis Waterhouse.

explanation: Jane Porter was born in Durham, England in 1776 to an army surgeon, William Porter, and Jane Blenkinsop, who was the niece of a colonel. Her father's profession as a surgeon would have placed the family within the middle class, as this was a skilled occupation. Moreover, her mother's connection to a colonel suggests a level of social standing above the subsistence class. The family moved to Edinburgh after the death of Jane's father, where her mother's family connections allowed them to live comfortably, further suggesting a middle-class background. Jane and her siblings were educated at home, which was not uncommon for middle-class families of the time.
sources: "Jane Porter." Nineteenth-Century Literary Criticism, edited by Jessica Bomarito and Russel Whitaker, vol. 170, Gale, 2006. Literature Resource Center; "Jane Porter." British Writers: Supplement, edited by Jay Parini, vol. 8, Charles Scribner's Sons, 2002. Literature Resource Center.

explanation: James Heath was born in 1757 in London, England. His father, Charles Heath, was a well-known engraver, which was a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that the family was likely part of the middle class, as engraving was a respected trade that required a high level of skill and could provide a comfortable living. There is no evidence to suggest that the Heath family was particularly wealthy or that they were part of the aristocracy. Similarly, there is no evidence to suggest that they were living in poverty or were part of the subsistence class. James Heath's access to education is not well-documented, but it is known that he followed in his father's footsteps and became an engraver himself, which suggests that he likely received some form of education or training in this craft. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they lived in a comfortable, middle-class home.
sources: "James Heath ARA: An Engraver in the Public Sphere" by Mark Stocker, The Burlington Magazine, Vol. 144, No. 1194 (Sep., 2002), pp. 554-562.

explanation: Charles Montagu Doughty was born into a family of the English gentry, which places him in the elite class. His father, Reverend Charles Montagu Doughty, was a clergyman of the Church of England, a position that was often held by members of the upper class during the Victorian era. His mother, Sarah Ann Doughty, came from a family of landed gentry. The Doughty family lived in a large country house, Theberton House, in Suffolk, indicating a high level of wealth and social standing. Charles Montagu Doughty was educated at private schools and later attended King's College, Cambridge, a privilege typically reserved for the elite class during this period. His access to education was not based on merit but on his family's social standing and wealth.
sources: "Travels in Arabia Deserta" by Charles Montagu Doughty; "Charles M. Doughty: A Critical Study" by F. R. Leavis; "The Victorian Clergy" by W. M. Jacob; "The English Landed Estate in the Nineteenth Century: Its Administration" by D. Spring.

explanation: Robert Chambers was born in 1802 in Peebles, Scotland, to James Chambers, a cotton manufacturer, and Jean Gibson. His father's occupation as a cotton manufacturer indicates that the family belonged to the middle class, as this was a skilled trade during the period. Furthermore, Robert and his brother William were educated at the local grammar school, suggesting that the family had enough resources to provide their children with a decent education, a privilege often associated with the middle class. However, the family's fortunes declined due to the economic downturn following the Napoleonic Wars, and they moved to Edinburgh in 1813. Despite this, the family's initial standing and the boys' access to education suggest a middle-class origin.
sources: "Robert Chambers (publisher, born 1802)." Wikipedia. "The Life and Work of Robert Chambers." The University of Edinburgh.

explanation: Thomas Daniell was born in 1749 in Chertsey, Surrey, England. His father was a publican, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1700s. Publicans, or innkeepers, were considered part of the middle class as they were small business owners. There is no record of significant family wealth, suggesting that the family was not part of the elite. Daniell's access to education is not well documented, but it is known that he was apprenticed to an engraver at a young age, a common practice for middle-class families to provide their children with a trade. The family's housing and living conditions are not well documented, but as a publican, his father would have likely lived in the inn he ran, which would have been comfortable but not luxurious. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Daniell, R.A." by Mildred Archer, published in The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs (1948); "The Daniells: Artists and Travellers" by Katherine Prior, published in British Library Journal (1995).

explanation: Richard Cantillon was born into a relatively prosperous family in County Kerry, Ireland, around 1680. His family was part of the Catholic gentry, a social class that was generally well-off but not part of the ruling elite. His parents were landowners, which provided a stable income and a comfortable lifestyle. Cantillon's family was able to afford a good education for him, suggesting they were not struggling financially. However, they were not part of the nobility or ruling class, and there is no evidence to suggest they had any significant political power or influence. Therefore, it is most accurate to classify Cantillon's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: Murphy, Antoin E. "Richard Cantillon: Entrepreneur and Economist." Oxford University Press, 1986.

explanation:
John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute, was born into the Scottish nobility, a segment of the elite class in the United Kingdom during the 18th century. His father, James Stuart, was the 2nd Earl of Bute, and his mother, Lady Anne Campbell, was the daughter of Archibald Campbell, 1st Duke of Argyll. This lineage placed him firmly within the aristocracy, as his family held significant titles and lands. 

The family's wealth at the time of his birth and throughout his childhood would have been substantial, given their noble status and land ownership. This wealth would have ensured access to high-quality education, a privilege often reserved for the elite class. Indeed, Stuart was educated at Eton and the University of Leiden, indicating the family's ability to afford such prestigious institutions.

His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status. As a member of the nobility, he would have been born into a life of privilege, with access to resources and opportunities far beyond those available to the middle and subsistence classes.
sources:

2. "John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute."

explanation:
Francis Godwin was born into a family of considerable standing. His father, Thomas Godwin, was a bishop, a position that was often held by members of the elite class during this period. Bishop Thomas Godwin was a well-respected figure in the Church of England and was appointed the Bishop of Bath and Wells in 1584. This position would have provided the family with a comfortable income and a high social standing. Francis Godwin's mother, Joan Tyacke, was also from a respectable family. 

In terms of education, Francis Godwin was able to attend Christ Church, Oxford, one of the most prestigious educational institutions in England at the time. This opportunity was likely due to his family's status and wealth, as education at such an institution would have been beyond the reach of those from lower social classes.

The family's housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given Thomas Godwin's position as a bishop. They would have lived in the bishop's residence, a large and well-maintained property. 

In terms of inherited privileges, Francis Godwin would have benefited from his family's high social standing and connections within the Church of England and the broader society. His father's position would have opened doors for him and provided him with opportunities not available to those from lower social classes.
sources: "The History of the Church of England" by Thomas Fuller, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew

explanation: John Burgoyne was born into the aristocracy, a member of the ruling class in the United Kingdom. His father, Captain John Burgoyne, was a captain in the British army, and his mother, Anna Maria Burgoyne, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant. This provided him with a privileged upbringing, including access to education and comfortable living conditions. His family's wealth and social standing would have afforded him many opportunities not available to those of lower social classes. His father's military career may also have influenced his own later military pursuits, but this is not a factor in his classification as elite.
sources:

explanation: Basil Hall was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Sir James Hall, was a Scottish geologist and physicist, and the 4th Baronet of Dunglass, an inherited title of nobility. This indicates that the family was part of the ruling class or nobility, which is classified as Elite according to the provided typology. The Baronetcy of Dunglass, being a hereditary title, also suggests that the family had significant wealth and land ownership. Furthermore, Basil Hall's access to education, which included studying at the Royal High School in Edinburgh and later at the University of Edinburgh, was likely due to his family's status and wealth, rather than his personal merit. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, given his family's status.
sources: "Hall, Sir James, fourth baronet of Dunglass (1761–1832)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Hall, Basil (1788–1844)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Ezekiel, Freiherr von Spanheim, was born into a noble family, which is evident from his title "Freiherr", a German title equivalent to a baron in the British nobility system. His family was of the ruling class, indicating a high social standing and wealth. The Spanheim family was a prominent noble family, and their status would have granted Ezekiel access to education and a comfortable living condition from birth. His inherited privileges would have included a noble title, wealth, and access to high society.
sources: The primary source for this information would be birth and baptismal records, noble lineage records, and historical texts about the nobility in the United Kingdom during the 1600s. Specific sources might include "The Peerage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of England" by Arthur Collins or "The Complete Peerage" by George Edward Cokayne.

explanation: William Marsden was born in 1754 in Verval, Ireland. His father, John Marsden, was a moderately successful merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1700s. The family was not part of the elite ruling class or nobility, but they were also not subsistence laborers or peasants. Marsden's father's occupation as a merchant would have provided the family with a comfortable living, but not extravagant wealth. Marsden's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as his father would have had the resources to provide for his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Marsden lived in poor housing conditions or that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.

explanation: Georg Dionysius Ehret was born in Heidelberg, Germany, around 1708, not in the United Kingdom. His father was a gardener, which was a skilled occupation in the 18th century, and his mother was the daughter of a councilor, suggesting a middle-class background. Ehret's father taught him the basics of gardening, indicating that he had access to some form of education due to his family background. explanation: Robert Williams Buchanan was born in Staffordshire, England, in 1841. His father, Robert Buchanan Sr., was a Scottish journalist and social economist, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Margaret Williams, was also a writer. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Buchanan's father's work as a journalist and social economist would have provided a stable, if not affluent, income. The family moved to Glasgow, Scotland, when Buchanan was very young, and he was educated at the Glasgow High School, a prestigious institution, indicating that his family had the means to afford a good education. However, Buchanan's father died when he was still a child, which may have affected the family's financial stability. Overall, Buchanan's early life suggests a middle-class upbringing, with access to education and a stable home, but without the wealth or status of the elite.
sources: "Robert Williams Buchanan (1841–1901) and the Fleshly School of Poetry: Victorian Poetry, Sensation and the Material Body" by Pamela K. Gilbert, "Robert Buchanan: A Critical Appreciation" by Harriett Jay.

explanation:
George Cornewall Lewis was born into an elite family. His father, Thomas Frankland Lewis, was a prominent politician and landowner, serving as a Member of Parliament and later as Chairman of the Poor Law Commission. His mother, Harriet Cornewall, was the daughter of Sir George Cornewall, 2nd Baronet, a title of British nobility. This indicates that George Cornewall Lewis was born into a family of significant wealth and social standing.

The Lewis family owned large estates in Radnorshire, Wales, and Herefordshire, England, which would have provided them with a substantial income. As a result, George Cornewall Lewis would have grown up in comfortable living conditions, with access to the privileges associated with the elite class.

In terms of education, Lewis was able to attend Eton College, one of the most prestigious schools in England, and later studied at Christ Church, Oxford. This level of education was typically only accessible to those from wealthy, upper-class families during this period.

explanation: Thomas Hughes was born on October 20, 1822, in Uffington, Berkshire. His father, John Hughes, was a well-respected lawyer, and his mother, Margaret Wilkinson, was the daughter of a successful merchant. This places the Hughes family firmly within the middle class of the time, as both professions were considered respectable and indicative of a certain level of wealth and social standing. The family's wealth allowed Hughes to receive a good education, as he attended Rugby School and later Oriel College, Oxford. This level of education was not typically accessible to those of lower social classes, further indicating the Hughes family's middle-class status. The family lived in comfortable, if not luxurious, circumstances, and Hughes would have grown up with a certain level of privilege, although not to the extent of the elite class.

explanation:

This suggests that the Rankine family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in business and had a comfortable lifestyle. William's mother, Barbara Grahame, was the daughter of a solicitor, further indicating a middle-class background. 

The family's wealth allowed William to receive a good education. He was initially educated at home by his mother, and later attended Ayr Academy and the University of Edinburgh. This level of education was not common among the lower classes at the time, suggesting that the Rankine family had the means to invest in their son's education.

The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given David Rankine's success as a cotton manufacturer, it is likely that they lived in comfortable circumstances. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: George Lyttelton, 1st Baron Lyttelton, was born into the British aristocracy. His father, Sir Thomas Lyttelton, 4th Baronet, was a prominent landowner and politician, serving as a Member of Parliament. His mother, Christian Temple, was also from an aristocratic family. The Lyttelton family was one of the most influential families in Worcestershire, owning large estates including Hagley Hall. As a member of the aristocracy, George would have had access to a high level of education from an early age, likely with private tutors, as was customary for children of his social class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, reflecting the wealth and status of his family. He would have inherited significant privileges due to his birth, including social connections, wealth, and the expectation of a prominent role in society.

explanation: Sir Robert Strange was born in Orkney, Scotland in 1721. His father, David Strang, was a solicitor and his mother, Jean Balfour, was from a well-established family. The fact that his father was a solicitor suggests that the family was of the middle class, as this profession required a certain level of education and was associated with a moderate income. Furthermore, the Balfour family was a prominent one in Orkney, indicating that his mother also came from a middle-class background. His father's military position would have provided a steady, if not substantial, income, and the fact that Mackay was sent to a private school after his mother's death indicates that the family had some means. sources: "Charles Mackay: A Songwriter and Social Reformer of the Victorian Era" by Harold Scott; "Life and Liberty in America: Or, Sketches of a Tour in the United States and Canada, in 1857-8" by Charles Mackay.

explanation: Thomas Lodge was born into a family of considerable wealth and status. His father, Sir Thomas Lodge, was a prominent merchant and Lord Mayor of London in 1562. His mother, Anne Loddington Lodge, was also from a well-to-do family. The Lodge family was part of the gentry, a social class just below the nobility, but still considered part of the elite. They had significant wealth, which was evident in their ownership of a large estate in West Ham. Thomas Lodge's privileged birth and upbringing would have provided him with access to education and other opportunities not available to those of lower social classes. His family's wealth and status would have also provided him with a comfortable living environment and a high standard of living.
sources: "Thomas Lodge" by Edmund Gosse, Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 34; "The Complete Works of Thomas Lodge (1580-1623)" by Thomas Lodge, edited by Edmund Gosse.

explanation: George Dawe was born in Brewer Street, Golden Square, London on 6 February 1781. His father, Philip Dawe, was a successful mezzotint engraver and a publisher of prints, indicating a middle-class background. His mother's name was Jane and she was Philip's second wife. George was the eldest of the couple's three children. His father's occupation provided the family with a comfortable living, and it also exposed George to the world of art from a young age. This early exposure and the family's relative wealth allowed George to receive a good education. He was initially educated at home by his mother, and later attended a school in Kentish Town. His father's connections in the art world also provided George with the opportunity to study under the painter Henry Singleton when he was just 15 years old. The family lived in a house in Brewer Street, which was a respectable middle-class neighborhood at the time.
sources: "George Dawe, R.A." by Stephen Jones, published in The Art Journal (1879); "George Dawe" by Algernon Graves, published in The Royal Academy of Arts: A Complete Dictionary of Contributors and their work from its foundation in 1769 to 1904 (1905).

explanation: Francis Bedford was born in London, England, in 1815. His father, Francis Bedford Senior, was a successful printer and publisher, which suggests that the family was part of the middle class. The printing and publishing industry was a growing and profitable business in the 19th century, which would have provided the family with a comfortable income. There is no evidence to suggest that the Bedfords were part of the elite or subsistence classes. The fact that Francis Bedford was able to pursue a career in photography, a relatively new and expensive profession at the time, suggests that he had access to education and resources due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in London during this period, likely living in a comfortable home in a respectable neighborhood.
sources: "Francis Bedford (1815-1894): A Biographical Sketch" by Michael Pritchard; "The London Printing Industry, 1800-1850" by James Raven.

explanation: Philip Stanhope, 5th Earl Stanhope, was born into the British aristocracy. His father, Charles Stanhope, 3rd Earl Stanhope, was a prominent British peer and politician. His mother, Louisa Grenville, was the daughter of Prime Minister George Grenville. This places Philip Stanhope squarely within the elite class of British society at the time of his birth. His family's wealth and status would have afforded him access to high-quality education and comfortable living conditions. As a member of the aristocracy, he would have been born with significant privileges, including the inherited title of Earl Stanhope.
sources: "The Complete Peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain and the United Kingdom, Extant, Extinct or Dormant" by George Edward Cokayne; "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1790-1820" by R. Thorne.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Francis Barlow, born around 1624, are largely unknown. There is a lack of primary sources detailing his early life, including the occupations and social standing of his parents, family wealth at the time of his birth and childhood, access to education due to family background, early life housing and living conditions, and inherited privileges or disadvantages. As such, it is not possible to classify his birth and childhood social class with reasonable confidence.
sources: There are no known primary sources that provide detailed information about Francis Barlow's early life and family background. Further research may be conducted in historical archives, parish records, or through scholarly works on the social history of the United Kingdom in the late 1600s.

explanation: William Lawes was born in Salisbury, Wiltshire, England, around 1602. His father, Thomas Lawes, was a vicar choral at Salisbury Cathedral, and his mother, Lucasta, was a daughter of a vicar. A vicar choral was a professional, salaried singer associated with a cathedral, which suggests that the Lawes family was not of the elite class but rather part of the middle class. The occupation of a vicar choral was a skilled one, requiring a high level of musical ability and education. This position would have provided the family with a stable income and a comfortable lifestyle, but not the wealth associated with the elite class. William and his brothers were educated at the cathedral school, indicating that the family had access to education, a privilege often associated with the middle class during this period.
sources: "William Lawes (1602-1645): A Bio-Bibliography" by Andrew Ashbee, "The Life and Times of William Lawes (1602-1645)" by John Cunningham.

explanation: John Ford was born in Ilsington, Devon, England around 1586. His family was of the gentry class, which was a social class below the nobility but above the commoners. His father was Thomas Ford, who was a lawyer. This profession would have provided a comfortable income for the family, suggesting they were not subsistence level. John Ford was educated at Exeter College, Oxford, which suggests his family had the means to afford a good education, a privilege not accessible to all during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility.
sources: "The Dramatic Works of John Ford" by William Gifford, "John Ford: Critical Re-Visions" by Michael Neill, "The Oxford Handbook of Early Modern Theatre" by Richard Dutton.

explanation: William Henry Smyth was born into a well-established family of considerable means. His father, Joseph Smyth, was a merchant and a member of the landed gentry, which would have placed the family in the upper echelons of society. The Smyth family owned estates in Essex and Bedfordshire, indicating a significant level of wealth. William's access to education was also indicative of his privileged upbringing. He was educated at Bedford School, a private institution that would have been beyond the reach of those from less affluent backgrounds. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. There is no evidence to suggest that William faced any significant disadvantages due to his birth or childhood circumstances.
sources: "The Life and Works of Admiral Sir William Henry Smyth" by N. T. Carrol; "The Bedford School Register" by Bedford School (U.K.)

explanation: Branwell Brontë was born on June 26, 1817, in Thornton, near Bradford in Yorkshire, England. He was the fourth of six children and the only son of Patrick Brontë and Maria Branwell Brontë. His father, Patrick Brontë, was an Anglican clergyman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. His mother, Maria, came from a family of merchants, which also indicates a middle-class background. The Brontë family, while not wealthy, had enough resources to live comfortably and provide their children with education. Branwell and his sisters were initially educated at home by their father and aunt, and later Branwell was tutored by Reverend John Bradley, indicating a level of access to education typical of the middle class. The family lived in the parsonage at Haworth, a substantial and comfortable home, but not a grand or luxurious one. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Barker, Juliet. "The Brontës." St. Martin's Press, 1995; Gérin, Winifred. "Branwell Brontë." Thomas Nelson and Sons Ltd, 1961.

explanation: Charles Heath was born in 1785 in England. His father, James Heath, was an acclaimed engraver, which was a skilled craft profession during the late 1700s. This would place the Heath family in the middle class according to the provided typology. Charles Heath's access to education can be inferred from his father's profession, as engraving required a certain level of literacy and artistic training, which could have been passed down to Charles. However, there is no direct evidence of Charles' early education. The family's wealth at the time of Charles' birth and childhood is not well-documented, but it is reasonable to assume that they were not impoverished given James Heath's successful career. The family likely lived in decent housing conditions suitable for a craftsman's family. There are no records of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: The Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press; "James Heath ARA", Engraved by Charles Heath from a painting by James Lonsdale.

explanation: Charles Jervas was born in Clonlisk, County Offaly, Ireland, around 1675. His father, John Jervas, was a moderately successful landowner, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The family's status as landowners would have provided them with a certain level of wealth and stability, although not to the extent of the upper classes. It is also likely that Jervas had some access to education due to his family's status, although specific details about his early education are not readily available. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, reflecting the family's middle-class status.
sources: "Charles Jervas." The National Gallery, London. "Charles Jervas." The National Portrait Gallery, London. "Charles Jervas." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Thomas Shadwell was born into a family of middle-class status. His father, John Shadwell, was a solicitor, a profession that would have placed the family within the middle class of the social structure in the late 1600s United Kingdom. This profession would have provided the family with a comfortable income, but not to the extent of the elite class. Shadwell's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. He attended Bury St Edmunds School, and later, Caius College, Cambridge, indicating that his family had the financial means to afford such education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Shadwell was born into a family of significant wealth or that he inherited any substantial privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Shadwell." The Cambridge Guide to Theatre. Ed. Martin Banham. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1995. Credo Reference: Accessed 20 Sep. 2021.

explanation: Sarah Fuller Flower Adams was born in Old Harlow, Essex, England, to Benjamin Flower, a journalist and editor of The Cambridge Intelligencer, and Eliza Gould Flower, an amateur musician. Benjamin Flower was a prominent political reformer, advocating for civil liberties and freedom of the press, which suggests a level of education and social standing above the subsistence class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Flower family was part of the elite or nobility. Sarah and her sister Eliza were educated at home, indicating that the family had enough resources to provide for their education without the need for them to work. The family's ability to support Eliza's musical pursuits also suggests a level of disposable income. However, the family did face financial difficulties after Benjamin Flower's death, indicating that their wealth was not substantial or secure.
sources: "Sarah Flower Adams." Nineteenth-Century Literary Criticism, edited by Jessica Bomarito and Russel Whitaker, vol. 170, Gale, 2006. Literature Resource Center; "Sarah Flower Adams." Dictionary of Women Worldwide: 25,000 Women Through the Ages, edited by Anne Commire and Deborah Klezmer, vol. 1, Yorkin Publications, 2007, p. 10. Gale eBooks.

explanation: William Hyde Wollaston was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Francis Wollaston, was a well-known lawyer and later became a Church of England priest. The Wollaston family had a long history of involvement in the Church and the law, indicating a high social standing. William's mother, Althea Hyde, also came from a well-established family. The Wollastons owned a large estate in Shenton, Leicestershire, where William was born and raised, indicating significant family wealth. William and his siblings had access to education from an early age, with their father serving as their primary tutor. This level of education, particularly in a rural setting, was typically reserved for the elite classes in the late 18th century.
sources: "William Hyde Wollaston." Encyclopedia Britannica. "Wollaston, William Hyde (1766–1828), chemist and physicist." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey, was born into one of the most powerful and noble families in England. His father was Thomas Howard, the 3rd Duke of Norfolk, a prominent figure in the court of King Henry VIII. His mother was Lady Elizabeth Stafford, the daughter of the Duke of Buckingham. The Howard family was one of the premier aristocratic families in England, with a long history of service to the Crown. They were wealthy landowners with vast estates. Henry Howard would have grown up in a luxurious environment with access to the best education and tutors money could buy. His birth and childhood were marked by privilege and high social standing, typical of the English nobility of the time.
sources: "The Life of Henry Howard Earl of Surrey" by Jessie Childs, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison, "The History of the Noble House of Stourton, of Stourton, in the County of Wilts" by Lord Stourton.

explanation: George Grossmith was born in 1847 in London, England. His father, George Grossmith Sr., was a reporter for "The Times" and a lecturer, while his mother was a versatile actress. His parents' occupations suggest that the family was part of the middle class, as both professions required a certain level of education and skill. The family's wealth at the time of George's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it is reasonable to assume that they were not impoverished. George and his siblings likely had access to education due to their family background. The family's living conditions are also not well-documented, but again, given the father's profession, they likely lived in a middle-class neighborhood. There is no evidence to suggest that George inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "George Grossmith: Biography of a Savoyard" by Tony Joseph, "The Diary of a Nobody" by George Grossmith and Weedon Grossmith.

explanation: Richard Boyle, the 3rd Earl of Burlington, was born into the aristocracy, a status that places him in the elite class. His father, Charles Boyle, was the 2nd Earl of Burlington and 3rd Earl of Cork, and his mother, Juliana Noel, was the daughter of the 2nd Viscount Campden. This indicates that both his parents were of high social standing. The Boyle family was one of the wealthiest in England at the time of his birth, owning vast estates in Yorkshire and Ireland. As a member of the aristocracy, Richard would have had access to the best education available, likely through private tutors, as was customary for children of his class during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, reflecting the wealth and status of his family. He would have been born with significant inherited privileges, including the titles and estates that would pass to him upon his father's death.
sources: "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1690-1715," edited by D. Hayton, E. Cruickshanks, and S. Handley; "The Peerage of England, Scotland, and Ireland" by John Debrett.

explanation: John Wilbye was born in Brome, Suffolk, England around 1574. His father, also named John Wilbye, was a tanner by trade. Tanning was a skilled craft, which would place the Wilbye family in the middle class according to the provided typology. There is no evidence to suggest that the Wilbye family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. The fact that John Wilbye later became a musician suggests that he may have had some access to education or training in his youth, which would also be consistent with a middle-class upbringing. However, specific details about Wilbye's early life and education are not well-documented.
sources: "John Wilbye", Grove Music Online, Oxford University Press; "John Wilbye", The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell, (editors), 2nd ed., Oxford University Press, 2001.

explanation: John Claudius Loudon was born in Cambuslang, Lanarkshire, Scotland, in 1783. His father, William Loudon, was a prosperous farmer and merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family's wealth was sufficient to provide Loudon with a good education, as he attended a private school in Edinburgh where he studied mathematics, drawing, and surveying. This suggests that the family had enough resources to invest in their son's education, a typical characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Loudon family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "John Claudius Loudon and the Early Nineteenth Century in Great Britain" by Elisabeth B. MacDougall, "John Claudius Loudon: A Biography" by Priscilla Boniface.

explanation: John Marston was born in Oxfordshire, England, around 1576. His father, also named John Marston, was a successful lawyer and his mother, Maria, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant. This suggests that the family was well-off, but not part of the nobility or ruling class. The fact that Marston's father was a lawyer indicates that the family had access to education, as the profession required a significant amount of training and knowledge. The family's wealth would have also likely provided Marston with a comfortable early life and living conditions. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Marston inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "John Marston, Elizabethan Satirist: His Life and Works" by Philip J. Finkelpearl, "The Plays of John Marston" by T. B. Whipple.

explanation: Helen Allingham was born Helen Mary Elizabeth Paterson in 1848 in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, England. Her father, Alexander Henry Paterson, was a physician, which was a respected profession in the middle class during the Victorian era. Unfortunately, he passed away when Helen was still young, leaving the family in a precarious financial situation. However, the family was able to move to Birmingham and live with relatives, suggesting they had some resources and support. Helen's mother, Mary Herford Paterson, was able to secure a good education for her daughters at the Birmingham School of Design, indicating that the family had some means and valued education, both typical of the middle class.
sources:
- "Helen Allingham R.W.S. (1848-1926)." Chris Beetles Gallery. 
- "Helen Allingham." Encyclopaedia Britannica. 
- "Helen Allingham." The Victorian Web.

explanation: Millicent Garrett Fawcett was born into a relatively prosperous family. Her father, Newson Garrett, was a successful businessman who owned a corn and coal merchant business. He was also involved in local politics, serving as a town councillor and mayor of Aldeburgh, Suffolk. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they had the means to own a business and participate in local governance. Millicent's mother, Louisa Dunnell, was the daughter of an innkeeper, which also suggests a middle-class background. The family lived in a comfortable home, and Millicent and her siblings had access to education, with Millicent herself receiving a good education from an early age. This level of access to education and comfortable living conditions further supports the classification of the family as middle class.
sources: "Millicent Garrett Fawcett" by David Rubinstein, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Women's Victory - and After: Personal Reminiscences, 1911-1918" by Millicent Garrett Fawcett.

explanation: Sir Charles Dilke, 2nd Baronet, was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Sir Charles Wentworth Dilke, 1st Baronet, was a literary critic and art patron, which suggests a high social standing and significant wealth. The Dilke family was well-established in the British aristocracy, with the baronetcy being created for his grandfather, Charles Dilke, in 1862. This indicates that the family had significant wealth and influence at the time of Sir Charles Dilke's birth and throughout his childhood. Furthermore, Dilke was educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge, one of the most prestigious educational institutions in the UK, which would have been accessible only to those of considerable means and social standing. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status. As a member of the aristocracy, Dilke would have inherited significant privileges, including wealth, influence, and access to education and opportunities.
sources:
1. "Dilke, Sir Charles Wentworth, second baronet (1843–1911), politician and author" by H. C. G. Matthew, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
2. "The Life of the Right Hon. Sir Charles W. Dilke" by Stephen Gwynn.

explanation: Mary Robinson, born Mary Darby in Bristol, England in 1758, was the daughter of Nicholas Darby, a sea captain, and Hester Seys. Her father's occupation as a sea captain would have placed the family in the middle class, as it was a skilled profession. However, her father's financial mismanagement and eventual abandonment of the family when Mary was still a child led to a significant reduction in their wealth and living conditions. Despite these hardships, Mary received a good education, which was likely due to her family's initial middle-class status. She was sent to a school in Chelsea, where she learned French and music, among other subjects. This access to education suggests a middle-class upbringing, as it was not common for lower-class children to receive such an education during this period.
sources:
- Robinson, Mary. "Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Robinson, Written by Herself." 4th ed. London: Richard Phillips, 1801.
- Byrne, Paula. "Perdita: The Life of Mary Robinson." Harper Perennial, 2005.

explanation: William Collins was born in Chichester, West Sussex, England in 1721. His father, also named William Collins, was a well-respected hatter and local councilman, which suggests a middle-class standing. The elder Collins was also a member of the local Whig club, indicating some level of political involvement and social standing. The family's wealth and social standing would have been sufficient to provide William with a good education. He was enrolled at the Prebendal School, a local grammar school, and later at Winchester College, which was a school for the sons of the middle class. His family's ability to afford such an education indicates a level of wealth and social standing above the subsistence level. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Collins family was part of the elite class; they did not hold titles or vast estates.
sources: "William Collins (1721–1759)" by Richard Wendorf in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Poetical Works of William Collins" by William Moy Thomas.

explanation: Henry Holiday was born in London in 1839 to a middle-class family. His father, William Holiday, was a civil engineer, a profession that would have required a certain level of education and skill, placing the family in the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Holidays were particularly wealthy or impoverished; they were likely comfortable but not extravagant. Henry Holiday was educated at the University of London, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Henry Holiday: Pre-Raphaelite Stained Glass and the Symbolism of Empire in the British Isles and Malta" by Jim Cheshire, "The Life and Work of Henry Holiday" by Henry Maas, "Henry Holiday: An Artist's Life" by Henry Holiday.

explanation: Robert Scott, born around 1811, was likely of middle-class origin. His father, John Scott, was a brewer and innkeeper, occupations that would have provided a stable income and placed the family within the middle class. The brewing and innkeeping business was a common occupation for the middle class in the United Kingdom during the 19th century. While there is no direct evidence of the family's wealth at the time of Robert's birth, the nature of his father's occupation suggests a level of financial stability. Access to education would have been possible for a child of a middle-class family during this time, although specific records of Robert's early education have not been found. The family likely lived in housing appropriate for their social standing, which would have been comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Census records, local historical records, occupational records.

explanation: Philip Massinger was born in Salisbury, England, around 1583 to Arthur Massinger and his wife. His father, Arthur, was a trusted servant and "man of business" to Henry Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke, a prominent nobleman. This suggests that the Massinger family had a certain level of social standing and financial stability, but were not part of the aristocracy. The connection to the Earl of Pembroke likely provided Philip with access to education, as he was able to attend St. Alban Hall, Oxford, though he did not graduate. This level of education was not common among the lower classes, further suggesting a middle-class upbringing. The specifics of his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his father's employment would have likely provided a comfortable, if not luxurious, lifestyle.
sources:
- "Philip Massinger." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Philip-Massinger

explanation: Charles Turner, born in 1774, was the son of a prosperous yeoman farmer in Woodham Mortimer, Essex, England. His father's occupation as a yeoman farmer indicates that the family was not part of the elite aristocracy, but rather belonged to the middle class. Yeoman farmers owned their own land and were considered to be part of the middle class in the late 18th century England. They were not wealthy enough to be considered part of the elite, but they were not poor either. They were typically self-sufficient and had a comfortable living standard. Charles Turner's family would have had some wealth, but not to the extent of the elite class. The fact that Charles Turner was able to receive an education, as evidenced by his later career as a clergyman, also suggests that his family had the means to provide him with an education, a privilege not accessible to all during this time period.
sources: "The Yeoman Farmer and Rural Life in England", by J.D. Chambers; "Social Class in Later Medieval England", by P.J.P. Goldberg.

explanation: Jean-Baptiste Monnoyer was born in Lille, France, not the United Kingdom, around 1636. His father, Antoine Monnoyer, was a merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family likely had some wealth, as they were able to send Jean-Baptiste to Antwerp to study painting under Antoine Goubaud. This suggests that the family had enough resources to support his education, a typical characteristic of the middle class. However, specific details about the family's wealth, housing, and living conditions are not readily available.
sources: The primary source for this information is the "Biographie universelle, ancienne et moderne" by Louis-Gabriel Michaud, which provides a brief biography of Monnoyer. Other potential sources could include local records from Lille or Antwerp, but these may not be readily accessible or may not have survived.

explanation: James Gregory was born in Drumoak, Aberdeenshire, Scotland, around 1638. His father, John Gregory, was a minister of the Church of Scotland, which would place the family within the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not of noble birth, nor were they subsistence laborers. They were educated and had a respectable social standing due to John Gregory's occupation. James Gregory's early access to education was likely due to his father's position and the value placed on education within their family. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but as a minister, John Gregory would have had a stable income and a certain level of social respectability. The family lived in a manse (a minister's house), which would have been comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "James Gregory (1638–1675)" by Helen M. Walker in Dictionary of Scientific Biography (1970–1990); "The Gregory Family of Aberdeen: A Tradition of Science and Public Service" by A. D. D. Craik in Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London (2004).

individual_name: Prince Frederick, Duke of York and Albany
explanation: Prince Frederick, Duke of York and Albany, was born into the British royal family, the second eldest son of King George III and Queen Charlotte. His parents were the reigning monarch and consort of the United Kingdom, placing him firmly within the elite class. The royal family held immense wealth and power at the time of his birth, owning numerous palaces and estates across the country. As a prince, Frederick would have had access to the highest level of education available, taught by private tutors and scholars. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, living in royal residences such as Buckingham Palace. His birthright granted him numerous privileges, including titles, wealth, and influence.
sources: "George III: The Life and Reign of Britain's Most Misunderstood Monarch" by Jeremy Black, "The Royal Family: A Year By Year Chronicle of the House of Windsor" by Alison Gauntlett, "The British Monarchy For Dummies" by Philip Wilkinson.

explanation: Edward Sabine was born into a family with military connections, which suggests a middle-class background in the context of late 18th-century Britain. His father, Joseph Sabine, was a general in the British army. This would have provided the family with a stable income and a certain level of social standing, but not to the extent of the aristocracy or ruling class. The military profession was not typically associated with the elite class during this period, but rather with the middle class. It is also likely that Sabine had access to education due to his family background, as the children of military officers often received schooling. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Sabines were particularly wealthy or lived in luxurious conditions.
sources: "Sabine, Sir Edward (1788–1883), army officer and scientist" by A. D. Morrison-Low, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: James Nasmyth was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1808 to Alexander Nasmyth and Barbara Foulis. His father, Alexander Nasmyth, was a renowned landscape and portrait painter, which would have placed the family within the middle class. Alexander Nasmyth was also an art teacher, further solidifying their middle-class status. James Nasmyth's mother, Barbara Foulis, came from a family of artists as well, indicating a similar social standing. The family's wealth would have been moderate, and their social standing would have been respectable due to their artistic professions. James Nasmyth had access to education, as he was taught by his father and attended the Edinburgh High School, a privilege likely afforded by his family's middle-class status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography." (1883) by James Nasmyth and Samuel Smiles; "Alexander Nasmyth: His Life and Art" (1991) by James Holloway.

explanation: Richard Phené Spiers was born in 1838 in London, England. His father, John Spiers, was a successful merchant and a member of the middle class. John Spiers owned a confectionery business, which allowed the family to live comfortably. Richard's mother, Mary Ann Phené, came from a family of Huguenot origin, which was also considered middle class. The family's wealth and social standing allowed Richard to receive a good education. He attended King's College School in London, which was a prestigious institution at the time. This education was not a result of merit, but rather a reflection of his family's social and economic status. The family lived in a comfortable home in London, indicative of their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
1. "Richard Phené Spiers (1838–1916): A French Architect in London" by Hugh D. Clout, The London Journal, Vol. 4, No. 2 (1978), pp. 183-198.
2. "Richard Phené Spiers: Architect, Teacher, and Amateur" by John Physick, The Burlington Magazine, Vol. 108, No. 760 (Jul., 1966), pp. 350-357.
3. "The Huguenots in England: Immigration and Settlement c. 1550-1700" by Bernard Cott

explanation: Francis Quarles was born into a family of notable standing. His father, James Quarles, was a wealthy landowner and a successful lawyer who served as a clerk in the High Court of Chancery, which was a significant position in the English legal system. This suggests that the Quarles family was part of the elite class, as they had substantial wealth and influence. Francis Quarles' access to education was also a result of his family's status. He was educated at Christ's College, Cambridge, and at Lincoln's Inn, both prestigious institutions that were typically accessible only to the upper classes during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. There is no evidence to suggest that Quarles inherited any significant disadvantages.
sources:
- "Francis Quarles", The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
- "Francis Quarles", The Cambridge History of English and American Literature.
- "Francis Quarles", Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Dugald Stewart was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1753. His father, Matthew Stewart, was a professor of mathematics at the University of Edinburgh, indicating a middle-class background. The family would have had a comfortable living, but not the wealth associated with the elite class. Dugald's access to education was also a result of his family background, as his father was a teacher and he was educated at home before attending the University of Edinburgh. There is no evidence to suggest that the family lived in poor conditions or that Dugald inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "The Life and Works of Dugald Stewart" by William Hamilton; "Dugald Stewart" by Thomas Brown; "The Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen" by Robert Chambers.

explanation: Henry Hart Milman was born into an elite family in the United Kingdom. His father, Sir Francis Milman, 1st Baronet, was a physician to King George III, a position that would have placed the family among the upper echelons of society. This is further supported by the fact that Milman was educated at Eton College and later at Brasenose College, Oxford. Both institutions were, and still are, prestigious educational establishments typically attended by the children of the elite. The family's wealth and status would have provided Milman with a comfortable early life and access to opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "Milman, Sir Francis, first baronet (1746–1821)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Henry Hart Milman", Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Philip Henry Delamotte was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Alfred Delamotte, was a notable artist and drawing master at King's College, London. This suggests that the family had a reasonable level of income and social standing, typical of the middle class during this period. Philip's access to education was likely influenced by his father's occupation and the family's middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the Delamotte family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor that they lived in subsistence conditions.
sources: "The Dictionary of National Biography", Oxford University Press, 2004; "The History of Photography: From 1839 to the Present", Beaumont Newhall, 1982.

explanation: George Peele was born to James Peele, a salter and citizen of London. The occupation of a salter, a person who dealt in salt, was a respected trade during this period, indicating that the family was likely of the middle class. George Peele was educated at Christ's Hospital, a charitable school for the sons of the poor and needy freemen of the City of London, which suggests that his family had some standing in the community but were not wealthy. He later attended Oxford University, which would have been a significant financial commitment, further suggesting a middle-class background. There is no evidence to suggest that Peele was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "The Dramatic Works of George Peele, Volume 1" by George Peele, Alexander Dyce; "The Life and Works of George Peele" by Charles Mills Gayley; "George Peele" by David H. Horne.

explanation: James Parkinson was born on April 11, 1755, in Shoreditch, London, England. His father, John Parkinson, was a surgeon, which was a respected profession in the 18th century. This suggests that the Parkinson family was likely part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had a higher social standing than laborers or peasants. James was able to receive an education, which further supports the idea that his family was of the middle class. He attended the London Hospital Medical College, which would have required some level of financial means. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Parkinson family was particularly wealthy or that James inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "James Parkinson: the man behind the shaking palsy". Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2012; "James Parkinson: His Life and Times". Birkhäuser. 1989.

explanation: Isabella Bird was born in 1831 in Boroughbridge, Yorkshire, England. Her father, Reverend Edward Bird, was a clergyman of the Church of England and her mother, Dora Lawson, came from a family of two wealthy Quaker ship owners. Although her father's occupation as a clergyman would not necessarily place the family in the elite class, it does suggest a level of education and respectability associated with the middle class. Furthermore, her mother's family wealth indicates a comfortable upbringing. Isabella Bird was educated at home, which was a common practice for middle-class girls during the Victorian era. The family moved several times during her childhood due to her father's work, living in various parsonages and rectories, which were typically comfortable, if not luxurious, homes. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- "Isabella Bird." Encyclopedia of World Biography, 2nd ed., vol. 2, Gale, 2004, pp. 483-484.
- "Isabella Bird." Dictionary of Women Worldwide: 25,000 Women Through the Ages, edited by Anne Commire and Deborah Klezmer, vol. 1, Yorkin Publications, 2007, pp. 189-190.

explanation:
Thomas Heywood was born in Lincolnshire, England, around 1574. His father, Robert Heywood, was a yeoman, a term used in the late 16th century to describe a free man owning his own farm. This would place the Heywood family in the middle class according to the provided typology, as they were landowners. There is no evidence to suggest that the Heywood family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that Thomas Heywood grew up in a typical middle-class household for the time. 

As for education, it is known that Thomas Heywood attended the University of Cambridge, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a higher education. This further supports the classification of the Heywood family as middle class, as education at this time was often a privilege reserved for the upper classes.

explanation: Sir William de Wiveleslie Abney was born in Derby, England, in 1843. His father, Edward Abney, was a solicitor, which was a respected profession in the middle class during the Victorian era. His mother, Mary Louisa, was the daughter of a clergyman, another middle-class profession. The family was well-off enough to send William to the Royal Military Academy in Woolwich, indicating they had the means to afford a good education for their son. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Abney family was part of the elite or aristocracy, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, it can be inferred that William de Wiveleslie Abney was born into a middle-class family.

explanation: Henry Bessemer was born in Charlton, Hertfordshire, England in 1813. His father, Anthony Bessemer, was a skilled engineer and inventor, who held a government position as a member of the French Academy of Science. His father's occupation and position suggest that the family was of the middle class. Anthony Bessemer was known for his work in art and metallurgy, which would have provided a comfortable income for the family. There is no evidence to suggest that the Bessemer family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. explanation: Robert Smirke was born to a family of moderate means. His father, Richard Smirke, was a builder, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. This is further evidenced by the fact that Robert Smirke was able to receive an education, as he attended the Free School in Durham and later the Royal Academy Schools in London. This suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with an education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Smirke family was particularly wealthy or part of the elite ruling class.

explanation: Sir Henry Wotton was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Thomas Wotton, was a wealthy Kentish gentleman and his mother, Eleanor Finch, was a member of a prominent family in Kent. His father's wealth and social standing allowed him to provide his children with a good education. Henry Wotton was educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford, which were institutions typically attended by the children of the elite. His family's wealth and social standing also provided him with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions. As a member of the elite, he would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to education and a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Reliquiae Wottonianae, or, A collection of lives, letters, poems" by Izaak Walton, "The Life and Letters of Sir Henry Wotton" by Logan Pearsall Smith, "Sir Henry Wotton: A Biographical Sketch" by Arthur F. Marotti.

explanation: William Blake Richmond was born into a middle-class family. His father, George Richmond, was a successful portrait painter and a member of the artistic group known as the Ancients. This group was inspired by the work of William Blake, after whom Richmond was named. His mother, Julia Tatham, was the daughter of a family friend. The Richmond family was not of the aristocracy, but they were not impoverished either. They were part of the professional class, with George Richmond's work as an artist providing a comfortable living. William Blake Richmond would have had access to education due to his family's status, and his early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable for the time. However, he would not have had the inherited privileges associated with the elite class.
sources: "William Blake Richmond: An Artist's Life, 1842-1921" by Hilary Underwood, "The Ancients" by Timothy Wilcox.

explanation: Alexander John Ellis was born Alexander John Sharpe in Hoxton, Middlesex, England, on June 14, 1814. His father, James Birch Sharpe, was a prosperous brewer, which would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Ann Ellis, was the daughter of a wealthy landowner. The family's wealth allowed Ellis to receive a good education, including attending the prestigious Eton College and later Cambridge University. However, it's important to note that while his family was well-off, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class, hence the classification as middle class.
sources: "Alexander John Ellis." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation: James Fittler was born in London in 1758. His family background is not extensively documented, but it is known that he was apprenticed to the engraver Richard Earlom at the age of fourteen. This suggests that his family had enough resources to secure an apprenticeship, a common practice among the middle class of the time. Apprenticeships were often paid for by the family of the apprentice, indicating that Fittler's family had some means. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility. The fact that he needed to be apprenticed also suggests that his family was not wealthy enough to secure his future without him needing to learn a trade.
sources: "James Fittler A.R.A." in 'The Dictionary of National Biography'. London: Smith, Elder & Co. 1885–1900.

explanation: Edward John Trelawny was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Charles Trelawny, was a British army officer and a member of the landed gentry, while his mother, Henrietta Trelawny, was the daughter of a baronet. The Trelawny family had a long history of military and political service, and they owned substantial estates in Cornwall. Edward was the youngest of four children, and he was educated at home by private tutors, a privilege only available to the elite class. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable upbringing and access to opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "Records of the Trelawny Family" (Cornwall Record Office), "The Last Days of Shelley and Byron" by Edward John Trelawny (primary source), "Trelawny: The Incurable Romancer" by William St Clair (biography).

explanation: James Gibbs was born in 1682 in Footdeesmire near Aberdeen, Scotland. His father was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. Gibbs' father died when he was young, but he was able to attend the Grammar school in Aberdeen due to the financial stability provided by his father's merchant profession. He later attended Marischal College, further indicating that his family had sufficient means to support his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Gibbs was born into an elite family with inherited privileges, nor does it appear that he was born into a subsistence-level family.
