explanation: Alexander Dalrymple was born in Newhailes, East Lothian, Scotland, around 1737. His father, Sir James Dalrymple, was a lawyer and the Baron of Newhailes, a title that, while noble, was not associated with significant wealth or power in the Scottish peerage. His mother, Lady Christian Hamilton, was the daughter of an earl. While the family had some status, they were not part of the ruling elite. Dalrymple's father's profession as a lawyer suggests a middle-class background. The family had enough wealth to provide Alexander with a good education, as he attended the Royal High School in Edinburgh, but there is no evidence of extravagant wealth or luxury in his early life.
sources: "The Life of Alexander Dalrymple" by Andrew Cook, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Scottish Nation: Dalrymple" by William Anderson.

explanation: Thomas Stanley was born into a noble family, the Stanley family, which was one of the most prominent families in England during the 16th and 17th centuries. His father, Sir Thomas Stanley, was a Knight and his mother, Alice Spencer, came from the Spencer family, another noble family. The Stanley family was wealthy and owned significant landholdings, including the Isle of Man. As a member of the nobility, Thomas Stanley would have had access to education and lived in comfortable conditions. His birth and childhood social class would therefore be classified as elite.
sources: "The History of the House of Stanley from the Conquest to the Death of the Right Honourable Edward, Late Earl of Derby, in 1776" by John Seacome; "The Peerage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of England" by Arthur Collins.

explanation: John Cam Hobhouse, 1st Baron Broughton, was born into a wealthy family. His father, Sir Benjamin Hobhouse, was a successful merchant and a member of Parliament, which indicates a high social standing. The Hobhouse family was well-established and had considerable wealth, allowing John access to a high-quality education. He attended Westminster School and later Trinity College, Cambridge, which were both prestigious institutions typically attended by the elite class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth. As the son of a successful merchant and politician, John would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to influential social circles and opportunities for advancement.

explanation: George John Romanes was born into a wealthy family. His father, George Romanes, was a successful merchant and landowner, which indicates a high social standing. Romanes was born in Kingston, Canada West, but his family moved back to the United Kingdom when he was young. His family's wealth allowed him to receive a high-quality education, as he was privately tutored before attending the University of Cambridge. explanation: Henry Gray was born in Belgravia, London, in 1827. His father was a private messenger to George IV and William IV, a position that would have provided a stable income and a certain level of social standing, indicating a middle-class background. Gray's early access to education, as evidenced by his enrolment at St. George's Hospital Medical School at the age of 21, also suggests a middle-class upbringing, as such opportunities were typically not available to those from lower social classes during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Gray's family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Henry Gray's Anatomy: Descriptive and Surgical" by Ruth Richardson; "The Making of Mr Gray's Anatomy" by Ruth Richardson.

explanation: Philip Henry Wicksteed was born into a middle-class family. His father, Charles Wicksteed, was a Unitarian minister, a profession that typically fell within the middle class in the 19th century United Kingdom. His mother, Jane Lupton, came from a family of merchants, which also suggests a middle-class background. There is no evidence to suggest that the Wicksteed family was particularly wealthy or impoverished at the time of Philip's birth. As for education, Philip was educated at University College, London, and Manchester New College, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, this was likely due to their professional status rather than any inherited wealth or privilege. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but given their professional status, it is reasonable to assume that they were comfortable, if not luxurious.
sources: "Philip Henry Wicksteed: A Memoir" by Charles Wicksteed (his son), "The Economic Journal" by the Royal Economic Society, "The Letters of Philip Henry Wicksteed" edited by Ian Steedman.

explanation: Isaac D'Israeli was born into a Jewish family of Italian origin. explanation: Samuel Wesley was born into a family with a strong religious background. His father, also named Samuel Wesley, was a clergyman of the Church of England. His mother, Susanna Wesley, was a well-educated woman who played a significant role in the education of her children. The family, while not wealthy, was not poor either. They lived in a parsonage, which indicates a certain level of comfort and stability. However, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. The family's access to education was due to their social standing and the importance they placed on education, rather than wealth. Samuel Wesley's early life was marked by religious and intellectual pursuits, rather than manual labor or servitude, which suggests a middle-class upbringing.

explanation: Arnold Ruge was born into a middle-class family. His father was a pastor, which was a respected profession in the 19th century Prussia. This would have provided the family with a stable income and a certain level of social standing. The fact that Ruge was able to attend university, studying theology and philosophy, suggests that his family had enough resources to afford his education. However, there's no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility.

explanation: George Gascoigne was born into an aristocratic family, which places him in the elite class. His father, Sir John Gascoigne, was a prominent landowner and member of the gentry, which was the lower tier of the aristocracy. This provided George with a privileged upbringing, including access to education, which was not common for those outside of the elite class during this time period. His family wealth and social standing would have also provided him with a comfortable living situation and certain inherited privileges.

explanation: John Fane, 11th Earl of Westmorland, was born into the British aristocracy, a clear indication of his elite status. His father was John Fane, 10th Earl of Westmorland, a prominent figure in British politics and society. His mother, Sarah Anne Child, was the only child of Robert Child, the principal owner of Child's Bank, which was one of the most powerful financial institutions in the country at the time. This means that John Fane was born into significant wealth and privilege. His family's status would have granted him access to the best education available at the time, and he would have grown up in the comfortable surroundings of his family's estates. His birth and childhood circumstances were clearly those of the elite class.
sources: The Peerage, a genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe; "The House of Commons 1790-1820" by R. G. Thorne; "Child & Co.: A History" by Harold Pollins.

explanation: George Alfred Henty, known as G. A. Henty, was born in Trumpington, near Cambridge, England on December 8, 1832. His father, William Henty, was a solicitor, a profession that would place the family in the middle class. His mother, Sarah, was the daughter of a London merchant, further supporting the classification of Henty's family as middle class. The family was not of aristocratic or noble lineage, nor were they laborers or peasants. Henty's family had the means to send him to Westminster School, a prestigious institution, indicating a certain level of wealth and access to education. However, this was due to their family background and not Henty's individual merit. The family lived in a comfortable home in Trumpington, which suggests they were not living in poverty or struggling for resources.
sources: "G. A. Henty: A Bibliographical Study" by Peter Newbolt, "G. A. Henty, 1832-1902: A Bibliographical Study of His British Editions, with Short Accounts of His Publishers, Illustrators and Designers, and Notes on Production Methods Used for His Books" by R. T. S. Bircham.

explanation: William Burges was born on December 2, 1827, in London, England. His father, Alfred Burges, was a civil engineer and surveyor, which was a skilled profession during the 19th century. This occupation would have placed the Burges family in the middle class of society. Alfred Burges was successful enough in his profession to provide his family with a comfortable lifestyle, including a home in a respectable neighborhood. William Burges was also able to receive a good education because of his family's social standing. He attended the prestigious King's College School and later Corpus Christi College, Oxford. This access to education was a privilege that was typically reserved for the middle and upper classes during this time period.
sources:
1. "William Burges." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. Crook, J. Mordaunt. William Burges and the High Victorian Dream. Frances Lincoln Ltd, 2013.

explanation: James Shirley was born to a family of modest means in London, around 1596. His father, also named James Shirley, was a merchant tailor, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class of the social hierarchy of the time. This is further supported by the fact that Shirley was able to attend Merchant Taylors' School, a prestigious institution that catered primarily to the sons of the middle class. His access to education at this school was likely due to his father's occupation and social standing, rather than any inherent merit. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class in late 16th-century England.
sources: "The Dramatic Works and Poems of James Shirley" by James Shirley, Alexander Dyce; "James Shirley: A Study of Literary Tradition and Influence" by Samuel Schoenbaum; "The Merchant Taylors' School Register, 1561-1934" by Merchant Taylors' School (London, England).

explanation: John Edwin Sandys was born on May 19, 1844, in Leicester, England. His father, Reverend Timothy Sandys, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which places the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. The clergy were typically considered part of the middle class, as they were educated and held a respected position in society, but they were not part of the aristocracy. There is no evidence to suggest that the Sandys family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they lived comfortably but not extravagantly. John Edwin Sandys had access to education, as he attended the Leicester School and later St. John's College, Cambridge, which suggests that his family had the means to support his education. However, this does not necessarily indicate that the family was wealthy, as education was highly valued in middle-class Victorian society and families often prioritized spending on education.
sources: "John Edwin Sandys", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Victorian Middle Class", BBC History; "The Social Structure of Victorian England", Victorian Web.

explanation: Robert Stawell Ball was born on July 1, 1840, in Dublin, Ireland, to Amelia Gresley Hellicar and Bob Stawell Ball. His father, Bob Stawell Ball, was an amateur astronomer and a professional naturalist, working as a curator of the Dublin Zoo. This suggests that the family had a stable income and a certain level of education, which are characteristics of the middle class. Robert's access to education was also likely due to his family background. His father's interest in astronomy probably influenced Robert's own interest in the subject, and he was able to study at the University of Dublin, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but given Bob Stawell Ball's occupation, it is reasonable to assume that they were comfortable, if not affluent.
sources: "Robert Stawell Ball." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Stawell-Ball. "Robert Stawell Ball." The MacTutor History of Mathematics archive, https://mathshistory.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Ball_Robert/.

explanation: Ingram Bywater was born in 1840 in Paddington, London, England. His father, Thomas Bywater, was a successful merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Bywater family would have had enough wealth to provide a comfortable life for Ingram and his siblings, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Ingram's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended the City of London School and later Queen's College, Oxford. This level of education was not typically accessible to those in the subsistence class, further supporting the classification of the Bywater family as middle class. Information about the family's early life housing and living conditions is not readily available, but given their middle-class status, it can be inferred that they were likely adequate and comfortable for the time.
