This suggests that the Dodwell family was not part of the elite ruling class or nobility, but rather belonged to the middle class. The elder Dodwell's occupation as a civil servant would have provided a stable, if not particularly affluent, income for the family. There is no evidence to suggest that the Dodwells were particularly wealthy or that they lived in opulent housing, but their income would have been sufficient to provide for their needs and some comforts. Henry Dodwell was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, suggesting that his family had the means to provide him with a good education, a privilege not available to those of lower social classes at the time.
sources: "Henry Dodwell (1641-1711): A Biographical Essay" by R. K. Webb, Journal of the History of Ideas, Vol. 20, No. 2 (Apr. - Jun., 1959), pp. 235-255; "Dodwell, Henry (1641-1711)" by Leslie Stephen, Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 15.

explanation: Augustus Hare was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Francis George Hare, was the 2nd son of the 1st Earl of Listowel, a title of nobility in the Peerage of Ireland. His mother, Maria Leycester, was the daughter of a rector and the niece of the Dean of York, indicating a high social standing on her side of the family as well. The Hare family owned considerable property, including the Stow Bardolph estate in Norfolk, which was passed down through generations. Augustus was born at the family's London residence, and he spent his early childhood in Rome, Italy, where his family owned a villa. His access to education was also a result of his family's status; he was educated at home by private tutors before attending Harrow School, a prestigious boarding school in London.
sources:
1. "The Story of My Life" by Augustus J.C. Hare (his autobiography)
2. "The Peerage of Ireland" by John Lodge, Mervyn Archdall
3. "Harrow School Register" by Reginald Courtenay Welch
4. "The Hare Family of Listowel and the Stow Bardolph Estate" by Susanna Wade Martins, Norfolk Archaeology.

explanation: Edward Burnett Tylor was born on October 2, 1832, in Camberwell, London, England. His father, Joseph Tylor, was a brass founder and a successful businessman. The Tylor family was part of the Quaker community, which was known for its emphasis on education and self-improvement. This suggests that Tylor had access to education due to his family background. His father's occupation as a brass founder indicates that the family was likely part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had a stable income from a skilled trade. There is no evidence to suggest that Tylor was born into poverty or extreme wealth, so the middle class is the most likely classification.
sources: "Edward Burnett Tylor, Religion and Culture" by Paul-François Tremlett, Bloomsbury Publishing, 2017; "Edward B. Tylor" by George W. Stocking, University of Wisconsin Press, 1995.

explanation:
Henry More was born in Grantham, Lincolnshire in England around 1614. His father, Alexander More, was a respected local gentleman and a successful businessman who had made a fortune in the cloth trade. This suggests that the More family were comfortably middle class, with a stable income and a good reputation in their community. Henry's mother, Anne More, was also from a respectable family. 

The More family's wealth and social standing allowed Henry to receive a good education. He was sent to Eton College, a prestigious school for boys, and later attended Christ's College, Cambridge. This level of education was typically only accessible to the middle and upper classes during this period.

In terms of housing and living conditions, it can be inferred that the More family lived comfortably. The fact that Alexander More was able to amass a significant fortune in the cloth trade suggests that the family would have been able to afford a decent home and a comfortable lifestyle.

As for inherited privileges or disadvantages, it seems that Henry More was born into a relatively privileged situation. His family's wealth and social standing would have afforded him opportunities that were not available to those from lower social classes.
sources:
- "Henry More (1614–1687)" by Sarah Hutton, Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, 2006.
- "The Life of Henry More: Parts 1 and 2" by Richard Ward, 1710.

explanation: Giuseppe Marc'Antonio Baretti was born in Turin, Italy, not the United Kingdom, in 1719. His father was a lawyer, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but neither were they subsistence workers or laborers. Baretti's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as his father would have had the resources to provide for his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Baretti grew up in poverty or that he had any inherited privileges or disadvantages due to his birth. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in Turin during the early 18th century.
sources: "Baretti, Giuseppe Marc'Antonio." Encyclopedia of Italian Literary Studies, edited by Gaetana Marrone, Routledge, 2007.

explanation: William Powell Frith was born in Aldfield, North Yorkshire, England, in 1819. His father, James Frith, was a domestic servant and later a hotelier, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Jane Powell, was a housewife. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to send William to study at the Sass's Academy of Art in London when he was 15, indicating that they had some disposable income and valued education. This level of education was not common among the subsistence class, further suggesting a middle-class upbringing. The family's ability to operate a hotel also indicates a certain level of financial stability and social standing, typical of the middle class during this period in the United Kingdom.
sources: "William Powell Frith: Painting the Victorian Age" by Mark Bills and Vivien Knight; "The Victorian Artist: Artists' Life Writings in Britain, c. 1870-1910" by Julie F. Codell.

explanation: Nahum Tate was born in Dublin, Ireland around 1652. His father, Faithful Teate, was a clergyman and a member of the Protestant Ascendancy in Ireland, which was a minority but held a significant amount of power and wealth. Faithful Teate was also a published poet, indicating a level of education and cultural capital. This suggests that Nahum Tate was born into a middle-class family, with access to education and a certain degree of comfort, but not to the level of the elite or nobility. However, the family's fortunes declined during the Irish Confederate Wars when Faithful Teate lost his estate and was forced to flee to England, which may have impacted Nahum Tate's childhood circumstances.
sources: "Nahum Tate." The Columbia Encyclopedia, Paul Lagasse, and Columbia University, Columbia University Press, 8th edition, 2018. "Faithful Teate." Dictionary of Irish Biography, James McGuire and James Quinn, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 2009.

explanation: John Webster was born around 1578 in London, England. His father, a prosperous carriage maker, was a member of the Merchant Taylors' Company, a prestigious city guild. This suggests that Webster's family was of the middle class, as guild membership often indicated a certain level of wealth and social standing. The family's ability to provide Webster with an education, as he attended the Merchant Taylors' School, further supports this classification. However, it's important to note that the details of Webster's early life are not well-documented, and there is limited information available about his family's wealth or living conditions.
sources: "John Webster." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., February 28, 2020. "John Webster." The Cambridge Guide to Theatre. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1995.

explanation: George Farquhar was born in Londonderry, Ireland, around 1677. His father, William Farquhar, was a clergyman of the Church of Ireland, which would place the family in the middle class during this period. The clergy were typically educated and held a certain social standing, but they were not part of the nobility or ruling class. Farquhar's access to education was likely due to his father's occupation and status. He attended the local grammar school and later Trinity College in Dublin, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with an education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Farquhar family was particularly wealthy or that George Farquhar inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Works of George Farquhar" by George Farquhar, edited by Shirley Strum Kenny; "George Farquhar" by William A. Armstrong.

explanation: Joseph Paxton was born in 1803 in Bedfordshire, England, to a farming family. His parents, William and Ann Paxton, were working-class individuals who made their living through agriculture. As such, Paxton's family would have been considered part of the subsistence class, as they were laborers with minimal resources. Paxton's early life was marked by hard work on the family farm, and he did not have access to formal education due to his family's socioeconomic status. Instead, he was apprenticed to a local gardener at a young age, which was a common practice for children from working-class families at the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, reflecting his family's working-class status.
sources: "Sir Joseph Paxton (1803–1865): A bibliography" by Breakell, Sue (2007), "Joseph Paxton and the Crystal Palace" by George F. Chadwick (1961), and "The Victorian Garden" by Tom Carter (1985).

explanation: Thomas Middleton was born to a well-to-do middle-class family in London. His father, William Middleton, was a bricklayer who had served as a warden of the Bricklayers' Company, indicating a level of respect and standing within his trade. His mother, Anne Middleton, was the daughter of a gentleman, which suggests that the family had some social standing. The family's wealth is evidenced by the fact that they owned property in London. Thomas Middleton was able to attend Oxford University, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Thomas Middleton: The Collected Works" (Taylor & Lavagnino, 2007); "Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture: A Companion to the Collected Works" (Taylor & Lavagnino, 2007); "The Oxford Handbook of Thomas Middleton" (Bloom, 2012).

explanation: Giovanni Battista Cipriani was born in Florence, Italy, in 1727. His father, Alessandro Cipriani, was a sculptor, which suggests a middle-class background, as sculpting was a skilled craft. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their time and place. The fact that Giovanni was able to train as an artist under Ignazio Hugford and David Allan, both well-respected artists of their time, suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that this education was due to inherited privilege rather than merit. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were adequate for a family of their social standing.
sources: "Giovanni Battista Cipriani." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004. "Giovanni Battista Cipriani." The National Gallery, London.

explanation: Nicholas Patrick Stephen Wiseman was born in Seville, Spain, in 1802 to Irish parents. His father, James Wiseman, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The family moved back to Ireland when Nicholas was still young, and he was sent to Ushaw College, Durham, England, for his education. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide their son with a good education, further supporting their middle-class status. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages, and the family's living conditions are not well-documented, but their ability to move internationally and educate their children suggests a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Cardinal Wiseman: His Life and Times" by Wilfrid Philip Ward, "The Life and Times of Nicholas Wiseman" by Wilfrid Ward.

explanation: George Biddell Airy was born on July 27, 1801, in Alnwick, Northumberland, England. His father, William Airy, was a small squire and a collector of excise, and his mother, Ann Biddell, was a woman of vigour and intelligence. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were part of the middle class, with enough resources to provide a decent life for their children. Airy's father's occupation as a collector of excise indicates a position of some responsibility and status within the community, typical of the middle class. The family's financial situation was stable enough to allow Airy to attend schools in Hereford and Colchester, indicating access to education based on family background. However, the death of his father when Airy was only two years old did put some financial strain on the family.
sources: "George Biddell Airy." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Biddell-Airy. "Airy, George Biddell (1801–1892), astronomer royal." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-210.

explanation: Margaret Cavendish was born into an aristocratic family, the Lucas family, which was one of the wealthiest families in England at the time. Her father, Sir Thomas Lucas, was a knight and her mother, Elizabeth Leighton, came from a family with royal connections. Margaret was the youngest of eight children, and her family's wealth and status would have provided her with a comfortable upbringing. Her family's wealth also allowed her access to education, which was uncommon for women at the time. She was tutored at home and had access to her family's extensive library. The Lucas family lived in a large estate, St. John's Abbey, which further indicates their elite status.
sources:
1. Whitaker, Katie. "Mad Madge": The Extraordinary Life of Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle, the First Woman to Live by Her Pen. Basic Books, 2002.
2. Battigelli, Anna. Margaret Cavendish and the Exiles of the Mind. University Press of Kentucky, 1998.
3. Clucas, Stephen. A Princely Brave Woman: Essays on Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle. Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2003.

explanation:
Charles Bell was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1774. His father, the Reverend William Bell, was a clergyman of the Episcopal Church of Scotland, which indicates a middle-class status. His mother, Margaret, was the sister of John Hunter, a renowned anatomist and surgeon, suggesting a family with some intellectual standing. The family was not of the nobility or ruling class, nor were they laborers or peasants, which rules out the classifications of Elite and Subsistence. 

Charles Bell was the fourth son in the family, and he had access to education, which was not a common privilege for lower-class families in the late 18th century. He was educated at the High School in Edinburgh, a prestigious institution, indicating that his family had the means to afford such an education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, typical of a middle-class family of the time.
sources:
- "Charles Bell (1774–1842)." The Embryo Project Encyclopedia. https://embryo.asu.edu/pages/charles-bell-1774-1842
- "Bell, Sir Charles (1774–1842), surgeon and anatomist." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-2024
-

explanation: George Borrow was born in East Dereham, Norfolk, England in 1803. His father, Thomas Borrow, was a military man, serving as a lieutenant in the West Norfolk Militia. His mother, Ann Perfrement, was from a family of farmers and landowners. The Borrow family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They had a comfortable life, typical of the middle class of that time. George Borrow's education was also typical of the middle class. He was educated at the Royal High School of Edinburgh and later studied law, but did not pursue it as a career. His family lived in comfortable, but not luxurious, housing. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Life of George Borrow" by Herbert Jenkins, "George Borrow: The Man and His Books" by Edward Thomas, "George Borrow and His Circle" by Clement King Shorter.

explanation: Edwin Arnold was born on June 10, 1832, in Gravesend, Kent, England. His father, Robert Coles Arnold, was a schoolmaster, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class. The profession of a schoolmaster was considered a respectable occupation and was associated with the middle class during the Victorian era in England. Edwin Arnold was also able to receive a good education, attending King's School, Rochester, and then King's College, London, before going on to study at University College, Oxford. This access to education suggests that his family had some means, further supporting the classification of the family as middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or belonged to the elite class.
sources: "Edwin Arnold." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., 2021. Web. 20 Sep. 2021.

explanation: John Leech was born in London in 1817. His father, a well-off vintner and coffee-house keeper, provided a comfortable middle-class upbringing for Leech. His family's wealth and status allowed him to attend Charterhouse School, a prestigious boarding school in London, indicating a level of financial stability and access to education typically associated with the middle class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his family's middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Leech and the Victorian Scene: 1817-1864" by Simon Houfe, "John Leech, his life and work. Vol. 1" by William Powell Frith, "The Life and Work of John Leech" by John Brown.

explanation:
Margaret Oliphant was born on April 4, 1828, in Wallyford, near Musselburgh, East Lothian, Scotland. Her father, Francis Wilson Oliphant, was a clerk in the customs office in Glasgow, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. Her mother, Margaret Oliphant (nee Passmore), was the daughter of a London merchant, which also suggests a middle-class background. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Margaret was the youngest of eight children, and the family lived in a comfortable home in Glasgow. 

Margaret's access to education was typical for a middle-class girl of her time. She was educated at home by her mother, who taught her to read and write. She also had access to her father's extensive library, which allowed her to develop her literary talents from a young age. 

In terms of inherited privileges or disadvantages, Margaret's middle-class background would have provided her with a certain level of comfort and security, but she would not have had the same opportunities or privileges as a child from the elite class. However, her family's financial situation was precarious, and they struggled with debt, which may have limited her opportunities.
sources:
- "Margaret Oliphant." In Dictionary of Literary Biography, 1997.
- "Margaret Oliphant." In Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, 2004.
-

explanation: Samuel Prout was born in Plymouth, Devon, England in 1783. His father, Samuel Prout, was a naval outfitter, a profession that would likely place the family in the middle class of the time. This would have provided a level of financial stability, allowing Prout access to education. Indeed, he was educated at Plymouth Grammar School, indicating that his family had the means to afford such schooling. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Prout family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Prout's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Samuel Prout, 1783–1852, British" (The J. Paul Getty Museum); "Samuel Prout: A Biography" by John Finch.

explanation: James Anthony Froude was born in Dartington, Devon, England, on April 23, 1818. His father, Robert Hurrell Froude, was an Anglican clergyman, indicating a middle-class status. The Froude family was not part of the aristocracy or nobility, nor were they subsistence workers or laborers. They were part of the educated class, with Robert Hurrell Froude having been a fellow of Oriel College, Oxford. James Anthony Froude's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. He attended Westminster School and Oriel College, Oxford, following in his father's footsteps. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not opulent, typical of the middle class of the time.
sources:
- "James Anthony Froude." Encyclopedia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/James-Anthony-Froude
- "Robert Hurrell Froude." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10183
- "James Anthony Froude." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10184

explanation: Anna Laetitia Barbauld was born into a middle-class family. Her father, John Aikin, was a schoolmaster and a Dissenting minister, which places him in the middle class as a professional. Her mother, Jane Jennings, was also from a middle-class family. The Aikin family was not wealthy, but they were comfortable enough to provide Anna with a good education. Anna's father taught her classics, including Latin and Greek, which was unusual for girls at the time but indicates a certain level of family resources and prioritization of education. The family lived in a schoolhouse, which suggests a modest but not impoverished living condition. There's no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: McCarthy, W. (2004). Anna Letitia Barbauld: Voice of the Enlightenment. Johns Hopkins University Press. ; Ellis, G. (2002). A History of the English-Speaking Peoples Since 1900. HarperCollins.

explanation: Mary Elizabeth Braddon was born in London in 1835 to Fanny Braddon and Henry Braddon, a solicitor. Her father's profession as a solicitor indicates that the family was of the middle class, as this was a profession that required a certain level of education and was associated with a comfortable income. The family was not of the elite class, as there is no evidence of aristocratic lineage or inherited wealth. However, they were also not subsistence class, as Henry's profession allowed for a lifestyle above mere subsistence. Mary's access to education was likely due to her family's middle-class status. However, her father's later financial difficulties and eventual departure to India, leaving the family behind, may have impacted the family's social standing and economic stability.
sources: "Mary Elizabeth Braddon (1835–1915)." Victorian Web. "Mary Elizabeth Braddon." The British Library. "Mary Elizabeth Braddon." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Philip James de Loutherbourg was born in Strasbourg, France, in 1740 to a family of artists and miniaturists. His father, Johann Jakob de Loutherbourg, was a miniaturist and a court painter to the Duke of Württemberg. His mother, Maria Magdalena, was also an artist. This suggests that the family had a certain level of social standing and economic stability, as they were employed by the court and were able to support their artistic pursuits. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or aristocracy. As for education, Philip was likely taught art by his parents from a young age, indicating access to education due to his family background. The family's occupation and access to education suggest they were part of the middle class.
sources: "Philip James de Loutherbourg." The J. Paul Getty Museum. www.getty.edu/art/collection/artists/1154/philip-james-de-loutherbourg-british-born-france-1740-1812/; "Philip James de Loutherbourg." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-16576.

explanation: Caroline Elizabeth Sarah Norton was born into an aristocratic family. Her father, Thomas Sheridan, was an actor, soldier, and colonial administrator, and her mother, Caroline Henrietta Callander, was a noted author. Her paternal grandfather, Richard Brinsley Sheridan, was a well-known playwright and Whig statesman. This indicates that her family had a high social standing in society. Her family's wealth and status would have provided her with access to education and comfortable living conditions. However, her father's death when she was eight years old led to financial instability, but her mother's literary connections helped to maintain their social standing.
sources: "The Life of Mrs. Norton" by Jane Gray Perkins, 1909; "The Scandalous Lady Norton" by Carole Seymour-Jones, 2015.

explanation: Sir Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baronet, was born into an elite family. His father was Abram Tyzack Rawlinson, a wealthy merchant who was also part of the landed gentry, owning a large estate in Chadlington, Oxfordshire. His mother, Eliza Eudocia Albinia Creswicke, was the daughter of a wealthy landowner. This indicates that Rawlinson was born into a family of considerable wealth and status. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to a high-quality education, which was typically reserved for the elite during this time period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth. He would have also had inherited privileges due to his family's status.
sources: "The Rawlinson Family." The Rawlinson Project, University of Oxford. "Sir Henry Creswicke Rawlinson." Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Ellen Terry was born into a family of actors, which was a respected profession but not one of great wealth or high social standing. Her parents, Benjamin, of Irish descent, and Sarah, of Scottish descent, were both actors. She was the third of eleven children, indicating a large family that likely had to spread its resources. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, suggesting a middle-class upbringing. The family's profession in the arts would have provided Terry with access to education and cultural experiences, but this would have been due to their profession rather than any inherited wealth or privilege. Her early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but it is likely that they were typical of a middle-class family in the mid-19th century.
sources: "Ellen Terry." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Ellen-Terry; "Ellen Terry." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-36461.

explanation: Charles Wesley was born on December 18, 1707, in Epworth, Lincolnshire, England. He was the eighteenth child of Samuel Wesley and Susanna Wesley. His father, Samuel Wesley, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which would place the family in the middle class according to the given typology. Samuel Wesley served as the rector of Epworth, indicating a position of some respect and stability, though not immense wealth. Charles Wesley's mother, Susanna Wesley, was the daughter of a minister, further solidifying their middle-class status. The family, while not wealthy, was able to provide Charles Wesley with an education, as he attended the Westminster School and later Christ Church, Oxford. This access to education suggests a level of financial stability and social standing beyond that of the subsistence class. However, it should be noted that the family did experience periods of financial difficulty, particularly due to Samuel Wesley's mismanagement of finances and the size of the family.
sources: "Charles Wesley: English Clergyman and Poet." Encyclopædia Britannica. "The Journal of Charles Wesley." The Wesley Center Online. "Susanna Wesley: Mother of Methodism." The United Methodist Church.

explanation: Frances Burney was born into a family of musicians and scholars, which places her in the middle class according to the given typology. Her father, Dr. Charles Burney, was a well-known music historian, composer, and musician. Her mother, Esther Sleepe Burney, was the daughter of a French refugee. Although her father's profession provided them with a comfortable living, they were not part of the elite or nobility. Frances Burney had access to education because of her family background. Her father's extensive library allowed her to self-educate, and she was also taught by her elder siblings. Her early life housing and living conditions were comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Journals and Letters of Fanny Burney (Madame d'Arblay)" by Fanny Burney, "Frances Burney: The Life in the Works" by Margaret Anne Doody, "Dr. Charles Burney: A Literary Biography" by Lonsdale Ragg.

explanation: Walter Bagehot was born in Langport, Somerset, England, in 1826 to Thomas Watson Bagehot and Mary Stuckey Bagehot. His father, Thomas, was a managing director of Stuckey's Banking Company, a regional bank in the West of England. This indicates a middle-class background, as banking was a profession typically associated with the middle class during this period. His mother, Mary, was from a family of ship owners, another profession indicative of middle-class status. The family's wealth would have provided Walter with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. He was educated at University College London, which was not a traditional path for the elite class, who typically attended Oxford or Cambridge. This suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education, but they were not part of the elite class.
sources: "The English Constitution and Other Political Essays" by Walter Bagehot; "Walter Bagehot: A Life" by Alastair Buchan; "The Life of Walter Bagehot" by Emily Barrington.

explanation: Richard Cobden was born in Sussex, England in 1804. His father, William Cobden, was a farmer, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The Cobden family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough to maintain a decent standard of living, but the death of Richard's father when he was just 15 led to financial difficulties for the family. Despite these challenges, Richard was able to receive an education. He attended a grammar school in Yorkshire, which was paid for by his uncle. This indicates that the family had some resources and connections, further supporting their classification as middle class. Richard's early life was spent in a rural setting, living in a farmhouse, which was typical for families of their social standing at the time.
sources: "Richard Cobden: A Victorian Outsider" by Anthony Howe; "The Political Economy of Peace: Richard Cobden's Relevance Today" by Nicholas C. Edsall.

explanation: Richard Cosway was born in Tiverton, Devon, England, in 1742. His father, Samuel Cosway, was a schoolmaster, which suggests a middle-class background, as education was a profession typically associated with this social stratum during the 18th century. His mother, Mary Cosway, was reported to be a talented musician, which further suggests a middle-class upbringing, as the ability to pursue music often required some level of financial stability and access to education. There is no evidence to suggest that the Cosway family was particularly wealthy or part of the elite class, nor that they were struggling for subsistence. Richard and his brother William were both sent to London to study at the Duke of Richmond's academy, indicating that the family had the means to invest in their children's education. However, it should be noted that this does not necessarily indicate a high level of wealth, as education was highly valued in middle-class families of this period.
sources: "Richard Cosway, R.A." by George C. Williamson, published in 1905; "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee, published in 1885-1900.

explanation: George Henry Lewes was born in London in 1817 to a minor poet and a mother of Huguenot descent. His father, John Lee Lewes, was an actor and minor poet, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Elizabeth Ashweek, was from a family of Huguenot refugees. Lewes was educated at a variety of schools, including Dr Charles Burney's in Greenwich, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a decent education. However, his father's death when Lewes was just a child and subsequent financial difficulties faced by his mother suggest that the family was not wealthy. Lewes was sent to live with a Quaker family in London after his father's death, which suggests that his mother struggled to provide for him.
sources:
- "George Henry Lewes." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Henry-Lewes
- "George Henry Lewes: A Uniquely Victorian Mind." Victorian Web. http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/ghlewis/bio1.html
- "George Henry Lewes." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-16544

explanation: Richard Earlom was born in Liverpool, England, around 1743. His father, Richard Earlom Sr., was a coach and harness maker, a skilled craft that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. This occupation would have provided a stable income for the family, but not to the extent of the wealth associated with the elite class. There is no evidence to suggest that the family had significant wealth or land beyond what would be expected for their class. Earlom's access to education is not well-documented, but his early apprenticeship with record painter Jeremiah Meyer suggests that he had some access to training in the arts, which would have been more likely for a middle-class child than for a child from a subsistence-level family. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but as a coach and harness maker, Earlom Sr. would likely have been able to provide a comfortable home for his family.
sources: "Richard Earlom (1743–1822), Mezzotint Engraver" by Timothy Clayton, published in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Dictionary of British 18th Century Painters in Oils and Crayons" by Ellis Waterhouse.

explanation: Johann Baptist Cramer was born in Mannheim, Germany, in 1771 and moved to England with his family when he was a young child. His father, Wilhelm Cramer, was a renowned violinist who served as the leader of the King's band in England. This suggests that the family had a certain level of social standing and financial stability, as Wilhelm's position would have been a respected and reasonably well-paid one. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or aristocracy. The family's access to music education, which Johann received from an early age, further supports their middle-class status. This education was likely a result of Wilhelm's profession and connections in the music world, rather than a reflection of the family's wealth or social standing.
sources: Grove Music Online, Oxford University Press; "Johann Baptist Cramer: A Thematic Catalogue of His Works" by Howard Irving, PhD, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

explanation: Grant Allen was born on February 24, 1848, in Alwington, near Kingston, Canada West (now Ontario), to Joseph Antisell Allen and Catharine Ann Grant. His father, Joseph Antisell Allen, was a Protestant minister and a professor of natural history and Greek at Queen's University, Kingston. His mother, Catharine Ann Grant, was the daughter of a Scottish merchant. This suggests that Allen was born into a middle-class family, as his father was a professional and his mother came from a merchant family. His father's occupation as a minister and professor would have likely provided Allen with access to education, further supporting his classification as middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was exceptionally wealthy or part of the elite ruling class.
sources:
1. "Grant Allen: A Memoir", by Edward Clodd, 1900.
2. "Grant Allen: Literature and Cultural Politics at the Fin de Siècle" by Dennis Denisoff, 2005.
3. "The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction" by John Clute, Peter Nicholls, and David Langford, 2012.

explanation: Benjamin Jowett was born in Camberwell, London, in 1817 to Isabella Langhorne and Benjamin Jowett Sr. His father was a furrier, a skilled trade occupation, which would place the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to provide for their children and ensure they received an education. Benjamin Jowett was the third of nine children, indicating that the family had enough resources to support a large family. Jowett's father died when he was young, but his mother was able to continue supporting the family and ensuring the children received an education. Jowett attended St Paul's School in London, a fee-paying school, indicating that the family had some disposable income. However, his access to higher education at Balliol College, Oxford, was due to a scholarship, not family wealth.
sources: "Benjamin Jowett and the Christian Religion" by Peter Hinchliff, "The Life and Letters of Benjamin Jowett, M.A., Master of Balliol College, Oxford" by Evelyn Abbott and Lewis Campbell.

explanation: John Toland was born in Ardagh on the Inishowen Peninsula, a rural area in the north of Ireland. He was born into a Catholic family, which was a disadvantaged group in Ireland at the time due to the Penal Laws. His parents were likely peasants or laborers, as they were unable to provide him with a formal education. Toland was initially educated by a local priest before being taken in by a Protestant family who provided him with further education. His early life was marked by poverty and religious discrimination, which would have limited his opportunities and access to resources.
sources: "John Toland: His Life and Works" by Stephen H. Daniel, "John Toland and the Deist Controversy: A Study in Adaptations" by Robert E. Sullivan.

explanation: Isaac Vossius was born in 1618 in Leiden, Netherlands, not the United Kingdom. His father, Gerardus Vossius, was a respected scholar and professor of rhetoric and chronology at the University of Leiden. This suggests that the family was part of the educated middle class. Gerardus Vossius was known to have a large library, indicating a certain level of wealth and access to education for Isaac. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Vossius family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility. The family's wealth and status seem to have been based on Gerardus' academic work rather than inherited privilege or land ownership. Isaac's early life would likely have been spent in a comfortable, scholarly environment, with access to his father's library and intellectual circles.
sources: "Gerardus Vossius" in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; "Isaac Vossius (1618-1689) and his Circle: His Life until his Farewell to Queen Christina of Sweden, 1654" by Eric Jorink and Dirk van Miert.

explanation: Johann Joachim Becher was born in Speyer, Germany, in 1635. His father was a Lutheran minister, which would place the family in the middle class, as clergy were typically considered part of this social stratum during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy, but his father's occupation would have provided a stable, if modest, income. Becher was able to attend the University of Helmstedt due to his father's occupation, which suggests a certain level of financial stability and access to education.
sources: "Johann Joachim Becher" in Complete Dictionary of Scientific Biography. Vol. 1. Detroit: Charles Scribner's Sons, 2008. p. 491-492.

explanation: Sydney, Lady Morgan, was born as Sydney Owenson to Robert Owenson and Jane Hill. Her father was an actor and her mother was the daughter of a Shropshire clergyman. Robert Owenson was also a published author, indicating a level of literacy and education not common among the lower classes. However, the family was not part of the aristocracy or ruling class, suggesting a middle-class background. The family did face financial difficulties, particularly after the death of Sydney's mother, but they were not in abject poverty. Sydney and her sister were educated, with Sydney showing a talent for writing from a young age. This suggests that despite their financial struggles, the family had access to some level of education, further supporting a middle-class classification.
sources: "Lady Morgan (Sydney Owenson)" by Julia M. Wright, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Sydney Owenson, Lady Morgan and the Politics of Style" by Susan B. Egenolf, The Eighteenth Century.

explanation: Samuel Smiles was born in Haddington, East Lothian, Scotland in 1812. His father, also named Samuel, was a paper maker and stationer, a trade that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class of the time. His mother, Janet Wilson, was the daughter of a local builder. The family was not wealthy, but they were comfortable and had access to basic necessities. Smiles was one of eleven children, which suggests that the family was not impoverished, as they were able to support a large family. Smiles' father's occupation as a paper maker and stationer would have given the family a steady income and a respectable social standing within their community. Smiles was able to attend a local school due to his family's middle-class status, which indicates that they had the financial means to provide him with an education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in the early 19th century Scotland, likely living in a modest but comfortable home.
sources: "Self-Help; with Illustrations of Character and Conduct" by Samuel Smiles; "Samuel Smiles and the Construction of Victorian Values" by Adrian Jarvis; "Samuel Smiles: A Life in Letters" by John Hunter.

explanation: Augustus De Morgan was born in Madurai, India, in 1806 to Colonel John De Morgan and his wife Elizabeth. His father was a British officer in the Indian Army, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family had enough wealth to provide for their children's education, as evidenced by De Morgan's early schooling in several private institutions. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the De Morgans were part of the elite ruling class or nobility. They returned to England when Augustus was seven months old, and his father died in 1816, leaving the family in a financially precarious situation. Despite this, Augustus was able to attend Trinity College, Cambridge, likely due to the family's middle-class status and connections rather than their wealth.
sources: "Augustus De Morgan." Encyclopedia Britannica. "Augustus De Morgan and the Logic of Relations." Durham E-Theses. "Augustus De Morgan." Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

explanation: Anna Sewell was born on March 30, 1820, in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, England. Her parents were Mary Wright Sewell and Isaac Sewell. Her father was a bank manager, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the 19th century. Her mother, Mary Wright Sewell, was a successful children's book author, which would have also contributed to their middle-class status. The family was Quaker, a religious group known for their emphasis on education, suggesting that Anna likely had access to education due to her family background. The family moved to Stoke Newington when Anna was twelve, where she attended school until she was fourteen. The family's ability to move and to afford schooling for Anna further suggests a middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the Sewells were either part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources:
1. "Anna Sewell." British Library, www.bl.uk/people/anna-sewell
2. "Anna Sewell." Encyclopædia Britannica, www.britannica.com/biography/Anna-Sewell
3. "Anna Sewell." The Literature Network, www.online-literature.com/anna-sewell/

explanation:
Clements Robert Markham was born on 20 July 1830 in Stillingfleet, Yorkshire, England. He was born into a family of the English gentry, which is considered part of the elite class. His father, Reverend David Frederick Markham, was the Canon of Windsor from 1827 to 1853, a prestigious position in the Church of England. His mother, Catherine, was the daughter of Sir Robert Dundas. The Markham family had a long history of service to the crown and the church, which would have afforded them a comfortable lifestyle and high social standing.

Clements Markham had access to education because of his family background. He was educated at Westminster School, one of the top public schools in England, which was typically reserved for the children of the elite. His family's wealth and social standing would have also provided him with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions.
sources:
1. "Markham, Sir Clements Robert" by H. R. Mill in Dictionary of National Biography, 1912 supplement​. 
2. "The Markhams of Ollerton: A History of the Markham Family" by David Markham, 2010. 
3. "Westminster School: Its Scholars and Its History" by Arthur D. Innes, 1903.

explanation: Thomas Love Peacock was born in Weymouth, Dorset, England in 1785. His father was a London merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. His mother, a woman of Cornish family, was a daughter of Thomas Love, who was involved in the East India Company, which again suggests a middle-class background. After his father's death when Peacock was three years old, he was raised by his mother in her family home in Chertsey, Surrey. This indicates that the family had some wealth and property, reinforcing the classification of middle class. Peacock received a good education, attending a private school in Englefield Green where he received a classical education, which would have been accessible primarily to the middle and upper classes at the time.
sources: "Thomas Love Peacock." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Love-Peacock. "Thomas Love Peacock." The Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/thomas-love-peacock.

explanation: John Opie was born in the small village of St Agnes, near Truro, in Cornwall. His father, Edward Opie, was a master carpenter, and his mother, Mary (née Tonkin), was the daughter of a local mine captain. They were not wealthy and lived a modest lifestyle. The family was of lower social standing, and their economic situation was precarious, as was common for working-class families in rural areas of Britain in the late 18th century. Opie's education was limited and mostly self-taught, as his family could not afford formal schooling. He learned to read and write from his mother, and he showed an early talent for drawing, which he developed on his own. His early life housing and living conditions were humble, typical of a working-class family of the time. There were no inherited privileges or advantages in his background.
sources: "John Opie: A Phenomenon in Art" by Viv Hendra; "John Opie and the Radical Defence of Genius" by Amelia Yeates in Art History, Vol. 35, No. 1 (February 2012), pp. 132-157.

explanation: John Dalton was born in Eaglesfield, Cumberland, England, in 1766. His father, Joseph Dalton, was a weaver by trade, a profession that was considered skilled labor and would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. His mother, Deborah Greenup, was from a family of tradesmen and small landowners, further supporting the middle class classification. The family was not wealthy, but they were not destitute either. They were Quakers, a religious group that valued education, and Dalton received his early education from Quaker schools. However, his family's financial situation was not robust enough to support further formal education, and Dalton had to work as a farmhand and later as a teacher to support himself. His family lived in a modest house, indicative of their middle-class status.
sources: "John Dalton - Biography, Facts and Pictures." Famous Scientists. https://www.famousscientists.org/john-dalton/ ; "John Dalton." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Dalton

explanation: John Wallis was born in Ashford, Kent, England in November 1616. His father, Reverend John Wallis, was a minister of the gospel and his mother, Joanna Chapman, was the daughter of a freeman of Canterbury. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were neither nobility nor laborers. The fact that his father was a minister indicates that they had a certain level of education and social standing in their community. Furthermore, Wallis's access to education was likely due to his family background. He attended a grammar school in Ashford and later went on to study at Emmanuel College, Cambridge. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family of the time. There is no evidence to suggest that Wallis inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Wallis (1616–1703)" by Philip Beeley and Christoph J. Scriba, published in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "John Wallis: A Life in Mathematics and Cryptography" by Jacqueline A. Stedall.

explanation: Thomas Allom was born in Lambeth, south London, in 1804. His father was a coachman, which was a skilled occupation during this time period. This suggests that the Allom family belonged to the middle class, as they were not part of the aristocracy, but also not laborers or peasants. The fact that Thomas Allom was able to become an apprentice to architect Francis Goodwin further indicates that his family had enough resources to provide him with this opportunity. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Allom family was particularly wealthy or that Thomas had access to a high level of education due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were adequate but not luxurious.
sources: "Thomas Allom: His Life and Work" by H. M. Alderman, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Leslie Stephen and Sidney Lee.

explanation: Alfred Marshall was born in Bermondsey, a suburb of London, in 1842. His father, William Marshall, was a bank cashier and a devout Evangelical. This suggests that his family was of the middle class, as his father held a skilled job in the financial sector. His mother, Rebecca Oliver, was the daughter of a middle-class merchant. This further supports the classification of Marshall's family as middle class. The family's religious devotion also suggests a level of education and literacy, which was more common among the middle class during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that Marshall's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they lived in typical middle-class conditions for the time.
sources: "Alfred Marshall 1842-1924" by Peter Groenewegen, published in 1995; "Alfred Marshall: Economist 1842-1924" by John K. Whitaker, published in 1990.

explanation: John Lyly was born in Kent, England around 1554. His father, Peter Lyly, was a minor government official, serving as a registrar for the Archbishop of Canterbury. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, but rather of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had a stable income and a respectable position in society. John Lyly's access to education also indicates a middle-class background. He attended Magdalen College, Oxford, where he received both his Bachelor's and Master's degrees. While it's not clear if his family's wealth directly enabled this education, his father's position would have likely provided the necessary connections and social standing. The specifics of Lyly's early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it can be inferred that they were likely comfortable but not extravagant. There is no evidence of any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Lyly" by Ruth Lunney (Manchester University Press, 2016); "John Lyly and Early Modern Authorship" by Andy Kesson (Manchester University Press, 2014).

explanation: Francis Darwin was born into a family of significant social standing and wealth. His father was Charles Darwin, the renowned naturalist and author of "On the Origin of Species," which had already been published and gained recognition by the time of Francis' birth. Charles Darwin was a member of the scientific elite and his family was financially secure due to a combination of inherited wealth and income from his publications. Francis' mother, Emma Darwin, was also from a wealthy background, being the daughter of a successful industrialist. The Darwin family lived in Down House, a large and comfortable country home in Kent. Francis would have had access to a high level of education due to his family's resources and connections.
sources: "Charles Darwin: A Biography" by Janet Browne; "The Darwin Family in Their Own Words" by Frederick Burkhardt and Sydney Smith; "The Correspondence of Charles Darwin" by Frederick Burkhardt and Sydney Smith.

explanation: Samuel Daniel was born in 1562 or 1563 in Taunton, Somerset, England. His father, John Daniel, was a music master, which suggests a middle-class occupation. Music masters were skilled professionals who taught music, often to the children of the wealthy. This would have provided a stable income and a degree of social standing, but not to the level of the elite class. Samuel Daniel was the second of three children, and his family was of Welsh ancestry. His older brother, John Daniel, also became a musician, suggesting that the family had access to education and training in this field. Samuel Daniel himself was educated at Magdalen Hall, Oxford, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a higher education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or that they owned significant property, which would be characteristic of the elite class. Therefore, it is most likely that Samuel Daniel was born into the middle class.
sources: "Samuel Daniel." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Daniel; "Samuel Daniel." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/samuel-daniel; "Samuel Daniel." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.

explanation: Adelina Patti was born into a musical family. Her father, Salvatore Patti, was a tenor, and her mother, Caterina Barilli, was a soprano. Both of her parents were involved in the Italian opera scene, which suggests a middle-class background as they were skilled professionals in their field. The family was not of aristocratic lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. Adelina and her siblings were exposed to music and performance from a young age, indicating a certain level of access to education and cultural resources. However, this was likely due to their parents' professions rather than a result of substantial wealth or high social standing. The family moved to the United States when Adelina was a child, suggesting they had the means for international travel but not necessarily significant wealth.
sources: "Adelina Patti." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Adelina-Patti; Klein, H. W. (1910). "Adelina Patti." The Musical Times, 51(808), 163-165.

explanation: George Grote was born into a middle-class family in Beckenham, Kent, England, in 1794. His father, also named George Grote, was a prosperous banker of German descent. His mother, Selina Mary Peckwell, was the daughter of a minister. The family's wealth and status would have provided Grote with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. His father's occupation as a banker indicates a level of financial stability and social standing that aligns with the middle class of the time. However, there's no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or ruling class. Grote's early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious, typical of the middle class. His family background would have provided him with certain privileges, such as access to education, but he did not inherit a title or significant wealth.
sources: "George Grote: A Biography" by A. Bain (1880); "The History of Greece" by George Grote (1846-1856); "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee (1885-1900).

explanation:
Isaac Barrow was born in London, England, around 1630. His father, Thomas Barrow, was a linen draper by trade, which was a skilled occupation that would likely place the family in the middle class. His mother, Ann, was the daughter of a Suffolk yeoman, which was a social rank in England, typically a free man who owned his own farm. This suggests that the family had some level of wealth and stability, but were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. 

Barrow's access to education also suggests a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at Charterhouse School and at Felsted School, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, it's important to note that his education was not solely due to his family's wealth. His uncle and namesake, Isaac Barrow, was a fellow of Peterhouse, Cambridge, and he used his influence to secure a place for his nephew at Trinity College, Cambridge.

In terms of housing and living conditions, there is little specific information available. However, given his father's occupation and the family's ability to send Barrow to school, it can be inferred that they lived in reasonable comfort for the time.
sources:
- "Isaac Barrow." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Isaac-Barrow
- "Isaac Barrow."

individual_name: Edward Herbert, 1st Baron Herbert of Cherbury
explanation: Edward Herbert, 1st Baron Herbert of Cherbury, was born into a wealthy and noble family. His father, Richard Herbert, was a member of the gentry and a prominent landowner in Montgomeryshire, Wales. His mother, Magdalen Newport, was also from a wealthy family and was a patron of poets. Edward was the eldest of ten children, and his family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable upbringing. His family's wealth and status also allowed him access to education, which was not common for those outside the elite class during this time. He was educated at home by his mother and private tutors before attending University College, Oxford. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, given his family's wealth and status. He would have also inherited the privileges that came with being part of the elite class, such as the potential for political influence and the opportunity to acquire more land and wealth.
sources: "Herbert of Cherbury, Edward Herbert, 1st Baron." Encyclopædia Britannica. "Edward Herbert." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. "Herbert, Edward, first Baron Herbert of Cherbury (1583–1648)." The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1604-1629.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Thomas Tallis are largely unknown. There is no concrete information available about his parents, their occupations, or their social standing. It is also unclear about the family wealth at the time of his birth and childhood, as well as his access to education due to family background. Early life housing and living conditions, along with any inherited privileges or disadvantages, are also not known. While it is known that Tallis was a chorister at the Chapel Royal, it is unclear how he attained this position and whether it was due to his family background or personal merit.
sources: Most information about Tallis comes from secondary sources, such as biographies and music history books. Primary sources, such as birth records, family documents, or contemporary accounts, do not appear to exist or have not been discovered. Further research in archives or historical records may potentially uncover more information about Tallis's early life and family background.

explanation: Richard Wilson was born in 1714 in Penegoes, Wales, to a clergyman father. His father, also named Richard Wilson, was a rector of the parish, which suggests a middle-class status. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The fact that Richard Wilson's father was a clergyman suggests that the family had some level of education and literacy, which was not common among the lower classes at the time. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or had significant landholdings. The family's living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the middle class in the 18th century.
sources: "Richard Wilson and the Transformation of European Landscape Painting" by Robin Simon and Martin Postle; "Richard Wilson (1714–1782) and the British Landscape" by Ann Sumner.

explanation: Horatio Herbert Kitchener was born on June 24, 1850, in Ballylongford, County Kerry, Ireland. His father, Lt. Col. Henry Horatio Kitchener, was a British Army officer and landowner, which would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Frances Anne Chevallier, was the daughter of a priest. The family lived in a comfortable home, and Kitchener and his siblings had access to education. However, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. The family's wealth was significantly reduced when Kitchener's father inherited debts, but they maintained their middle-class status. Kitchener's early life was marked by a comfortable upbringing, but not one of significant privilege or wealth.
sources: "Kitchener: The Road to Omdurman" by John Pollock; "Kitchener: Architect of Victory, Artisan of Peace" by John Pollock; "The National Archives" (UK).

explanation: Abraham Cowley was born in London in 1618 to a family of moderate means. His father, Thomas Cowley, was a stationer, a profession that would place the family in the middle class of the time. Stationers were skilled craftspeople who produced, sold, and traded in books. This profession required a certain level of education and literacy, which suggests that the Cowley family had access to some form of education. Unfortunately, Abraham's father died before he was born, leaving the family in a more precarious financial situation. However, his mother was able to send him to Westminster School, a prestigious institution, due to the help of some generous friends. This suggests that despite their financial difficulties, the Cowley family still had connections and resources that allowed them to provide Abraham with a good education.
sources: "Abraham Cowley." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/abraham-cowley; "Abraham Cowley." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Abraham-Cowley.

explanation: Clarkson Frederick Stanfield was born in Sunderland, England, in 1793. His father, James Field Stanfield, was an Irish-born author, but before that, he was a seaman and later a 'press-ganged' sailor in the Royal Navy. His mother, Mary Hoad, was the daughter of a captain. The family was not wealthy, and Stanfield's father's experiences at sea, including being press-ganged, suggest that they were of a lower social class. There's no evidence to suggest that Stanfield had access to education due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his family's lack of wealth, it's likely they were modest at best. Stanfield himself went to sea at a young age, suggesting a lack of other opportunities.
sources:
- "James Field Stanfield", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.
- "Clarkson Stanfield", Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2021.

explanation: Robert Brown was born in Montrose, Scotland in 1773. His father, James Brown, was an Episcopalian clergyman, which would have placed the family within the middle class of the social structure of the time. The family would have had a moderate level of wealth, enough to provide for their needs and some comforts, but not to the extent of the elite class. Brown's father's occupation as a clergyman would have also provided the family with a certain level of social standing within their community. Furthermore, Brown's access to education was likely due to his family background. He attended the local Grammar School and Marischal College, Aberdeen, which suggests that his family had the means to afford his education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Robert Brown (1773-1858): A Brief Biography" by J. M. Lynch; "Robert Brown and the Discovery of the Nucleus" by P. F. Cannon.

explanation: Benjamin Robert Haydon was born in Plymouth, England, in 1786. His father, Benjamin Robert Haydon, was a prosperous printer, publisher, and stationer, and his mother, Mary Cobley Haydon, was the daughter of a prosperous farmer. This suggests that Haydon was born into a family of some means, but not of the elite class. His father's profession as a printer and publisher would have placed the family in the middle class, as this was a skilled trade. The family's prosperity is further evidenced by the fact that Haydon was able to attend the Plymouth Grammar School, indicating that his family had the means to afford his education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious, consistent with a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Life of Benjamin Robert Haydon, Historical Painter, from His Autobiography and Journals" by Tom Taylor, "Benjamin Robert Haydon: Correspondence and Table-Talk" by Benjamin Robert Haydon, Frederic Wordsworth Haydon.

explanation: Izaak Walton was born in Stafford, England, around 1593. His father, Jervis Walton, was an innkeeper, a profession that would likely place the family in the middle class during this period. The innkeeping business would have provided a stable income, but it was not a profession associated with the elite or nobility. There is no evidence to suggest that the Walton family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their time and place. Izaak Walton was educated at the Free Grammar School in Stafford, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with an education, a privilege not available to all children during this period. However, the fact that he attended a free school rather than a private institution suggests that his family was not among the elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical for a middle-class family of the time, likely comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence to suggest that Walton inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Izaak Walton: A New Life" by Michael Pritchard, "The Compleat Angler" by Izaak Walton (biographical introduction), Staffordshire Record Office (parish records)

explanation: John Aubrey was born into a wealthy gentry family in the county of Wiltshire, England. His father, Richard Aubrey, was a gentleman and landowner, which placed the family in the upper echelons of society. The Aubrey family had a long history of land ownership, and John Aubrey himself was born at the family estate, Easton Piers. This indicates that the family had considerable wealth at the time of his birth and throughout his childhood. Moreover, Aubrey's access to education was a direct result of his family's status. He was educated at home by private tutors before attending the prestigious Trinity College, Oxford. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable and privileged, given the family's wealth and status.
sources: "Brief Lives: John Aubrey" by Ruth Scurr; "John Aubrey: My Own Life" by Ruth Scurr; "John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning" by William Poole.

explanation:
Isambard Kingdom Brunel was born on 9 April 1806 in Portsmouth, England. His father, Sir Marc Isambard Brunel, was a prominent engineer of French origin. Despite being born in France, Marc Brunel moved to the United States and then to England, where he established himself as a respected engineer. His mother, Sophia Kingdom, was the daughter of a contractor. 

The Brunel family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were not subsistence level either. Marc Brunel's profession as an engineer would have placed the family in the middle class. The family had enough wealth to provide Isambard with a good education. He was initially educated at home by his father, and then sent to France to study at the University of Caen and the Lycée Henri-IV in Paris.

The family lived in decent conditions in Portsmouth, and later in London, which suggests a level of financial stability. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Isambard Brunel inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources:
- "The Life of Isambard Kingdom Brunel, Civil Engineer" by Isambard Brunel (1870)
- "Marc Isambard Brunel" by Paul Clements (2006)
- "Isambard Kingdom Brunel: Engineering Knight-Errant" by Adrian Vaughan (1991)

explanation: Charlotte Mary Yonge was born into a middle-class family. Her father, William Crawley Yonge, was a British Army officer and a landowner, which indicates a level of wealth and social standing typical of the middle class. Her mother, Frances Mary Bargus, was also from a middle-class background. The family lived in a comfortable home in Otterbourne, Hampshire, which was owned by her father. This suggests that they had a stable income and were not living in poverty. Charlotte had access to education due to her family background. Her father, who had received a classical education, was her primary educator. This level of education was not common among lower classes, further suggesting a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Charlotte Mary Yonge: Religion, Feminism and Realism in the Victorian Novel" by June Sturrock; "The Life of Charlotte Mary Yonge" by Christabel Coleridge.

explanation: Thomas Stothard was born in London in 1755. His father, Thomas Stothard Senior, was an innkeeper in Long Acre, a street in the city known for its coach-makers, and later became a silk-dyer. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, but rather part of the middle class, as they were involved in skilled trades and small business ownership. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but they were likely comfortable enough to provide for their children. Stothard's early access to education seems to have been limited, as he was largely self-taught in his artistic pursuits. However, he did attend a school in Aigburth, Liverpool for a time, indicating that his family had the means to send him to school, a privilege not afforded to many in the subsistence class. His early life housing and living conditions would likely have been modest but adequate, typical of a middle-class family in London at the time.
sources: "Thomas Stothard: The Mechanisms of Art Patronage in England Circa 1800" by David Bindman, "The Life of Thomas Stothard, R.A." by Mrs. Bray.

explanation: Hugh Blair was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1718. His father, John Blair, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. Blair's family had enough wealth to provide him with a good education. He attended the Royal High School and the University of Edinburgh, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Blair was born into the elite class or that he lived in subsistence. His family's occupation, wealth, and ability to provide him with an education all point to a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Hugh Blair." Encyclopedia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Hugh-Blair. "Hugh Blair." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-2600.

explanation: Nicola Francesco Haym was an Italian-born British librettist, cellist, and composer. However, there is limited information available about his early life and family background. His date of birth is estimated to be around 1678, but the specifics of his family's social standing, wealth, and occupation during his childhood are not well-documented. Therefore, it is not possible to definitively classify his social class at birth and during his childhood.
sources: Most of the available information about Haym comes from secondary sources such as "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" and "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography". These sources focus primarily on his career in England and do not provide detailed information about his early life in Italy. Primary sources that could potentially provide more information about his family background are not readily accessible or may not exist.

explanation: James Thornhill was born in Melcombe Regis, Weymouth, Dorset, England, in 1675 or 1676. His father, Walter Thornhill, was a local magistrate and a member of the landed gentry, which suggests a middle-class status. The Thornhill family owned a considerable amount of land in Dorset, which further supports their middle-class standing. James Thornhill's early access to education, which included studying at a grammar school in Weymouth, was likely due to his family's resources and status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Thornhills were part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "James Thornhill: His Life and Works" by E. K. Waterhouse, The Journal of the Royal Society of Arts, Vol. 104, No. 4990 (May 1956), pp. 485-499; "James Thornhill 1675-1734" by Arline Meyer, The Burlington Magazine, Vol. 126, No. 975 (Jun., 1984), pp. 356+358-366.

explanation: John William Waterhouse was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Waterhouse, was a painter and his mother, Mary (née Robinson), was a descendant of a London merchant. The Waterhouse family lived in Rome during John's early years, where his father pursued his art. This suggests that the family had enough means to live abroad and support William's artistic career. John's early exposure to art and his later education at the Royal Academy schools, where his father had also studied, indicate that the family had access to educational resources. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Waterhouse family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they struggling for subsistence.
sources: "John William Waterhouse (1849–1917): A Life Study" by Peter Trippi, "John William Waterhouse: The Modern Pre-Raphaelite" by Elizabeth Prettejohn, and "John William Waterhouse" by Anthony Hobson.

explanation: James Hogg was born in 1770 in Ettrick, Scotland, into a family of subsistence farmers. His father, Robert Hogg, was a shepherd, a profession that James himself would later take up. The family lived in a small, humble cottage, indicating a lack of significant wealth. They were poor and lived a hand-to-mouth existence. James Hogg had little formal education, as his family's economic situation required him to work from a young age. He learned to read under the tutelage of his mother, Margaret Laidlaw Hogg, who was known for her storytelling and knowledge of local folklore. The family's circumstances and Hogg's early life experiences suggest that they were part of the subsistence class, living with minimal resources.
sources:
- "The Life of James Hogg: The Ettrick Shepherd" by Karl Miller
- "James Hogg: A Life" by Gillian Hughes
- "James Hogg and the Literary Marketplace: Scottish Romanticism and the Working-Class Author" by Sharon Alker and Holly Faith Nelson.

explanation: William Laud was born in 1573 in Reading, Berkshire, England. His father, also named William Laud, was a cloth merchant, which was a skilled and profitable trade during this period. This would place the Laud family within the middle class according to the specified typology. The family's wealth from the cloth trade would have provided a comfortable living, but they were not part of the ruling elite or nobility. Laud's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. He attended Reading School, a free grammar school in his hometown, and later went on to study at St. John's College, Oxford. His family's wealth and social standing would have played a significant role in his ability to pursue these educational opportunities.
sources:
- "William Laud", Encyclopædia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Laud
- "Archbishop Laud, 1573-1645", Hugh Trevor-Roper, 2000.

explanation: Owen Jones was born in 1809 in London, England. His father, also named Owen Jones, was a successful furrier, a trade that would place the family firmly in the middle class. Furriers were skilled craftspeople who made, repaired, and sold furs, a trade that required a significant level of skill and knowledge. The elder Jones was successful enough in his trade to provide his son with a good education. Young Owen was able to attend the Royal Academy Schools, a prestigious institution that would have been beyond the reach of a subsistence class family. The family's ability to afford such an education suggests a level of wealth and stability consistent with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Jones family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor that they were subsistence class laborers or peasants.
sources: "Owen Jones: Design, Ornament, Architecture, and Theory in an Age in Transition" by Carol A. Hrvol Flores; "The Grammar of Ornament" by Owen Jones; "Owen Jones: Architect, Aesthete, and Orientalist" by Robert Chapman.

explanation:
Joseph Hall was born in 1574 in Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire, England.
