His father, John Hall, was a successful and well-respected agent to George, Earl of Huntingdon, a role that would have placed him in the middle class of the time. This position would have provided a comfortable living for the family, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Joseph's mother, Winifred Bambridge, was a woman of good character and piety, but there is no record of her family's social standing. 

Joseph Hall's family background would have provided him with access to education. He was educated at the local grammar school in Ashby-de-la-Zouch, a privilege not available to those in the subsistence class. His family's middle-class status would have also provided a comfortable early life housing and living conditions. 

There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages, but his father's position would have likely provided some advantages in terms of social connections and opportunities.
sources:
- "Joseph Hall, Bishop of Norwich." The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
- "Joseph Hall." The Cambridge History of English and American Literature, Volume VII. Cambridge University Press, 1907–21.

explanation: William Edward Hartpole Lecky was born on 26 March 1838 in Newtown Park, near Dublin, Ireland. His parents were John Hartpole Lecky and Elizabeth Van Tromp. His father, John Hartpole Lecky, was a landowner, which was a typical occupation for the middle class during the 19th century in the United Kingdom. The family's wealth was moderate, and they were able to provide a comfortable living environment for Lecky during his early life. Lecky's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. He was educated at home until the age of twelve, then attended St. Columba's College, and later entered Trinity College, Dublin. The ability to afford private education and home tutoring indicates a certain level of financial stability and social standing, characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Lecky family were part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they struggling for subsistence.
sources:
1. "William Edward Hartpole Lecky." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Edward-Hartpole-Lecky
2. "William Edward Hartpole Lecky." Dictionary of Irish Biography. https://dib.cambridge.org/viewReadPage.do?articleId=a4746&searchClicked=clicked&quickadvsearch=yes

explanation: William Roscoe was born in Liverpool, England in 1753. His father was a market gardener, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. Market gardening was a skilled occupation, and while it did not bring the wealth of the elite, it would have provided a comfortable living. Roscoe's mother was the daughter of a publican, which also suggests a middle-class background. As for education, Roscoe was educated at a private school in Liverpool, which indicates that his family had the means to afford such an education. There is no evidence to suggest that Roscoe was born into either the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "William Roscoe of Liverpool" by David Watkin, "The Life and Works of William Roscoe, 1753-1831" by Stella Butler.

explanation: Arthur Cayley was born in Richmond, London, England, on August 16, 1821. His father, Henry Cayley, was a businessman, and his mother, Maria Antonia Doughty, was the daughter of William Doughty. The Cayley family was of good standing, but not of the aristocratic or ruling class. Henry Cayley's business ventures provided a comfortable living for the family, placing them firmly in the middle class. Arthur Cayley had access to education due to his family background. He was first educated at a private school in Blackheath, London, before moving on to King's College School, and later, Trinity College, Cambridge. This level of education was not typically accessible to those of lower social classes in the 19th century. The family's living conditions were also indicative of their middle-class status, as they resided in a comfortable home in Richmond.
sources: "Arthur Cayley." MacTutor History of Mathematics archive. University of St Andrews, Scotland.

explanation: Edmund Waller was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Robert Waller, was a successful lawyer and held the position of a Member of Parliament. His mother, Mary Banks, was the daughter of a wealthy London merchant. Upon his father's death in 1616, Waller inherited estates in Buckinghamshire and Middlesex, making him one of the wealthiest commoners in England. This wealth and social standing would have afforded him a high level of education from an early age. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, typical of the elite class of the time.
sources:
1. "Waller, Edmund (1606-87), of Hall Barn, Beaconsfield, Bucks. and St. James's, Westminster, Mdx." in The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1604-1629, ed. Andrew Thrush and John P. Ferris, 2010.
2. "Edmund Waller" in The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: Paul Sandby was born in Nottingham, England, around 1725. His father, Thomas Sandby, was a framework knitter, a skilled occupation that would place the family in the middle class. Framework knitting was a common occupation in Nottingham during the 18th century, and it required a level of skill and training, suggesting that the Sandby family had a stable income and were not living in poverty. Paul Sandby and his brother Thomas Sandby received some form of education, as they both were able to write, which was not common among the lower classes at the time. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Sandby family was particularly wealthy or had any inherited privileges. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Paul Sandby's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Paul Sandby: Picturing Britain" by John Bonehill and Stephen Daniels; "The Framework-Knitters of the 18th Century" by R.L. Hills.

explanation: Samuel Rawson Gardiner was born on March 4, 1829, in Ropley, Hampshire, England. His father, Rawson Boddam Gardiner, was a lieutenant-colonel in the British Army, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. His mother, Maria Gardiner, was the daughter of Samuel Reynolds, a master at Winchester College, which suggests a level of education and social standing also consistent with the middle class. The Gardiner family had a comfortable upbringing, with access to education and a stable living condition. However, there is no evidence to suggest they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor were they struggling for subsistence.
sources: "Samuel Rawson Gardiner" by John William Burgon, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, The English Historical Review, Vol. 19, No. 74 (Apr., 1904), pp. 334-336.

explanation:
James Prescott Joule was born in Salford, Lancashire, England, on December 24, 1818. His father, Benjamin Joule, was a wealthy brewer, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The brewing business was a successful one, providing the family with a comfortable living. Joule's mother, Alice Prescott Joule, came from a family that was involved in the brewing and malting business as well. This indicates that the family had a stable income and were part of the merchant class. 

In terms of education, Joule was initially educated at home. Later, he was sent to the University of Manchester, which was a privilege afforded to him due to his family's wealth. This access to education further supports the classification of Joule's family as middle class.

The family lived in a comfortable home in Salford, reflecting their middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that Joule inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources:
- Cardwell, D. S. L. (1991). James Joule: A Biography. Manchester University Press.
- Forrester, J. (1975). Chemistry and the Conservation of Energy: The Work of James Prescott Joule. Studies in History and Philosophy of Science Part A, 6(4), 273-313.
- Smith, C. (1998). The Science

explanation: John Stafford Smith was born in March 1750 in Gloucester, England. His father, Martin Smith, was an organist at Gloucester Cathedral, a position that would have required a certain level of education and skill, suggesting a middle-class standing. Martin Smith was also a lay clerk, or a non-ordained member of the clergy, which further supports the middle-class classification. The family's wealth at the time of John's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but the professional status of his father suggests they were not impoverished. John Stafford Smith received a good education, becoming a choirboy at the Chapel Royal, which suggests his family had the means to provide him with such opportunities. However, there is no evidence of inherited privileges or significant wealth that would suggest an elite status.
sources: "John Stafford Smith." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "John Stafford Smith." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2021.

explanation: William Boyce was born in London around 1711. His father was a joiner, a skilled craftsman who constructs the wooden components of a building, such as stairs, doors, and window frames. This occupation places the Boyce family in the middle class according to the provided typology. Boyce's access to education also suggests a middle-class background. He was accepted into the choir of St. Paul's Cathedral, where he received a musical education. This opportunity was likely due to his family's connections and standing, rather than his individual merit, as he would have been too young to have established a reputation. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Boyce's family was particularly wealthy or that they lived in luxurious conditions. The family's social standing and wealth would have been typical of skilled craftspeople of the time.
sources: Grove Music Online, Oxford University Press, "Boyce, William," by Peter Holman and Robert Thompson.

explanation: William Kent was born in Bridlington, Yorkshire, England, in 1684. His father was a joiner, a skilled craftsman who constructs the wooden components of a building, such as stairs, doors, and window frames. This profession places the family in the middle class, as it requires a specialized skill set and was a respected trade during the late 17th century. There is no record of the family owning significant property or having any noble or aristocratic connections, which further supports this classification. As for education, Kent was apprenticed to a local joiner, a common practice for middle-class families at the time. This would have provided him with a practical education in a trade, rather than the classical education typically afforded to the elite. The specific details of his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as the son of a skilled craftsman, it is likely that they were comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "William Kent: Designing Georgian Britain" by Susan Weber, Bard Graduate Center, Yale University Press, 2013.

explanation: William Jackson Hooker was born in Norwich, England in 1785 to Joseph Hooker, a merchant and amateur botanist. The Hooker family was well-established and respected in Norwich, with a history of involvement in the city's commerce. Joseph Hooker's occupation as a merchant suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in trade but not part of the landed gentry or nobility. William Jackson Hooker's early access to education, including botany lessons from his father and formal education at Norwich Grammar School, further indicates a middle-class background, as such opportunities were typically not available to the lower classes during this period. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but their status as a merchant family suggests they would have lived in comfortable, urban accommodations.
sources: "Sir William Jackson Hooker (1785–1865)" by Ray Desmond, published in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Correspondence of William Jackson Hooker: Volume 1, 1815–1820" edited by James R. Ainsworth.

explanation: Charles Keene was born in Hornsey, North London, in 1823. His father, Samuel Browne Keene, was a solicitor, a profession that typically belonged to the middle class during the 19th century in the United Kingdom. His mother, Sarah, was a homemaker. The family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Charles Keene's early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class of the time, with access to basic amenities. His father's profession as a solicitor would have provided the family with a steady income, and it is likely that Charles had access to education due to his family's middle-class status. However, there is no evidence of any inherited privileges or significant family wealth.
sources: "Charles Keene" by Simon Houfe (The Dictionary of British Book Illustrators and Caricaturists, 1800-1914); "Charles Samuel Keene" by Joseph Pennell (The Studio: An Illustrated Magazine of Fine and Applied Art, 1897).

explanation: Richard Baxter was born in 1615 in Rowton, Shropshire, England. His father, also named Richard Baxter, was a freeholder of a farm, a status that placed him in the middle class of the time. His mother, Beatrice Adeney, came from a family of substantial means, but her father's death and subsequent mismanagement of his estate by her brother left her family in a less secure financial position. Despite these financial difficulties, Baxter's parents were able to provide him with a basic education. He was tutored at home by the local clergyman and later attended the free grammar school in Wroxeter. His family's ability to provide him with an education, even in the face of financial hardship, suggests a middle-class background.
sources: "The Autobiography of Richard Baxter" (1696), "Richard Baxter and Puritan Politics" by Tim Cooper (2020), "Richard Baxter: A Reluctant Puritan?" by J. William Black (1981).

explanation: Samuel Butler was born in Strensham, Worcestershire, England, in 1612. His father, also named Samuel Butler, was a farmer and churchwarden, which indicates a middle-class status. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They had enough resources to provide Butler with a basic education. He attended the King's School, Worcester, which was a grammar school, indicating that his family had the means to afford some level of education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Butler's family was part of the elite or aristocracy, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Butler's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Samuel Butler." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., 20 Dec. 2019, www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Butler-British-author.

explanation: William Mulready was born in Ennis, County Clare, Ireland, in 1786. His father was a leather-glover, which was a skilled trade, suggesting that the family belonged to the middle class. However, it is also known that the family moved to London when Mulready was very young, which may suggest some level of economic instability or ambition for better opportunities. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that Mulready had access to education due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were modest but not impoverished. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "William Mulready: The Pre-Raphaelite Pioneer" by Paul Goldman, "The Dictionary of Irish Biography" by James McGuire and James Quinn.

explanation: John Hanning Speke was born into a family of the British gentry, a social class typically associated with landownership and a certain level of wealth. His father, William Speke, was a landed gentleman, and his mother, Harriet Speke, came from a similar background. The Speke family owned Jordans, a large estate in Somerset, England, which indicates a significant level of wealth. This wealth would have provided Speke with a comfortable early life and access to education, which was typically reserved for the upper classes in the 19th century. Speke attended the Royal Military College, further indicating his family's elite status, as such institutions were often attended by children of the aristocracy or gentry.
sources: "John Hanning Speke and the Nile." The Geographical Journal, Vol. 143, No. 2 (Jul., 1977), pp. 200-210; "John Hanning Speke's Discovery of Lake Victoria." The Geographical Journal, Vol. 132, No. 2 (Jun., 1966), pp. 169-183.

explanation: Dinah Craik, born Dinah Maria Mulock, was the daughter of Thomas Mulock, a nonconformist minister, and his wife, Dinah. Her father's occupation as a minister suggests a middle-class background, as clergy were typically considered part of the middle class in the 19th century United Kingdom. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. After her mother's death and her father's subsequent mental illness, Dinah and her younger brother were raised by a maternal aunt, suggesting a supportive extended family network. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or significant disadvantages, beyond the early loss of her mother and her father's mental illness. Dinah received a good education, which was more accessible to middle-class girls in the 19th century than to those from lower social classes.
sources: "Dinah Mulock Craik." Nineteenth-Century Literature Criticism, edited by Jessica Bomarito and Russel Whitaker, vol. 170, Gale, 2006. Literature Resource Center; "Craik, Dinah Maria (Mulock) (1826–1887), novelist and writer for children." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: John Hunter was born in 1728 in Long Calderwood, East Kilbride, Scotland. His father, John Hunter Sr., was a landowner and farmer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, nor were they laborers or peasants. They had enough resources to maintain a farm and provide a comfortable life for their children. John Hunter's mother, Agnes Paul, was the daughter of a merchant, further supporting the middle-class classification. John Hunter had nine siblings, and after his father's death in 1741, the family's financial situation became more difficult. However, they were still able to provide education for their children, with John's older brother William becoming a successful surgeon. John himself did not receive a formal education until he moved to London to live with his brother William in 1748, but this was more due to his own disinterest in formal education than a lack of resources.
sources: "John Hunter (1728–1793)" by Wendy Moore, published in The Lancet, Volume 369, Issue 9579, 2007; "John Hunter, Man of Science and Surgeon (1728-1793)" by Stephen Paget, published by T. Fisher Unwin, 1897.

explanation: Colley Cibber was born in London, England, in 1671 to Caius Gabriel Cibber, a Danish sculptor, and his wife Jane Colley. Caius Gabriel Cibber was a member of the middle class, as he was a skilled artisan. He was known for his work on public monuments, which suggests that the family had a stable income and were not living in poverty. However, they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Colley Cibber's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended the King's College School in Wimbledon. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in late 17th century England, with the family likely living in a comfortable, but not luxurious, home. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Colley Cibber: A Biography" by Helene Koon, "The Lives of the Poets of Great Britain and Ireland" by Theophilus Cibber, "The Cibbers" by Leonard R. N. Ashley.

explanation: Sir William Hamilton, 9th Baronet, was born into the Scottish nobility, which places him in the elite class of the late 18th-century United Kingdom. His father, Sir John Hamilton, 8th Baronet, was a member of the aristocracy, and his mother, Lady Harriet Hamilton, was the daughter of the 2nd Earl of Haddington. This lineage indicates a high social standing and wealth at the time of his birth and childhood. The title of Baronet, inherited by Sir William, was a hereditary title awarded by the British Crown, which further signifies his elite status. As a member of the nobility, he would have had access to education and comfortable living conditions due to his family background.
sources: "The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe" by Darryl Lundy; "The Baronetage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the English Baronets" by William Betham.

explanation: Thomas Chatterton was born in Bristol, England, in 1752. His father, also named Thomas Chatterton, was a schoolmaster at Bristol's Pyle Street School, but he died before young Thomas was born. His mother, Sarah Chatterton, was left to raise him and his older sister alone, and she supported the family by sewing and teaching young girls to read. The family lived in a small apartment above the schoolhouse where his father had taught. Chatterton's education was largely self-taught, as his family's circumstances did not afford him the opportunity for formal education. He was, however, able to access the books in the schoolhouse library, which sparked his interest in literature and history. Despite these hardships, Chatterton showed early signs of genius, but his family's poverty and social standing did not change during his childhood.
sources: "Thomas Chatterton, the Marvelous Boy: The Story of a Strange Life 1752-1770" by E.H.W. Meyerstein, "The Rowley Poems" by Thomas Chatterton, "Thomas Chatterton and Neglected Genius, 1760–1830" by Nick Groom.

explanation: Thomas Girtin was born in Southwark, London, in 1775. His father, Thomas Girtin, was a well-off brushmaker and a member of the Worshipful Company of Brushmakers, a London trade guild. This indicates that the family was of the middle class, as they were involved in a skilled trade and had a degree of economic stability. However, Girtin's father died while he was still young, and his mother, Elizabeth, was left to raise him and his brother alone. Despite this, she was able to provide for her sons' education, suggesting that the family retained some level of financial security. Girtin was apprenticed to the watercolourist Edward Dayes at the age of 14, indicating that his family had the means to secure such an apprenticeship, a common practice among the middle class of the time.
sources:
- "Thomas Girtin, 1775–1802, British, active in America (1794–95), The White House at Chelsea", Yale Center for British Art, Paul Mellon Collection.
- "Girtin, Thomas (1775–1802), landscape painter", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
- "The Worshipful Company of Brushmakers", The Worshipful Company of Brushmakers website.

explanation: Jeremy Taylor was born in Cambridge, England, around 1613. His father was a barber, which was a skilled trade during this period, suggesting a middle-class background. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished. His access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended the Perse School in Cambridge and later Gonville and Caius College, University of Cambridge. However, it should be noted that his education was also funded by a local benefactor, which suggests that while his family was not poor, they may not have had the means to fully fund his education themselves. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were adequate for the period. There is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.

explanation: Norman Lockyer was born in Rugby, Warwickshire, England in 1836. His father, Joseph Hooley Lockyer, was a draper by trade, which was a skilled occupation involving the selling of cloth and dry goods. This would place the family within the middle class according to the typology provided. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Lockyer's access to education would have been typical for a middle-class child of the time. He attended the local grammar school in Rugby, which was likely made possible by his family's middle-class status. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence to suggest that Lockyer inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Norman Lockyer." Encyclopedia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Norman-Lockyer. "Joseph Norman Lockyer." The Royal Society. https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rsbm.1927.0006.

explanation: William Gilbert was born in Colchester, England, around 1544. His father, Jerome Gilbert, was a borough recorder, a position of some importance in the local government, which suggests a middle-class status. The family was likely well-off, but not part of the nobility or ruling class. This is further supported by the fact that William Gilbert was able to attend Cambridge University, which would have required some level of financial means, but does not necessarily indicate an elite status.
sources:
- "The Life of William Gilbert of Colchester." Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, Vol. 165, 1875.
- "William Gilbert." Encyclopædia Britannica, 2021.

explanation: Maria Malibran was born as Maria Felicia Garcia in Paris, France, on March 24, 1808. Her father, Manuel Garcia, was a celebrated tenor and composer, and her mother, Joaquina Sitchez, was a soprano. The Garcia family was not of aristocratic or noble birth, but they were not subsistence level either. They belonged to the middle class, as Manuel Garcia was a professional musician, a career that required a certain level of skill and education. Maria's early life was spent in an environment filled with music and performance, indicating a level of comfort and access to cultural resources typical of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy at the time of Maria's birth. The family lived in various European cities due to Manuel's career, suggesting a level of mobility but not necessarily high wealth. Maria and her siblings received music education from their father, indicating access to education due to family background.
sources: "Maria Malibran: A Biography of a Singer" by Arthur Pougin, "The Garcia Family: A Life in Music" by James Radomski.

explanation: Thomas Nashe was born in Lowestoft, Suffolk, England around 1567. His father, William Nashe, was a minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family was not of noble birth, nor were they laborers or peasants, which rules out the elite and subsistence classes. Nashe's father's occupation as a minister would have provided the family with a stable, though not extravagant, income. Furthermore, Nashe's access to education at a young age, including his attendance at St John's College, Cambridge, was likely due to his family's middle-class status and not because of any inherited wealth or privilege. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in the late 1500s.
sources: "Thomas Nashe." The Cambridge Guide to Literature in English, edited by Dominic Head, Cambridge University Press, 2006. "Nashe, Thomas." The Oxford Companion to English Literature, edited by Dinah Birch, Oxford University Press, 2009.

explanation: John Flamsteed was born in Denby, Derbyshire, England in 1646. His father, Stephen Flamsteed, was a maltster, a profession that involves the production of malt from barley, a key ingredient in the production of beer. This occupation would have placed the Flamsteed family in the middle class, as maltsters were skilled craftspeople. His mother, Mary Spateman, was the daughter of a wealthy farmer, which further supports the classification of Flamsteed's family as middle class. Flamsteed's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He was educated at the free school of Derby, and later at the University of Cambridge, suggesting that his family had the means to support his education. However, it's important to note that his attendance at Cambridge was delayed due to his ill health and the financial difficulties of his family, indicating that while they were not poor, they were not exceptionally wealthy either.
sources: "John Flamsteed: England's Pioneer Astronomer" by Allan Chapman, "The Correspondence of John Flamsteed, The First Astronomer Royal" compiled and edited by Eric G. Forbes, Lesley Murdin, Frances Willmoth.

explanation: Francis Beaufort was born in Navan, County Meath, Ireland, in 1774. His father, Daniel Augustus Beaufort, was a Protestant clergyman and a member of the learned and professional class of the time. Daniel was also a skilled cartographer, indicating a level of education and skill typically associated with the middle class. The Beaufort family was not of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence laborers or peasants. They were part of the educated, professional class, which would place them in the middle class according to the typology provided. Francis Beaufort's access to education would have been due to his family's status and resources. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, consistent with a middle-class upbringing. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Life of Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort" by John Knox Laughton; "The Beaufort Family and the Family Seat" by Patrick Guinness.

explanation: Joanna Baillie was born in Bothwell, Lanarkshire, Scotland in 1762. Her father, Rev. James Baillie, was a Presbyterian minister and professor of divinity at the University of Glasgow. Her mother, Dorothea Hunter, was the sister of the anatomist, John Hunter. The Baillie family was well-respected and had a comfortable living, but they were not part of the nobility or ruling class. Joanna and her siblings had access to education, which was not common for all children at that time, indicating a middle-class background. The family lived in a manse, a house provided for the minister of a Presbyterian church, which suggests decent living conditions. However, there is no evidence of significant wealth or inherited privileges.
sources: "Joanna Baillie, 1762–1851." The Poetry Foundation. "Joanna Baillie." Encyclopædia Britannica. "Joanna Baillie." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: John Raphael Smith was born in Derby, England, in 1752. His father, Thomas Smith, was a notable landscape painter and engraver, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class. This is because, during the 18th century, artists and craftsmen were typically considered part of the middle class in England. They were not aristocrats, but they were also not laborers or peasants. They had a certain level of education and skill, which allowed them to earn a living through their craft. There is no evidence to suggest that Smith's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Smith's access to education would have been typical for a middle-class child of his time, likely including basic literacy and numeracy, as well as training in his father's craft.
sources: "John Raphael Smith, 1752–1812, British, active in America", Yale Center for British Art, Paul Mellon Collection. "Thomas Smith of Derby", The Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art.

explanation: Thomas Hill Green was born on April 7, 1836, in Birkin, a village in the West Riding of Yorkshire, England. His father, the Reverend Valentine Green, was a clergyman of the Church of England and served as the Rector of Birkin. His mother, Henrietta, was the daughter of a solicitor. The family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence level, placing them in the middle class. As the son of a clergyman, Green would have had access to education and a relatively comfortable upbringing. His father's position as a clergyman would have afforded the family a certain level of respect and standing within their community. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or that Green inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Thomas Hill Green", Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; "Thomas Hill Green", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: John Blow was born in the village of Collingham in Nottinghamshire. The details of his parents' occupations are not well-documented, but it is known that he became a choirboy of the Chapel Royal by the age of 15, suggesting that his family had enough resources to provide him with some musical education and connections to secure such a position. This indicates that his family was likely not of the subsistence class, but rather of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his access to education and position as a choirboy suggest a level of family wealth and social standing consistent with the middle class of the time.
sources: Grove Music Online, "Blow, John." Oxford University Press, 2001.

explanation: George Dance the Younger was born into a family with a strong architectural background. His father, George Dance the Elder, was a well-known architect and city surveyor. This suggests that the family was of a professional, middle-class status. The Dance family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that George Dance the Younger and his brothers followed in their father's footsteps and became architects suggests that they had access to some level of education and training, which would have been more typical of a middle-class family during this period. However, specific details about their early life housing and living conditions or inherited privileges or disadvantages are not readily available.
sources: "George Dance, the Younger | British architect" by The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica, "George Dance the Younger" by John Summerson in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: James Planché was born in London in 1796 to a French father and an English mother. His father, Jacques Planché, was a costume designer and his mother, Elizabeth Planché, was a stage actress. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in skilled professions but were not part of the aristocracy. The family's wealth at the time of James' birth and childhood is not well-documented, but given their professions, it is likely that they were not impoverished. James had access to education, as he was educated at home by his mother and later attended a private school in Chelsea. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but given his parents' professions, it is likely that they were comfortable. James did not have any inherited privileges or disadvantages, as his parents were not part of the aristocracy or the lower classes.
sources: "James Planché, 1796–1880: A Life in the Theatre" by Richard Foulkes; "The Life and Reminiscences of E. L. Blanchard" by Clement Scott.

explanation: Henry Irving, born as John Henry Brodribb, was born into a middle-class family. His father, Samuel Brodribb, was a tailor, which was a skilled trade and typically associated with the middle class during the 19th century in the United Kingdom. His mother, Mary Behenna, came from a family of merchants, also a middle-class profession. The family lived in a modest home in Keinton Mandeville, Somerset, England, suggesting a comfortable but not wealthy lifestyle. Irving's parents were able to provide him with an education, as he attended the City Commercial School in London, which was a school for middle-class boys. However, his father's business failed when Irving was still a child, causing the family to fall into financial hardship. Despite this, Irving's early life was marked by the characteristics of a middle-class upbringing: skilled labor, access to education, and a comfortable home.
sources: "Henry Irving: A Re-Evaluation of the Pre-Eminent Victorian Actor-Manager" by Richard Foulkes; "Henry Irving: Actor and Manager: A Critical Study of the Pre-Eminent Victorian" by Madeleine Bingham.

explanation: Henry Sidgwick was born on May 31, 1838, in Skipton, Yorkshire, England. His father, Reverend William Sidgwick, was a schoolmaster at Skipton Grammar School, a position that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. His mother, Mary Sidgwick, was a daughter of a cotton manufacturer, a profession also associated with the middle class. The family was not of aristocratic origin or extreme poverty, suggesting a middle-class upbringing. The family's status would have provided Henry with access to education, as evidenced by his attendance at Rugby School and later Trinity College, Cambridge. However, this access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status and not necessarily individual merit. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family of the time.
sources:
1. Schultz, Bart. "Henry Sidgwick", The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2019 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.), URL = <https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2019/entries/sidgwick/>.
2. Sidgwick, Arthur. Henry Sidgwick: A Memoir. Macmillan and Co., 1906.

explanation: Henry Cavendish was born into the British nobility, a part of the elite social class. His father, Lord Charles Cavendish, was a nobleman and a Member of Parliament. His mother, Lady Anne Grey, was the daughter of the Duke of Kent. The Cavendish family was one of the wealthiest and most influential in England, with significant landholdings. Henry Cavendish was born into considerable wealth and privilege. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to the best education available at the time. He was educated at home by private tutors before attending the prestigious Newcome's School in Hackney and later, Cambridge University. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status.
sources: "Henry Cavendish: A Brief Account of His Life and Work" by George Wilson (1851), "The Life of the Honourable Henry Cavendish" by George Wilson (1851), "The Cavendish Family" by Francis Bickley (1911).

explanation: William Hodges was born in London, England around 1744. His father was a blacksmith, a skilled trade that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family likely had a modest income, but enough to provide for basic needs and some level of comfort. There is no evidence to suggest that Hodges was born into wealth or nobility, nor that he was born into poverty or subsistence living. His father's occupation as a blacksmith would have provided a stable income and a respectable social standing within their community. Furthermore, Hodges was able to attend an art school in London, indicating that his family had the means to afford some level of education. This was not a privilege available to all, and suggests a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "William Hodges 1744–1797". Tate. Retrieved 18 March 2015. ; Quilley, Geoff (2004). "Hodges, William (1744–1797)". Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (online ed.). Oxford University Press.

explanation: Wilfrid Scawen Blunt was born into a wealthy aristocratic family. His father was Francis Scawen Blunt, a retired naval officer, and his mother was born into the Shore family, which held the Baron Teignmouth peerage. The Blunt family owned Crabbet Park Estate in Sussex, indicating significant wealth and land ownership. This estate was inherited by Wilfrid from his father. His privileged background provided him with access to high-quality education, as he was educated at Twyford School and Stonyhurst College, both prestigious institutions. His family's wealth and status would have also afforded him a comfortable early life in terms of housing and living conditions.
sources: "Wilfrid Scawen Blunt: A Memoir" by Lady Anne Blunt, "My Diaries: Being a Personal Narrative of Events" by Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, "The Crabbet Arabian Stud: Its History and Influence" by Rosemary Archer, Colin Pearson, Cecil Covey, Betty Finke.

explanation:
James Beattie was born in Laurencekirk, Kincardineshire, Scotland, in 1735. His father, James Beattie, was a small farmer and a shopkeeper, which would place the family within the middle class according to the given typology. His mother, Margaret Watson, was a farmer's daughter. Beattie's parents were not wealthy, but they were able to provide a basic level of comfort and security for their family. Beattie was the youngest of six children, and after his father's death, his mother continued to run the family farm and shop, indicating a level of financial stability. 

Beattie's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended the parish school where he received a basic education. Later, he was able to attend Marischal College, Aberdeen, due to the financial support of his older brother, David, who was a successful merchant. This suggests that while the family was not wealthy, they had enough resources to support Beattie's education.
sources:
- "James Beattie", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.
- "James Beattie", Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2021.

explanation: John Boydell was born in Dorrington, Shropshire, England around 1719. His father, Josiah Boydell, was a land surveyor, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the 18th century in England. The family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence laborers or peasants. As the son of a land surveyor, John Boydell would have had some access to education, although it's unclear how extensive this was. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, reflecting their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Boydell: A Study of Art Patronage and Publishing in Georgian London" by Thomas Clayton; "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Leslie Stephen and Sidney Lee.

explanation: Sir George Gabriel Stokes, 1st Baronet, was born in Skreen, County Sligo, Ireland in 1819. His father, Gabriel Stokes, was the rector of the Church of Ireland parish of Skreen, indicating a position of some social standing within the community, but not of the elite nobility. The family's wealth would have been moderate, sufficient to provide a comfortable life but not extravagant. As the son of a clergyman, Stokes would have had access to education, and indeed he attended schools in Dublin before going on to study at the University of Cambridge in England. However, this access to education was likely due more to his father's position in the church and the value placed on education in his family, rather than any inherited wealth or privilege. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious, typical of the middle class of the time.
sources: "Memoir on the Life and Work of Sir G. G. Stokes" by Sir Joseph Larmor; "George Gabriel Stokes" by David B. Wilson; "The Stokes Phenomenon" by B. Riemann and H. Weber.

explanation: Martin Frobisher was born around 1535 in Yorkshire, England. His father, Bernard Frobisher, was a merchant who traded with the Low Countries and possessed moderate wealth. His mother's name is not known. Frobisher's father died when he was quite young, and he was sent to live with a relative, Sir John York, a merchant and former Lord Mayor of London. This suggests that his family had connections to the mercantile middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that Frobisher had access to formal education due to his family background, but he likely would have learned about trade and navigation through his family connections. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class of the time, likely comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "Martin Frobisher: Elizabethan Privateer" by James McDermott, "The Voyages of Martin Frobisher" by Robert McGhee.

explanation: George Back was born in Stockport, England, in 1796. His father, John Back, was a successful merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family's wealth allowed George to receive a good education, which was a privilege not available to all children in late 18th century England. There is no evidence to suggest that the family lived in poor conditions or that George inherited any significant disadvantages due to his birth circumstances. However, they were not part of the ruling class or nobility, which rules out the elite classification.
sources: "George Back" by E.C. Coleman, published in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Anna Brownell Jameson was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1794 to Denis Brownell Murphy, a miniature painter, and his wife, Johanna Murphy. Her father's occupation as a painter suggests a middle-class background, as he was a skilled craftsman but not part of the aristocracy. The family moved to England when Anna was young, where her father sought to improve his fortunes. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but they were able to provide Anna with a good education, further suggesting a middle-class background. Anna was educated at home by her mother and later attended a boarding school in England. The family's ability to afford a boarding school education for Anna suggests they had some disposable income, but not to the extent of the elite class. The family lived in a comfortable home in England, but there is no evidence to suggest they owned large estates or had significant wealth.
sources: "Anna Brownell Jameson." Dictionary of Women Worldwide: 25,000 Women Through the Ages, edited by Anne Commire and Deborah Klezmer, vol. 1, Yorkin Publications, 2007, pp. 1010-1011. Gale eBooks.

explanation: Thomas Shotter Boys was born in Pentonville, London, in 1803. His father, Thomas Boys, was a successful bookseller and publisher, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. The occupation of bookselling and publishing was a skilled trade, often associated with the middle class in the 19th century. It is likely that Boys had access to education due to his father's profession and the family's middle-class status. However, specific details about his early life housing, living conditions, and inherited privileges or disadvantages are not readily available.
sources: "Thomas Shotter Boys, 1803–1874, British" from the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. (https://www.nga.gov/collection/artist-info.3319.html) and "Thomas Boys" from the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-3009).

explanation: Maria Graham, born Maria Dundas, was the daughter of George Dundas, an officer in the Royal Navy. The Dundas family was a respectable family, but not part of the aristocracy. George Dundas' position as a naval officer would have provided a comfortable, but not extravagant, lifestyle for his family. Maria's access to education, as evidenced by her later writings and linguistic skills, suggests that she received a good education, a privilege often reserved for the middle and upper classes during this time period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Maria was born into wealth or inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to her family background.
sources: "Maria Graham: A Literary Biography" by Regina Akel, "Maria Graham's Journal of a Voyage to Brazil" by Maria Graham.

explanation: Thomas Willis was born in Great Bedwyn, England, in 1621. His father, Rachel Willis, was a steward to Lord Lovelace, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. This is further supported by the fact that Willis was able to attend school, suggesting that his family had the means to afford his education. His mother, also named Rachel, was the daughter of a yeoman, a social class composed of small landowners, a rank below the gentry, but above the laboring class. This further supports the classification of Willis' family as middle class.

explanation: James Mill was born in 1773 in Northwater Bridge, in the Carse of Gowrie, Scotland. explanation: Hester Thrale, born Hester Lynch Salusbury, was born into a middle-class family. Her father, John Salusbury, was a Welsh landowner and her mother, Hester Maria Cotton, was the daughter of a naval captain. The Salusbury family had a long history in Wales, but by the time of Hester's birth, their wealth had significantly diminished due to a series of poor investments and debts. Despite their financial struggles, the family maintained their middle-class status through their land ownership and connections. Hester received a good education, which was not uncommon for middle-class girls of her time, and she was known for her intelligence and wit from a young age. The family lived in a comfortable home in Bodvel, Carnarvonshire, Wales, and later moved to London.

explanation: John Robert Cozens was born to a family of middle-class social standing. explanation: Richard Garnett was born on February 27, 1835, in Lichfield, Staffordshire, England. The Garnett family was not wealthy, but they were comfortable and had access to education and cultural resources due to their father's position at the British Museum. explanation: Frederic William Farrar was born on August 7, 1831, in Bombay, India, to missionary parents. His father, Charles Farrar, was a missionary and school principal. His mother, Caroline Turner, was the daughter of a merchant. The family was not of noble or aristocratic descent, nor were they impoverished. They belonged to the middle class, as Charles Farrar's occupation as a missionary and school principal would suggest. Frederic's access to education was likely due to his family background, as his father was involved in education. explanation: John Newton was born in London in 1725. His father was a shipmaster in the Mediterranean service, which would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, who died of tuberculosis when Newton was six, was a devout Christian who had hoped her son would become a clergyman. This suggests that the family had some level of education and religious aspiration, which is also indicative of a middle-class status. However, Newton's father remarried and Newton was sent to a boarding school, where he was mistreated. This suggests that the family was not wealthy enough to provide a comfortable life for Newton, but they were able to afford a boarding school, further supporting the classification of middle class.
sources: "John Newton: From Disgrace to Amazing Grace" by Jonathan Aitken, "Out of the Depths: The Story of John Newton" by John Newton and Dennis R. Hillman.

explanation: Richard Hakluyt was born in London, England, around 1552. His father, also named Richard Hakluyt, was a member of the Skinners Company, one of the Great Twelve Livery Companies of the City of London. This suggests that the family was involved in the fur trade, a profession that would have placed them in the middle class during the late 1500s. The Skinners Company was a guild for those involved in the fur trade, and membership in such a guild was a marker of middle-class status. Hakluyt's father died when he was young, but his cousin, also named Richard Hakluyt, was a lawyer and member of the Middle Temple, one of the Inns of Court. This suggests that the family had some wealth and social standing, as the Inns of Court were institutions for those studying law, a profession typically associated with the middle class. Hakluyt was educated at Westminster School and Christ Church, Oxford, suggesting that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Hakluyts were part of the elite or ruling class.
sources: "Richard Hakluyt and Early English Travel" by Evan T. Davis, "The Hakluyt Handbook" by D. B. Quinn, "Richard Hakluyt: A Guide to His Books and to Those Associated with Him,

explanation:
George Bentham was born on September 22, 1800, in Stoke, Devon, England. His father, Sir Samuel Bentham, was a noted mechanical engineer and naval architect, while his mother, Mary Sophia Bentham, was the daughter of a successful merchant. This suggests that the Bentham family was part of the middle class, as they were neither aristocrats nor laborers. 

George Bentham's early life was marked by a good education, which was a privilege often reserved for the middle class and above during this period. His father's profession and his mother's merchant family background would have provided the resources necessary for this education. 

The Bentham family lived in a comfortable home, further indicating their middle-class status. Sir Samuel Bentham's profession would have provided a steady income, allowing the family to maintain a comfortable lifestyle. 

However, it should be noted that George Bentham did not inherit any titles or significant wealth, which would have been characteristic of the elite class. His family's status was based on their professions, not inherited privilege.

explanation: James Ussher was born into a well-established Anglo-Irish family. His father, Arnold Ussher, was a clerk in chancery who had married James Stanihurst's sister, Margaret. James Stanihurst was the speaker of the Irish House of Commons, indicating a high social standing of the family. The Usshers were part of the Anglo-Irish gentry, a social class that was considered part of the ruling elite in Ireland. They had significant land holdings, which would have provided a substantial income. James Ussher's early education was likely facilitated by his family's wealth and social standing, as he was educated in Dublin and later at Trinity College, which was a privilege typically reserved for the elite. His family's wealth and social standing would have also provided him with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions.
sources: "The Life and Times of James Ussher: Archbishop of Armagh" by J.A. Carr; "James Ussher: Theology, History, and Politics in Early-Modern Ireland and England" by Alan Ford.

explanation: Richard Doyle was born into a middle-class family. His father, John Doyle, was a notable political cartoonist, who worked under the pseudonym 'H.B.' This suggests that the family had a certain level of financial stability and social standing, as John's work was well-regarded and he was able to support his family through his art. Richard's access to education would likely have been due to his family's middle-class status, as the Doyle family was known to value education and intellectual pursuits. Richard and his siblings were educated at home by their mother, Marianne Doyle. The family lived in London, which would have provided them with access to cultural and educational resources. While there is no evidence to suggest that the Doyles were particularly wealthy, they were certainly not subsistence level, and their social standing and access to resources would have placed them firmly in the middle class.
sources: "Richard Doyle." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "John Doyle (artist)." Wikipedia. Wikimedia Foundation.

explanation:
Alexandra of Denmark was born on December 1, 1844, in Yellow Palace, an 18th-century townhouse at 18 Amaliegade, right next to the Amalienborg Palace complex in Copenhagen. Her father was Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg and her mother was Louise of Hesse-Kassel. Both her parents were of noble lineage. Her father was a minor German prince and a member of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg, while her mother was a member of the House of Hesse-Kassel, and a direct descendant of several European monarchs. Alexandra's father was chosen as the heir presumptive to the Danish throne because of his familial ties to the older royal Danish houses. This indicates that Alexandra was born into a family of high social standing and wealth. 

In terms of education, as a member of the nobility, Alexandra would have had access to the best education available at the time. She was privately educated by governesses and tutors, and was taught English by the English chaplain at Copenhagen. 

Her early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given her family's wealth and status. The Yellow Palace where she was born was a grand townhouse, indicating a high standard of living. 

Alexandra was born into a family of inherited privileges due to her noble birth. She was a princess from

explanation: William Ernest Henley was born in Gloucester, England, in 1849. His father, William Henley, was a struggling bookseller and stationer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Henley family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to provide for their children's basic needs and education. Henley attended The Crypt School, a grammar school in Gloucester, which suggests that his family had some means to afford education. However, the family's financial situation worsened after the death of Henley's father in 1861, which forced Henley to leave school and start working at a young age. Despite these hardships, Henley's early life and family background suggest a middle-class upbringing.

explanation: James Stuart, born in 1713, was a member of the British royal family, being the son of James Francis Edward Stuart and Maria Clementina Sobieska. His father, James Francis Edward Stuart, was the son of King James II and VII of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and claimed the English, Scottish, and Irish thrones as the rightful king after the deposition of his father. His mother, Maria Clementina Sobieska, was the granddaughter of the Polish king, John III Sobieski. Therefore, James Stuart was born into the elite class of society, with his parents being of royal descent and claiming thrones. His family wealth at the time of his birth and childhood was significant, as they were supported by various European courts who recognized their claims. His access to education was also privileged due to his family background, as he would have been tutored by private tutors, a luxury only the elite could afford. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of high standard, as befitting his royal status.

explanation:
George Howard Darwin was born into a family of significant social standing and wealth. His father was Charles Darwin, the renowned naturalist and author of "On the Origin of Species," who came from a wealthy family of doctors and industrialists. His mother, Emma Wedgwood, was a member of the Wedgwood family, who were prominent and wealthy pottery manufacturers. 

At the time of George's birth, the Darwin family was living in Down House, a large and comfortable country home in Kent, England. This suggests that they were financially well-off and had access to a high standard of living. 

Given his family's wealth and social standing, it is likely that George had access to a good education from an early age. His father was known to be a dedicated educator, and it is likely that he would have ensured his children received a good education. 

In terms of inherited privileges, George was born into a family with significant social and financial capital. His father's fame and the family's wealth would have provided him with numerous opportunities and advantages.

2. Browne, E. Janet (2002). Charles Darwin: vol. 2 The Power of Place. London: Jonathan Cape.
3. The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online – Biography. darwin-online.org.uk.

explanation: William Faithorne was born in London around 1616. Membership in such a guild indicates a certain level of wealth and social standing, but not to the extent of the elite or nobility. explanation: George Gilbert Scott was born in Gawcott, Buckinghamshire, England in 1811. His father, Thomas Scott, was a clergyman and a preacher, and his mother, Elizabeth Scott, was a homemaker. explanation: Bernard Bosanquet was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Reverend Charles Bosanquet, was a vicar and a member of the landed gentry, owning significant property in Northumberland. His mother, Caroline MacDowall, was the daughter of a Scottish baronet. The Bosanquet family was well-established and respected, with a history of public service and involvement in the Church. Bernard Bosanquet was educated at Harrow School, a prestigious boarding school in London, and later at Balliol College, Oxford. These educational opportunities were likely due to his family's wealth and social standing. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his family's wealth and status. He would have inherited significant privileges due to his family background.

explanation: James Bruce was born into a wealthy Scottish noble family. His father, David Bruce, was a laird, a title that denotes a significant landowner, and his mother, Marion Graham, was the daughter of a Scottish nobleman. The Bruce family was one of the oldest in Scotland, tracing their lineage back to Robert the Bruce, King of Scotland in the 14th century. This indicates that James Bruce was born into a family of high social standing and wealth. His family's wealth and status would have afforded him access to education and a comfortable early life. He was educated at Harrow School and Edinburgh University, which were exclusive institutions typically accessible only to the elite class during this period.
sources: "The Travels of James Bruce: Through Part of Africa, Syria, Egypt, and Arabia, Into Abyssinia, to Discover the Source of the Nile" by James Bruce; "James Bruce: Explorer and Linguist" by Sir Richard Burton; "The Scottish Nobility in the Late Middle Ages" by Alexander Grant.

explanation: William Booth was born on April 10, 1829, in Sneinton, Nottingham, England. His father, Samuel Booth, was a builder and a speculator in property, but his ventures did not prove successful. When William was only five, his father was declared bankrupt. After the bankruptcy, the family fell into poverty and William's mother, Mary Moss Booth, struggled to maintain the family's living conditions. William was sent to live with his grandparents for a short period of time. When he was 13, due to the family's financial difficulties, he was apprenticed to a pawnbroker. This indicates that his family did not have the means to provide him with a formal education. The family's living conditions and lack of access to education suggest they belonged to the subsistence class.
sources: "William Booth: Soup, Soap, and Salvation" by Janet Benge, Geoff Benge; "The General Next to God" by Richard Collier.

explanation: Richard Redgrave was born in Pimlico, London, in 1804. His father, William Redgrave, was a manufacturer of machinery for the production of lace, a skilled occupation that would place the family in the middle class. The family was not of aristocratic lineage or extreme poverty, suggesting a middle-class background. Richard Redgrave's access to education is also indicative of a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at a private school in Chelsea, which would have required some level of family wealth and social standing. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his father's occupation suggests they were likely comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Richard Redgrave, R.A." (1891) by F. M. O'Donoghue, published in the Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: William Davenant was born in late February 1606 in Oxford, England. His father, John Davenant, was a vintner and owner of the Crown Tavern in Oxford. His mother, Jane Shepherd Davenant, was the daughter of a wealthy London grocer. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were involved in trade and commerce, but were not nobility or landed gentry. The family's tavern was frequented by many scholars and intellectuals, including William Shakespeare, suggesting that the Davenants were well-respected and had some level of influence in their community. William Davenant was educated at the Lincoln College, Oxford, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Davenants were part of the elite ruling class or that they were impoverished.
sources:
1. "William Davenant." The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. "William Davenant." The Cambridge History of English and American Literature. Cambridge University Press, 1907–21.

explanation: George Vancouver was born in King's Lynn, Norfolk, England, around 1757. His father, John Jasper Vancouver, was a deputy collector of customs in King's Lynn, which suggests a middle-class status. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The occupation of George's father indicates a certain level of education and social standing, as customs officers were typically literate and had some level of administrative responsibility. While there is no specific information about the family's wealth at the time of George's birth and childhood, his father's occupation suggests they were not impoverished. George Vancouver was educated at King's Lynn Grammar School, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with an education, a privilege not universally accessible at the time. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "George Vancouver." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Vancouver. "George Vancouver." Canadian Encyclopedia, https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/george-vancouver.

explanation: Richard Lovelace was born into a wealthy and influential family, which was part of the English nobility. His father, Sir William Lovelace, was a knight and a prominent member of the gentry, while his mother, Anne Barne Lovelace, was the daughter of Sir William Barne, a former Lord Mayor of London. The Lovelace family owned a considerable amount of land, including the Lovelace Place estate in Kent, which suggests they were of significant wealth. Richard Lovelace's privileged background would have given him access to a high-quality education, and he was indeed educated at Charterhouse and Oxford, two of England's most prestigious educational institutions. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his family's wealth and status.
sources: "The Life of Richard Lovelace" by C.H. Wilkinson, "Lovelace, Richard (1617–1657)" by Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation:
François-André Danican Philidor was born in Dreux, France, not the United Kingdom, in 1726. He came from a family of musicians. His father, André Danican Philidor the elder, was a renowned musician who served in the court of Louis XIV. His family had been serving the French court as musicians for generations, a tradition that started with his ancestor Michel Danican, who served in the court of Louis XIII. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were skilled artisans (musicians) but not part of the nobility or ruling class. There is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or impoverished, but their consistent employment at the court would have provided a stable income. 

Philidor's access to education would have been influenced by his family background. As a child, he was sent to the choir school at Versailles, which suggests that his family had the resources to provide him with a formal education. His family's connections to the court may have also played a role in securing his admission.
sources:
- Allen, T. G. F. (1994). "François-André Danican Philidor: the life of a chess master". The Musical Times, 135(1817), 488-495.
- Harding, R. (2002). "A Philidor Family History". The Musical Times, 143(1879), 39-

explanation: Edmund Campion was born in London, England, around 1540. His father, also named Edmund Campion, was a bookseller, which was a skilled trade during the time. This would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough means to provide Campion with a basic education, as he was a choir boy at St. Paul's School, which was a privilege not available to the lower classes. However, his access to education was not solely due to his family's background but also due to his own merit and the patronage of others. After his father's death, his mother married a man of lesser means, which may have reduced the family's social standing. However, Campion's early life was marked by a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Edmund Campion: A Life" by Richard Simpson (1867); "The Life and Afterlife of St. Edmund Campion" by Gerard Kilroy (2012).

explanation: Thomas Pennant was born into a wealthy Welsh family. His father, David Pennant, was a gentleman and landowner, and his mother, Arabella Mytton, came from a family of Shropshire gentry. The Pennant family had been landowners in Flintshire since at least the 16th century, and by the time of Thomas's birth, they were one of the wealthiest families in the area. Thomas was educated at home by a private tutor before being sent to Queen's College, Oxford, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a high-quality education. His early life housing and living conditions were likely very comfortable, as his family owned a large estate, Downing Hall, in Flintshire. This background would have provided him with many inherited privileges, including wealth, education, and social connections.
sources: Pennant, Thomas. "The Literary Life of the Late Thomas Pennant, Esq." 1793; Lloyd, Jacob Youde William. "The History of the Princes, the Lords Marcher, and the Ancient Nobility of Powys Fadog." 1882.

explanation: Louis Haghe was born in Tournai, Belgium, in 1806, not in the United Kingdom. His father, Jean-Baptiste Haghe, was a respected printer and lithographer, suggesting a middle-class background. The family's ability to support Louis's apprenticeship in his father's workshop indicates a certain level of financial stability, typical of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The fact that Louis was able to learn a skilled trade from his father suggests that he had access to education, another characteristic of the middle class. Information about the family's housing and living conditions or any inherited privileges or disadvantages is not readily available.
sources: "Louis Haghe 1806–1885," Tate Museum, London; "Louis Haghe: His Life and Work," by J. R. Abbey, The Print Collector's Quarterly, 1921.

explanation: Samuel Baker was born into a middle-class family in London, England, in 1821. His father, Valentine Baker, was a merchant and a businessman, which indicates a middle-class status. The Baker family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. They had a comfortable lifestyle, and Samuel was able to receive a good education due to his family's financial stability. His early life housing and living conditions were likely typical of the middle class in the early 19th century England, with a comfortable home and access to basic amenities. There is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "The Nile Tributaries of Abyssinia and the Sword Hunters of the Hamran Arabs" by Samuel Baker; "Sir Samuel Baker: A Memoir" by Thomas Douglas Murray.

explanation: Robert Greene was born in Norwich, England, around 1558. His father, Robert Greene, was a saddler, which was a skilled trade in the 16th century. This would suggest that the family was of the middle class, as they were not nobility, but they were not laborers or peasants either. Greene's father was also a member of the local government, serving as a warden of the saddlers and a member of the city council, which further supports the idea that the family was of the middle class. Greene was able to attend Cambridge University, which suggests that his family had enough wealth to afford his education. However, this does not necessarily mean they were wealthy, as education was not exclusively for the elite during this time. It is also worth noting that Greene's mother, Alice, came from a family of weavers, another skilled trade, which further supports the classification of Greene's family as middle class.
sources: "Robert Greene." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., December 18, 2020. "Robert Greene." The Cambridge Guide to Theatre. Cambridge University Press, 1995.

explanation: Edward Bouverie Pusey was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Philip Bouverie (later Pusey), was the younger son of Jacob Bouverie, 1st Viscount Folkestone, and thus Edward was born into the British aristocracy. His father was a landowner, and the family's wealth was substantial. Edward's access to education was also a result of his family's status; he was educated at Eton, one of the most prestigious schools in England, and later at Christ Church, Oxford. His early life housing and living conditions were likely very comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. He would have inherited the privileges associated with being a member of the British aristocracy, including social connections and opportunities for advancement.
sources:
- "Edward Bouverie Pusey." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Edward-Bouverie-Pusey
- "Pusey, Edward Bouverie (PSY817EB)". A Cambridge Alumni Database. University of Cambridge.

explanation: John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester, was born into the English nobility. His father, Henry Wilmot, was the 1st Earl of Rochester, a title he was granted for his loyal service to King Charles I during the English Civil War. His mother, Anne St. John, was the daughter of the 1st Baronet St. John of Lydiard Tregoze, further cementing his noble birth. This high social standing would have provided him with a privileged upbringing, including access to quality education and comfortable living conditions. His father's wealth and title, both of which John inherited, are indicative of the family's elite status.
sources: "Life of John Wilmot Earl of Rochester" by Gilbert Burnet (1680); "The Works of John Earl of Rochester" by John Wilmot (1696); "The Complete Poems of John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester" by David M. Vieth (1968).

explanation: Peter Mark Roget was born in London, England in 1779. His father, Jean Roget, was a Genevan clergyman and his mother, Catherine Romilly, was the sister of Samuel Romilly, a legal reformer. The family was of Huguenot descent, indicating a certain level of social standing and wealth, as Huguenots were generally well-educated and skilled. Roget's father died when he was young, and his mother was noted to be overbearing, which led to Roget's early education being conducted at home. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide for his education without requiring him to work. The family moved to Edinburgh, Scotland when Roget was 12 years old, where he attended the University of Edinburgh, indicating a level of wealth and social standing that allowed for higher education.
sources: "Peter Mark Roget: British physician and philologist" by The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica; "Roget: Thesaurus compiler extraordinaire" by BBC News.

explanation: Francis Wheatley was born in London, England, around 1747. His father was a master tailor, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as tailoring was a skilled craft. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Wheatley was able to attend William Shipley's drawing school, which indicates that his family had enough resources to afford some form of education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "Francis Wheatley." Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press.

explanation: George Chapman was born in Hitchin, Hertfordshire, England around 1559. His father, Thomas Chapman, was a schoolmaster, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of schoolmaster during this period was typically associated with the middle class, as it required a certain level of education and literacy. The family's wealth at the time of George's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but the profession of his father suggests they were not impoverished. George Chapman's access to education was likely due to his father's profession, as schoolmasters often educated their own children. There is no evidence to suggest that Chapman lived in poor housing conditions or that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "George Chapman." The Cambridge Guide to Theatre. Ed. Martin Banham. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1995. Credo Reference. Web. 17 September 2012.

explanation: Thomas Weelkes was born in Elsted, Sussex, England around 1576. His father, John Weelkes, was a vicar of the local church, indicating a middle-class status. The role of a vicar during the late 1500s in England was a respected position within the community, often requiring a degree of education and literacy.
