sources: "Thomas Rowlandson: His Life and Art" by John Hayes, "Rowlandson Drawings from the Paul Mellon Collection" by Robert R. Wark, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation: Godfrey Kneller was born in Lübeck, Germany, around 1646 to a family of moderate means. His father, Zacharias Kneller, was a master schoolmaster and church organist, indicating a middle-class status. The family was not of noble birth or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide Godfrey and his siblings with a decent education. Godfrey's early access to education was due to his family's middle-class status, not because of any particular merit on his part. His father's occupation as a schoolmaster would have ensured that Godfrey and his siblings had access to education. The family's living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in the late 1600s.
sources: "Godfrey Kneller." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Godfrey-Kneller. "Sir Godfrey Kneller." National Portrait Gallery. https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp07214/sir-godfrey-kneller.

explanation: George Romney was born on 26 December 1734 in Dalton-in-Furness, Lancashire, England. His father, John Romney, was a cabinet maker and his mother, Anne Simpson, was the daughter of a yeoman. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They belonged to the middle class, as John Romney's profession as a cabinet maker was a skilled craft. George Romney was the third of eleven children, suggesting that the family had enough resources to support a large family, but not enough to provide a high level of education or luxury. George's education was limited, as he was largely self-taught. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, typical of a middle-class family in the 18th century England. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "George Romney: A Complete Catalogue of His Paintings" by Alex Kidson, "George Romney, 1734–1802" by Arthur B. Chamberlain.

explanation: William Holman Hunt was born on April 2, 1827, in Cheapside, London, to William Hunt and Sarah Hunt. His father was a warehouse manager, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They lived in a respectable neighborhood in London, indicating a comfortable living standard. Hunt's early education was at a school in which his mother had some connections, suggesting that the family had some social standing. However, his father's financial difficulties later in life led to Hunt leaving school early to work as an office clerk, indicating that the family's financial situation was not always stable.
sources: "William Holman Hunt: A Biography" by Timothy Hilton; "The Pre-Raphaelites" by Christopher Wood.

explanation:
Helena Blavatsky was born as Helena Petrovna von Hahn to an aristocratic Russian-German family in Yekaterinoslav, now Dnipro, Ukraine, not the United Kingdom. Her father, Peter von Hahn, was a Captain (later promoted to Colonel) in the Russian army, and her mother, Helena Andreyevna von Hahn (née Fadeyeva), was a renowned novelist. Helena's maternal grandfather, Andrey Mikhailovich Fadeyev, was a high-ranking civil servant, while her maternal grandmother, Princess Helena Pavlovna Dolgorukova, was a member of the Russian nobility. 

The family was wealthy and well-respected, and Helena grew up in a large, comfortable home with access to her grandfather's extensive library. Her education was provided by governesses, tutors, and later a stint at a women's institute in Saint Petersburg, indicating a privileged upbringing.
sources:
1. Cranston, S. L. (1993). HPB: The Extraordinary Life and Influence of Helena Blavatsky. G.P. Putnam's Sons.
2. Washington, P. (1995). Madame Blavatsky's Baboon: A History of the Mystics, Mediums, and Misfits Who Brought Spiritualism to America. Schocken Books.
3. Lachman, G. (2012). Madame Blavatsky: The Mother

explanation: Joseph Banks was born into a wealthy family. His father, William Banks, was a successful Lincolnshire country squire and member of the British Parliament. His mother, Sarah Bate, also came from a wealthy family. The Banks family owned a large estate in Lincolnshire, and Joseph was the only surviving son, which meant he stood to inherit the family wealth. His privileged background allowed him access to a quality education, which was not common for most people during this time. He was educated at Harrow School and later at Eton College, both prestigious institutions. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable early life and living conditions.
sources:
1. O'Brian, Patrick. "Joseph Banks: A Life." University of Chicago Press, 1997.
2. Gascoigne, John. "Joseph Banks and the English Enlightenment: Useful Knowledge and Polite Culture." Cambridge University Press, 1994.

explanation: George Herbert was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Richard Herbert, was a member of Parliament and the High Sheriff of Montgomeryshire. His mother, Magdalen Newport, was a patron of the arts and a friend of the poet John Donne. The Herbert family was well-established in the British aristocracy, with a lineage that traced back to the Earls of Pembroke. George Herbert's early life was marked by privilege and wealth, with access to high-quality education due to his family's status. He attended Westminster School and then Trinity College, Cambridge, both prestigious institutions that would have been inaccessible to those of lower social classes. His family lived in a large estate, Montgomery Castle, which further indicates their wealth and high social standing.
sources: "The Works of George Herbert" by F.E. Hutchinson, "George Herbert and the Seventeenth-Century Religious Poets [Authoritative Texts, Criticism]" by George Herbert and Mario A. Di Cesare, "George Herbert: His Religion and Art" by Joseph H. Summers.

explanation: James Macpherson was born in Ruthven, Badenoch, Scotland, in the United Kingdom around 1736. His father, Andrew Macpherson, was a farmer, which suggests that the family was not part of the elite or subsistence classes, but rather the middle class. This is further supported by the fact that Macpherson was able to attend King's College, Aberdeen, and later Marischal College, indicating that his family had enough wealth to afford his education. However, it's important to note that his access to education was also partly due to the patronage of Clan Chief, Cluny Macpherson, which suggests that his family had some social standing within their local community. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and his access to education, it's reasonable to infer that they were typical of the middle class during this period.
sources: "James Macpherson." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/james-macpherson ; "James Macpherson." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/James-Macpherson

explanation: David Ricardo was born in London, England, in 1772 to a family of Sephardic Jews who had recently emigrated from the Netherlands. His father, Abraham Ricardo, was a successful stockbroker and a member of the London Stock Exchange, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was well-off, but not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. David Ricardo was the third of seventeen children, which indicates that the family had enough resources to support a large family. Regarding education, Ricardo received a good one, but it was cut short when he joined his father's business at the age of 14. This suggests that while the family had access to education, it was not to the extent that the elite class would have had. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given Abraham Ricardo's profession, it is likely that they lived in comfortable, middle-class conditions. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "David Ricardo: A Brief Biography." The Library of Economics and Liberty. "David Ricardo (1772–1823)." The Concise Encyclopedia of Economics.

explanation: Frederic Leighton was born on 3 December 1830 in Scarborough, North Yorkshire, England. His father, Dr. Frederic Septimus Leighton, was a physician, which was a respected profession typically associated with the middle class during the 19th century. His mother, Augusta Susan Nash, came from a family of gentry, which also suggests a middle-class background. The family was financially stable, and Leighton's father was able to provide his son with a good education. Leighton was educated at University College School, London. He also lived abroad in various European cities during his childhood and early youth, which suggests that the family had the means to travel and live comfortably. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Leighton was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Frederic Leighton: Biography, Paintings, & Facts." Encyclopedia Britannica. "Leighton, Frederic." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: George Frederic Watts was born in London on February 23, 1817. His father, a poor piano tuner, was not wealthy but had a skilled trade, which suggests a middle-class standing. Watts's mother died when he was young, and his father's income was not sufficient to provide a high standard of living. However, the family was not destitute and Watts was able to receive some education. His father taught him some basic Latin and arithmetic, and he attended a local school for a short time. Despite the family's limited means, Watts showed an early talent for drawing and was able to attend the Royal Academy Schools, thanks to the financial support of a patron. This suggests that while the family was not wealthy, they had enough social connections to secure this opportunity for Watts.
sources: "G.F. Watts: The Hall of Fame: Portraits of his Famous Contemporaries" by Barbara Bryant, "George Frederic Watts: Victorian Visionary" by Mark Bills, "George Frederic Watts: The Annals of an Artist's Life" by Mrs. Russell Barrington.

explanation: William Thomson, later known as Lord Kelvin, was born on June 26, 1824, in Belfast, Ireland. His father, James Thomson, was a teacher of mathematics and engineering at Royal Belfast Academical Institution. This suggests that the family was of a middle-class background, as teaching was a profession typically associated with this social class during the 19th century. The family moved to Glasgow, Scotland, when James Thomson was appointed to the chair of mathematics at the University of Glasgow. This further suggests a middle-class upbringing, as the family had access to education and a stable income. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or part of the elite ruling class. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class of the time.
sources: "William Thomson, Baron Kelvin." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Thomson-Baron-Kelvin; "Lord Kelvin." University of Glasgow. https://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/biography/?id=WH0023&type=P

explanation: William Congreve was born in Bardsey, West Yorkshire, England, around 1670. His father, also named William Congreve, was a soldier and a staunch Royalist, which suggests a middle-class background. The family moved to Ireland following the Restoration of Charles II, where Congreve's father was granted lands and a position that would have provided a comfortable, but not aristocratic, lifestyle. Congreve's access to education was also indicative of a middle-class upbringing. He attended Kilkenny College and later Trinity College in Dublin, which would have required some level of financial means but does not necessarily indicate an elite status. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not lavish, and there is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- "William Congreve." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Congreve
- Dobrée, Bonamy. "William Congreve." The Review of English Studies, Vol. 1, No. 2 (Apr., 1925), pp. 154-174.

explanation: Arthur James Balfour was born on July 25, 1848, into the Balfour family, a prominent Scottish family with a long history of political involvement. His father, James Maitland Balfour, was a landowner and a Member of Parliament, indicating a high social standing. His mother, Lady Blanche Gascoyne-Cecil, was the daughter of the 2nd Marquess of Salisbury, further cementing the family's elite status. The Balfour family was wealthy, owning the Whittingehame Estate in East Lothian, Scotland, where Arthur was born and raised. This wealth and status would have provided Arthur with access to high-quality education and comfortable living conditions. His family background would have also granted him certain inherited privileges, such as connections to influential individuals and potential political power.
sources:
- "Arthur James Balfour, 1st earl of Balfour." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Arthur-James-Balfour-1st-earl-of-Balfour
- "Arthur Balfour." UK Parliament. https://members.parliament.uk/member/3475
- "Whittingehame Estate." East Lothian Antiquarian & Field Naturalists' Society. http://www.elafs.org.uk/ELAFS%20PDFs/Transactions%201953.pdf

explanation: William Stanley Jevons was born in Liverpool, England, in 1835. His father, Thomas Jevons, was an iron merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The iron trade was a profitable business during the Industrial Revolution, suggesting that the family had a reasonable level of wealth. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Jevons' mother, Mary Anne Roscoe, was the daughter of William Roscoe, a prominent historian, abolitionist, and Member of Parliament, which further supports the classification of the family as middle class. Jevons had access to education, attending the University College, London, which was likely due to his family's economic and social standing rather than his personal merit at that early age. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class during this period.
sources:
- "William Stanley Jevons (1835–1882)." The Concise Encyclopedia of Economics. 2008. Library of Economics and Liberty.
- Black, R.D. Collison. "Jevons, William Stanley (1835–1882), economist and philosopher." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Anthony Trollope was born in London in 1815 to Thomas Anthony Trollope, a barrister, and Frances Milton Trollope, a novelist. His father's profession would have placed the family in the middle class, as barristers were considered skilled professionals. However, the family's financial situation was unstable due to Thomas Trollope's unsuccessful ventures as a farmer and a failed Chancery suit, which led to the family's bankruptcy and subsequent move to Belgium to escape debtors. Despite these financial struggles, Anthony Trollope had access to education due to his family background. His mother, Frances Trollope, was a well-educated woman who ensured her children received a good education. She even started writing novels to support the family financially. The family's living conditions varied from comfortable to impoverished due to their fluctuating financial situation.
sources: "Anthony Trollope", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Anthony Trollope: An Autobiography", Anthony Trollope; "Domestic Manners of the Americans", Frances Trollope.

explanation: Aphra Behn, born Aphra Johnson, was the daughter of Bartholomew Johnson, a barber, and Elizabeth Denham, a wet-nurse. Her parents' occupations suggest a middle-class background, as barbers at the time were skilled tradespeople. There is no evidence to suggest that her family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, which further supports a middle-class classification. Behn's access to education is unclear, but she was literate, which suggests at least some formal education. This was not uncommon for middle-class children in the late 1600s. Her early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but there is no reason to believe they were outside the norm for a middle-class family. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Todd, Janet. "The Secret Life of Aphra Behn." Andre Deutsch, 1996. Goreau, Angeline. "Reconstructing Aphra: A Social Biography of Aphra Behn." Dial Press, 1980.

explanation: Charles Lyell was born into a wealthy family. His father, also named Charles Lyell, was a lawyer and botanist of some note. The Lyell family had a long history in Scotland and were part of the landed gentry, owning the Kinnordy estate in Forfarshire. This would have provided them with a substantial income. The family's wealth and status would have allowed Charles access to a good education. He was initially educated at home by private tutors before attending the prestigious Exeter College, Oxford. His family's wealth and status would have also provided him with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions.
sources: "Charles Lyell." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Charles-Lyell. "Charles Lyell." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-17200.

explanation: Edward Young was born to Edward Young, a fellow of Winchester College and rector of Upham. His mother was the daughter of William Turner, Esq., of Blunsdon, Wiltshire. His father's occupation as a rector and fellow of a college suggests a middle-class background, as clergy were typically considered part of the middle class in the late 17th century. His mother's family also appears to be of middle-class status, as the title "Esquire" was often used for individuals who were below the rank of knight but held a high social status. Young's access to education was likely due to his family background, as his father's position would have provided him with the resources and connections necessary for a good education. There is no evidence to suggest that Young was born into significant wealth or poverty, and his early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family at the time.
sources: "The Life of Edward Young" by Rev. John Mitford, "The Poetical Works of Edward Young" by Edward Young and John Doran.

explanation: William Cowper was born into a family of the English nobility. His father, Reverend John Cowper, was a rector of the Church of England, a position typically held by those of high social standing. His mother, Ann Donne Cowper, was a descendant of Henry III and belonged to the noble Donne family of Norfolk. Cowper was born in The Rectory, Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, indicating a comfortable living condition. His family's wealth and status allowed him access to a good education; he was first educated at home by a private tutor and later attended Westminster School, a prestigious institution in London. His family background and inherited privileges clearly place him in the elite class of the late 1700s United Kingdom.
sources: "William Cowper: A Biography" by David Cecil, "The Letters and Prose Writings of William Cowper" by James King and Charles Ryskamp.

explanation: Peter Lely, born as Pieter van der Faes, was of Dutch origin. His father, Johan van der Faes, was a captain of the infantry in the Dutch Republic. This suggests that the family was not of the ruling class or nobility, but had a respectable standing in society. The occupation of a captain would have provided a stable income, placing them in the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished. As for education, Lely was said to have been a pupil of Pieter de Grebber, a well-known Dutch painter. This suggests that his family had the means to provide him with an education in the arts, a luxury that would not have been available to those of lower social classes. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and his access to education, it can be inferred that they were likely comfortable. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Peter Lely: A Lyrical Vision," Carol Togneri, editor. The Courtauld Gallery, London, 2012. "The Dictionary of Art," Jane Turner, editor. Grove's Dictionaries, New York, 1996.

explanation: Charles Lamb was born in London, England in 1775. His father, John Lamb, was a lawyer's clerk and spent most of his professional life as a clerk to Samuel Salt, a member of parliament and a barrister at the Inner Temple. This position would have provided a stable, if not particularly affluent, income. His mother, Elizabeth Field, was a housekeeper for Salt. The family lived in the employer's home in the Inner Temple, a privileged environment that allowed Charles access to a library and an education. However, this was due to their employment rather than their own wealth or social standing. Charles Lamb was able to attend Christ's Hospital, a charity school, due to his father's connections with Salt. Therefore, despite living in a privileged environment and having access to education, the family's social standing and wealth were modest, placing them in the middle class.
sources:
- Charles Lamb, "The Old Benchers of the Inner Temple." In The Essays of Elia. 
- E.V. Lucas, "Charles Lamb and the Lloyds." In The Life of Charles Lamb, vol. 1. 
- Ainger, Alfred. Charles Lamb. Macmillan, 1882.

explanation: Friedrich Max Müller was born on December 6, 1823, in Dessau, Duchy of Anhalt (now part of Germany), not the United Kingdom. His father, Wilhelm Müller, was a popular lyricist, known for his poems that were later set to music by Franz Schubert, indicating a level of cultural and intellectual capital typical of the middle class. His mother, Adelheid Müller (née von Basedow), was the eldest daughter of a Prussian minister, suggesting a level of social standing and access to education. Friedrich Max Müller was educated at the gymnasium of Dessau and later at the University of Leipzig, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Friedrich Max Müller" by Lourens P. van den Bosch in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Friedrich Max Müller: A Life Devoted to Humanities" by Bimal Krishna Matilal in the Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London.

explanation: Johann Christian Bach was born in Leipzig, Germany, in 1735, the eleventh and youngest son of Johann Sebastian Bach, a renowned composer and musician, and Anna Magdalena Bach. His father was employed as the Cantor of the Thomasschule at Leipzig, a position of moderate prestige within the community. This position, while not making the family wealthy, did provide a stable income and a comfortable lifestyle. The family lived in the Thomasschule, a school building, which indicates a decent living condition. Johann Christian Bach had access to education, primarily due to his family background. His father, being a musician, provided him with a strong musical education from a young age. However, the death of his father when he was only 15 led to financial difficulties for the family. Despite this, his older brother, Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, took him in and continued his education. This suggests that the family had some resources to fall back on, even in times of hardship.
sources: "Johann Christian Bach: A Detailed Informative Biography." Classical Net. "Johann Christian Bach." Encyclopaedia Britannica. "Johann Sebastian Bach: Biography." BBC.

explanation: Edward FitzGerald was born into the aristocracy, the third son of the Duke of Leinster, and his mother was the daughter of the Earl of Bristol. His family was one of the wealthiest and most powerful in Ireland, with extensive landholdings. FitzGerald was born in England, but his family's wealth and status extended across the Irish Sea. His father's position as a Duke would have afforded FitzGerald access to the best education money could buy, and he would have grown up in the family's grand houses, surrounded by the trappings of wealth and privilege.
sources:
- "Edward FitzGerald." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
- "The Peerage of Ireland: A Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of That Ancient Kingdom." John Lodge, Mervyn Archdall, 1789.
- "The FitzGeralds, Dukes of Leinster." Turtle Bunbury, 2009.

explanation: Edmond Halley was born in Haggerston, in east London, England, in 1656. His father, also named Edmond Halley, was a wealthy soap-maker in London. The soap-making business was a prosperous trade during this period, which suggests that the Halley family was financially comfortable and likely belonged to the middle class. The elder Halley's wealth enabled him to provide his son with a good education. Young Halley was educated at St Paul's School, and later at The Queen's College, Oxford. This level of education was not common among the lower classes in the 17th century, further indicating the family's middle-class status. The family's living conditions would also have been relatively comfortable for the time, given the father's successful business.
sources: "Edmond Halley: Charting the Heavens and the Seas" by F. W. Clarke, "Halley's Quest: A Selfless Genius and His Troubled Paramore" by Julie Wakefield.

explanation:
Robert Adam was born in Kirkcaldy, Scotland, in 1728, the second son of William Adam, a prominent architect and entrepreneur. His father's successful career in architecture and business indicates that the family was part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but were also not subsistence workers. The Adam family was well-respected and had a comfortable lifestyle, which suggests they had a degree of wealth and stability. 

Robert Adam's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. His father was able to provide him with a good education, which included studying at the University of Edinburgh. This level of education was not typically accessible to those from lower social classes at the time.

The family's living conditions were also indicative of their middle-class status. They lived in a comfortable home, which William Adam had designed himself. This suggests that they had a degree of wealth and stability, as they were able to afford a well-designed home.
sources:
- Glendinning, M., MacInnes, R., & MacKechnie, A. (1996). A History of Scottish Architecture: From the Renaissance to the Present Day. Edinburgh University Press.
- Tait, A. (1979). The Adam Brothers in Rome: Drawings from the Grand Tour. Scala Books.

explanation: Edward Jenner was born on May 17, 1749, in Berkeley, Gloucestershire, England. His father, the Reverend Stephen Jenner, was the vicar of Berkeley, so the family was of reasonable social standing. The family lived in a vicarage, which suggests a comfortable, if not wealthy, lifestyle. Edward was the eighth of nine children, and after his father's death, he was raised by his older siblings. He received a good education, which was likely due to his family's social status and the importance they placed on education. Jenner was apprenticed to a local surgeon and then studied medicine in London, indicating that his family had the resources to support his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Jenner family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Edward Jenner (1749 - 1823)." BBC History. http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/jenner_edward.shtml ; "Edward Jenner." Science Museum Brought to Life. http://broughttolife.sciencemuseum.org.uk/broughttolife/people/edwardjenner.

explanation: David Roberts was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1796. His father, John Roberts, was a shoemaker, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Shoemaking was a skilled craft, and while it did not provide a lavish lifestyle, it would have allowed the family to live comfortably. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished. Roberts' access to education is unclear, but his early interest and talent in art suggest that he may have had some form of education, as the middle class in Scotland during this period often had access to basic education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in late 18th century Edinburgh. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "David Roberts", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Shoemaker's World: Craftsmen and Capital in the Nineteenth Century", by M. W. Kirby.

explanation: Ann Radcliffe, born Ann Ward, was born into a middle-class family in London in 1764. Her father, William Ward, was a haberdasher, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class during the late 18th century. Her mother, Ann Oates, came from a family of well-to-do grocers, further cementing their middle-class status. The family's wealth would have been sufficient to provide Ann with a comfortable upbringing, including access to education. While there is little information available about her early life housing and living conditions, it can be inferred from her family's social standing that she would have lived in a comfortable, if not luxurious, home. There is no evidence to suggest that she was born into any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- Rictor Norton (Ed.), "The Life of Mrs Radcliffe", The Great Queers of History, 20 August 2002. 
- "Ann Radcliffe", Encyclopædia Britannica, 22 Jan. 2020. 
- "Ann Radcliffe", The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica, 22 Jan. 2020, www.britannica.com/biography/Ann-Radcliffe.

explanation: Walter Pater was born in Shadwell, East London in 1839 to Richard Glode Pater, a physician, and Maria Pater, who died when Walter was a child. His father's profession as a physician suggests that the family was of the middle class, as medicine was a respected profession that required a significant level of education and skill. After his mother's death, Pater was sent to live with his aunt, who was a schoolmistress, further suggesting a middle-class background due to the family's access to education. His father's death in 1842 left the family in a precarious financial situation, but they were able to maintain their middle-class status through the support of relatives. Pater's early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in the mid-19th century, with a comfortable but not luxurious home. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Walter Pater: A Life Remembered" by Laurence Lerner, "Walter Pater: Lover of Strange Souls" by Denis Donoghue.

explanation: Inigo Jones was born in 1573 in Smithfield, London. His father, also named Inigo Jones, was a cloth worker, a trade that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The cloth trade was a skilled craft, and while it did not bring the wealth of the elite, it would have provided a comfortable living. There is no evidence to suggest that the Jones family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, suggesting a middle-class status. In terms of education, Jones was apprenticed to a joiner (a type of carpenter) named Raphael Brandon, a position that would have required some level of education and literacy. This apprenticeship suggests that Jones' family had the means to provide him with an education, further supporting a middle-class classification. However, details about Jones' early life housing and living conditions are scarce, and there is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Inigo Jones: A Life of the Architect" by Peter Cunningham; "Inigo Jones and the European Classicist Tradition" by Giles Worsley.

explanation: Ford Madox Brown was born on April 16, 1821, in Calais, France, to a family of middle-class standing. His father, Ford Brown, was a ship's purser (a ship's officer in charge of accounts, provisions, etc.), which was a respectable occupation within the middle class during the 19th century. His mother, Caroline Madox, was the daughter of a Royal Navy captain. The family had enough wealth to provide Brown with a good education. He was sent to study at Bruges Academy in Belgium at the age of 14, which indicates that the family had the resources to invest in his education. The family's ability to afford such an education, along with their occupations, suggests a middle-class standing. However, specific details about their early life housing and living conditions are not readily available.
sources:
1. Treuherz, Julian. Ford Madox Brown: Pre-Raphaelite Pioneer. Philip Wilson Publishers, 2011.
2. Lambourne, Lionel. Victorian Painting. Phaidon Press, 1999.

explanation: William Penn was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Admiral Sir William Penn, was a distinguished naval officer who served in the Second and Third Anglo-Dutch Wars. He was knighted and rewarded with a large estate in Ireland for his services to the Crown. This indicates that the Penn family was part of the ruling class, with access to the privileges that came with such a status. The family's wealth would have ensured that William had access to education and comfortable living conditions. His father's position would also have provided him with opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The Life of William Penn: With Selections from His Correspondence and Autobiography." By Samuel M. Janney, 1852; "The Penns of Pennsylvania and England." By Arthur Pound, 1932.

explanation: George Meredith was born on February 12, 1828, in Portsmouth, England. His father, Augustus Meredith, was a naval outfitter and tailor, which would place the family within the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough to provide for their basic needs and maintain a decent standard of living. George's mother died when he was only five years old, and his father remarried. George was sent to school in Germany and later to a Moravian school in Neuwied, indicating that the family had enough resources to afford a good education for him. However, his father's business failed when George was in his teens, causing a decline in the family's economic status. Despite this, George's early life was characterized by a middle-class upbringing.
sources:
- "George Meredith: His Life and Work" by J. A. Hammerton
- "George Meredith in Anecdote and Criticism" by James Milne
- "George Meredith: A Reappraisal of the Novels" by Ioan Williams

explanation: Richard Parkes Bonington was born in Arnold, near Nottingham, England. His father, also named Richard Bonington, was a skilled artisan, a drawing master, and portrait painter. His mother, Eleanor Parkes, was a teacher. The family moved to Calais, France when Bonington was young, where his father set up a lace factory. This suggests that the family had some means, but were not part of the elite ruling class. Bonington's access to education was likely due to his parents' occupations and their middle-class status. His father taught him watercolor painting, and he later attended the Louvre school in Paris. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, "Richard Parkes Bonington"; The British Museum, "Biography of Richard Parkes Bonington".

explanation: Giovanni Battista Viotti was born in Fontanetto Po, a small town in the Kingdom of Sardinia, not the United Kingdom. His birth date is believed to be May 12, 1755. His father, Giovanni Antonio Viotti, was a blacksmith, which was a skilled trade and would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. His mother's name was Anna Maria Viotti. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but they were likely comfortable given the father's profession. Viotti's early musical education was sponsored by Prince Alfonso dal Pozzo della Cisterna, which suggests that the family had some social connections, but this sponsorship was likely due to Viotti's talent rather than his family's status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but adequate for a family of their class. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Giovanni Battista Viotti: A Composer's Life" by Warwick Lister; "Giovanni Battista Viotti and His Musical Life" by Massimiliano Sala.

explanation: Sir Francis Drake was born in Tavistock, Devon, England, around 1540, the eldest of twelve sons in a farming family. His father, Edmund Drake, was a farmer and later a preacher. The family was not wealthy and lived in modest circumstances. They were forced to move to Kent due to religious persecution (they were Protestants during a time of Catholic rule). There, they lived in a hulk (an old ship) on the Medway River, where Edmund Drake ministered to the sailors of the King's Navy. Drake's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, and there's no evidence of any significant inherited privileges or advantages. His access to education would have been limited, given his family's social standing and financial situation.
sources:
- Sugden, John. "Sir Francis Drake." New York: Touchstone, 1990.
- Wilson, Derek. "Sir Francis Drake: The Queen's Pirate." New Haven: Yale University Press, 1998.

explanation: Isaac Casaubon was born in Geneva, Switzerland, in 1559, to Huguenot refugees from France. His father, Arnaud Casaubon, was a merchant and his mother, Janne Rousselet, was the daughter of a notary. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were part of the emerging middle class of the time. Isaac's father was able to provide him with a good education, which was a privilege not available to the lower classes. Isaac was sent to the Academy of Geneva at a young age, where he received a classical education. This suggests that the family had some resources and valued education, which are characteristics of the middle class. However, the family's refugee status and the fact that they were religious minorities may have limited their social standing and opportunities.
sources: "Isaac Casaubon, 1559-1614" by Mark Pattison (1892), "The World of the Favourite" edited by J.H. Elliott and L.W.B. Brockliss (1999)

explanation:
James Thomson was born in Ednam, Roxburghshire, Scotland in 1700. His father, Thomas Thomson, was a minister of the Church of Scotland, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence level either. They had a comfortable living and were respected members of their community. 

James Thomson's access to education was a direct result of his family background. His father, being a minister, would have placed a high value on education and ensured that his children were well educated. James attended the Jedburgh Grammar School and later went on to study at the University of Edinburgh, indicating that his family had the means to support his education.

The family's living conditions would have been modest but comfortable. As a minister, Thomas Thomson would have had a house provided by the church. This would have been a step up from the subsistence level, but not on par with the elite class.

There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages. The family was of a respectable standing in their community, but they were not part of the nobility or ruling class.
sources:
- "James Thomson (1700–1748)." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/james-thomson
- "James Thomson." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/James-Th

explanation: Leigh Hunt was born to Isaac Hunt, a lawyer, and Mary Hunt, a devout Christian. His father was a lawyer and his mother was a dedicated Christian. Isaac Hunt was originally from Philadelphia and had been a lawyer there before moving to England. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They had enough to provide for their children and ensure they received a good education. Leigh Hunt was educated at Christ's Hospital, a school for the sons of the London middle class. His early life housing and living conditions were typical of the middle class in the late 18th century England. He did not inherit any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources:
- Roe, Nicholas. "Fiery Heart: The First Life of Leigh Hunt." Pimlico, 2005.
- Holden, Anthony. "The Wit in the Dungeon: The Remarkable Life of Leigh Hunt-Poet, Revolutionary, and the Last of the Romantics." Little, Brown Book Group, 2005.

explanation: John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury, was born into a wealthy aristocratic family. His father, Sir John William Lubbock, was a prominent banker and astronomer. The Lubbock family was one of the principal shareholders in Lubbock & Co, a noted British bank. This wealth provided John Lubbock with a privileged upbringing and access to education, which was not common for most people during this period. He was privately tutored at home, a luxury only available to the elite class. The family lived in a large estate, High Elms Estate, indicating their high social standing and wealth. Therefore, considering his family's wealth, social standing, and his access to education, John Lubbock was born into the elite class.
sources:
1. "John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc.
2. "The Lubbock Family." The Peerage. Darryl Lundy.
3. "High Elms Country Park." London Borough of Bromley.

explanation: John Singleton Copley was born in Boston, Massachusetts, in the British American colonies, around 1738. His parents were Richard and Mary Singleton Copley. His father was from Limerick, Ireland, and his mother was from County Clare. Richard Copley was a tobacconist, but he died when John was very young. After his father's death, his mother married Peter Pelham, an engraver and painter, who had a significant influence on Copley's early artistic development. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They belonged to the middle class of the colonial society, which was made up of merchants, artisans, and skilled craftspeople. Copley's stepfather, Pelham, provided him with an education in art, which was a privilege not available to many during that time. However, this education was not due to the family's wealth or social standing, but rather Pelham's profession and skills.
sources: Prown, Jules David. John Singleton Copley. Harvard University Press, 1966.

explanation: Thomas Arne was born in London around 1710 to a father who was an upholsterer, a skilled trade that would place the family in the middle class. His father, also named Thomas Arne, was successful enough in his trade to own his own business, further supporting their middle-class status. The family was able to afford to send Arne to Eton College, a prestigious school, indicating they had some wealth and valued education. However, this does not necessarily mean they were part of the elite, as the middle class of the time could often afford such opportunities for their children. Arne's family lived in Covent Garden, a respectable area of London, suggesting they had a comfortable lifestyle but were not part of the aristocracy.
sources: "The Lives of the Great Composers" by Harold C. Schonberg, "Thomas Arne and the Mid-Eighteenth Century London Stage" by Todd Gilman, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: John Dowland was born in London, England around 1563. His father, also named John Dowland, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. There is no evidence to suggest that the Dowland family was exceptionally wealthy, but as a merchant, Dowland's father would have been able to provide a comfortable living for his family. This is further supported by the fact that Dowland was able to receive an education, which was not a given for children of lower social classes in the 16th century. He was admitted to Christ's Hospital, a charitable school in London, in 1576. However, it's important to note that this education was not necessarily a result of his family's wealth, but rather their middle-class status and the charitable nature of the institution. The family's living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the middle class in late 16th century England.
sources: Poulton, Diana. "John Dowland." In Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online, (Oxford University Press, 2007); "John Dowland." In The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, edited by Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell (London: Macmillan Publishers, 2001).

explanation: John Fletcher was born in December 1579 in Rye, Sussex, England. His father, Richard Fletcher, was a clergyman, who later became the Bishop of London, and his mother, Elizabeth Holland, was the niece of John Holland, a well-known translator. The occupation of his father as a clergyman and his mother's connection to a translator suggest that the family was of the middle class. They were not nobility, but they were not subsistence-level laborers either. The fact that Richard Fletcher was able to rise to the position of Bishop of London suggests that the family had some level of wealth and social standing. Furthermore, John Fletcher was educated at the prestigious Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, which would have been unlikely if he came from a subsistence-level family. However, it's important to note that his access to education was likely due to his father's position in the church, rather than the family's wealth.
sources: "John Fletcher (playwright)" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Dramatic Works in the Beaumont and Fletcher Canon", by Fredson Bowers; "John Fletcher: A Critical Biography", by Gordon McMullan.

explanation:
William Harvey was born in Folkestone, Kent, England around 1578. His father, Thomas Harvey, was a successful businessman and a jurat of Folkestone, which was a position of considerable local influence and prestige. This suggests that the Harvey family was well-established and financially secure, but not part of the nobility or ruling class. William was the eldest of nine children, indicating that the family had enough resources to support a large family.

In terms of education, William Harvey was able to attend the King's School in Canterbury, which was a prestigious institution at the time. This suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a high-quality education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class or higher. After his schooling in Canterbury, Harvey went on to study at Cambridge University, further indicating his family's ability to support his education.

As for housing and living conditions, there is no specific information available. However, given his father's status as a successful businessman and jurat, it can be inferred that the family lived in comfortable circumstances.

Inherited privileges or disadvantages are also not explicitly mentioned in the sources. However, Harvey's access to education and his father's status suggest that he was born into a family with certain privileges associated with the middle class.
sources:
1. "William Harvey" in the Encyclopædia Britannica.
2. "William Harvey" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
3. "

explanation: James Gillray was born in Chelsea, London, around 1756. His father, a native of Lanark, had served in the army, lost an arm at the Battle of Fontenoy, and was admitted, first as an out-pensioner, and afterwards as an in-pensioner, at Chelsea Hospital. His mother was also from a middle-class background. Gillray's early education was provided by the Chelsea Hospital school, which was established for the education of the children of soldiers. This suggests that his family had some access to education, but not the level of private tutoring or elite schooling that would be associated with the upper class. His family's housing and living conditions would have been modest but stable, typical of the middle class of the time.
sources: "James Gillray: The Art of Caricature" by Richard Godfrey; "James Gillray: A Life" by Draper Hill.

explanation: John Evelyn was born into a wealthy family in Surrey, England. His father, Richard Evelyn, was a successful gunpowder manufacturer and landowner, which indicates a high social standing. The family's wealth was substantial at the time of John's birth and throughout his childhood, as evidenced by the fact that they owned a large estate, Wotton, in Surrey. This wealth and social standing would have provided John with access to education, which was typically reserved for the elite class during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable and privileged, given the family's wealth and status.
sources:
1. "John Evelyn" by Gillian Darley, Yale University Press, 2006.
2. "The Diary of John Evelyn" edited by E.S. de Beer, Oxford University Press, 1955.
3. "The Later Stuarts 1660-1714" by Sir George Clark, Oxford History of England, 1956.

explanation:
Erasmus Darwin was born on December 12, 1731, in Elston Hall, Nottinghamshire, England. His father, Robert Darwin, was a lawyer by profession, and his mother, Elizabeth Hill, came from a family of gentry. The Darwins were a well-respected family in their community, but they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. They were comfortably middle class, with Robert Darwin's legal profession providing a stable income. 

Erasmus Darwin's access to education was a direct result of his family's social standing. His father's profession and connections enabled him to attend the Chesterfield School, a reputable grammar school, and later to study at St John's College, Cambridge. 

The Darwin family lived in Elston Hall, a substantial family home, indicating a comfortable living condition. However, they did not possess the vast estates or grand palaces associated with the elite class. 

In terms of inherited privileges or disadvantages, Darwin was born into a family that valued education and intellectual pursuits, which would have provided him with a stimulating environment growing up. However, they did not hold titles or significant political power, which would have been characteristic of the elite class.
sources:
- "Erasmus Darwin." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Erasmus-Darwin
- King-Hele, D. (1999). Erasmus Darwin: A

explanation: Kenelm Digby was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Sir Everard Digby, was a member of the gentry and was involved in the Gunpowder Plot, a failed assassination attempt against King James I of England. His mother, Mary Mulsho, came from a wealthy family as well. The Digby family owned a large estate in Stoke Dry, Rutland, indicating their significant wealth. Kenelm Digby's early life was marked by privilege and access to resources, including education. He was educated by a private tutor and later attended Oxford University, a privilege only accessible to the elite during this period. His family's wealth and social standing would have provided him with a comfortable living environment and opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The Life of Sir Kenelm Digby" by One of His Descendants, Longmans, Green, and Co., 1896; "Kenelm Digby and His Venetia: A Seventeenth-century Romance" by Martin Clifford, Methuen & Co., 1905.

explanation: Thomas Bewick was born in 1753 in the village of Cherryburn, Mickley, Northumberland, England. His father, John Bewick, was a landowner and tenant farmer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence farmers or laborers either. They had enough resources to provide Thomas with a basic education. He attended school in nearby Ovingham, where he learned reading, writing, and arithmetic. The family lived in a decent house on their farm, which suggests a level of comfort and stability. There's no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Bewick: A Life in Print" by Jenny Uglow; "Thomas Bewick: His Life and Times" by Robert Robinson.

explanation: Orlando Gibbons was born in Oxford, England, around 1583. His father, William Gibbons, was a town wait, a musician who played at public events and ceremonies, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Mary Needham, was the daughter of a joiner, a skilled craftsman, which further supports the middle-class classification. Orlando was the youngest of four brothers, all of whom became musicians, suggesting that the family had enough resources to provide their children with musical education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Gibbons family was part of the elite or nobility, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Orlando Gibbons and the Gibbons Family of Musicians" by John Harley, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Robert Bridges was born on October 23, 1844, in Walmer, Kent, England. His father, John Thomas Bridges, was a well-to-do gentleman who had retired from the military, and his mother, Harriet Elizabeth Affleck, came from a family with a naval background. This suggests that Bridges was born into a family of some means, but not of the elite ruling class or nobility. His family's status would have allowed him access to education, and indeed, he was educated at Eton College and Corpus Christi College, Oxford, which were prestigious institutions at the time. However, this education was likely due to his family's standing and not necessarily because of his own merit. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's status. There is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Robert Bridges: A Biography" by Catherine Phillips, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, "The Poetical Works of Robert Bridges" by Robert Bridges.

explanation: Tobias Smollett was born in 1721 in Cardross, Dumbartonshire, Scotland. His father, Archibald Smollett, was a judge and landowner, which indicates a middle-class status. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but they were not subsistence-level laborers either. They had enough wealth to own land and to provide Tobias with an education. Tobias attended the University of Glasgow, which suggests that his family had the means to support his education. However, it is also known that after his father's death, the family's financial situation worsened, which might have affected their social standing. Nonetheless, considering the family's initial wealth, occupation, and ability to provide education, it can be inferred that Tobias Smollett was born into a middle-class family.
sources:
1. "Tobias Smollett: Scotland's First Novelist" by David Daiches (1979)
2. "Tobias Smollett in the Enlightenment: Travels through France, Italy, and Scotland" by Richard J. Jones (1994)
3. "Tobias Smollett: Bicentennial Essays Presented to Lewis M. Knapp" by G.S. Rousseau and P.G. Boucé (1971)

explanation:
Sir Charles Hubert Hastings Parry was born into an affluent and privileged family. His father, Thomas Gambier Parry, was a wealthy artist and art collector, and his mother, Isabella Parry, came from a family with a strong military background. The Parry family was well-established and had significant wealth, which allowed Hubert to have a comfortable upbringing. 

Hubert Parry was born in Bournemouth, England, in a house called "Highnam Court," which was a large estate owned by his family. The estate was vast and luxurious, indicating the family's high social standing. 

In terms of education, Parry's family background played a significant role. He was privately educated by a succession of tutors before attending Twyford School, a prestigious preparatory school. He later attended Eton College, one of the most elite schools in England, and then went on to study at Exeter College, Oxford. His access to these institutions was largely due to his family's wealth and social standing.
sources:
1. "Parry, Sir (Charles) Hubert (Hastings)" by Jeremy Dibble, in 'Oxford Dictionary of National Biography' (Oxford University Press, 2004).
2. "The Life and Music of Sir Hubert Parry" by Jeremy Dibble (Boydell Press, 2017).
3. "Hubert Parry: His Life and Music" by Charles L.

explanation: William Chambers was born in Peebles, Scotland, in 1723. His father, James Chambers, was a prosperous draper (a dealer in cloth and dry goods), which indicates the family belonged to the middle class. The drapery business was a common occupation among the middle class during this period, as it involved trade and skilled craftsmanship. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's ability to send William and his brother Robert to local schools for their early education further supports their middle-class status, as education was not universally accessible and often depended on the family's financial situation. The Chambers family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but their ability to maintain a drapery business suggests a level of stability and comfort consistent with the middle class.
sources: "William Chambers." Dictionary of National Biography. London: Smith, Elder & Co., 1885–1900; "Chambers, William (1723–1783)." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: James Watt was born in Greenock, Scotland, in 1736. His father, also named James Watt, was a shipwright, ship owner, and contractor, as well as served as a town's chief baillie, while his mother, Agnes Muirhead, came from a distinguished family and was well educated. This suggests that the Watt family was of the middle class, as they were involved in skilled work and held a certain level of social standing in their community. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Watt's early access to education was likely due to his family's status and his mother's educational background. She home-schooled him in his early years, and he later attended Greenock Grammar School. His family's home was comfortable, though not luxurious, and he had a room where he could work on his hobbies and interests.
sources: "James Watt: Making the World Anew" by Ben Russell; "The Lunar Men: Five Friends Whose Curiosity Changed the World" by Jenny Uglow.

explanation: John Dee was born in London around 1527 to Rowland Dee and Johanna Wild. His father, Rowland Dee, was a gentleman server at the court of Henry VIII, a position that would have provided a comfortable, though not extravagant, living for the family. This suggests that John Dee was born into a family of some means, but not of the elite nobility. The fact that Dee was able to attend the Chelmsford Chantry School, a grammar school, and later St. John's College, Cambridge, indicates that his family had the resources to provide him with a good education, a privilege not available to those of lower social classes. However, it should be noted that his access to education was not solely due to his family's wealth, but also due to the patronage of relatives and family friends who recognized his intellectual potential.
sources:
- "John Dee: The World of an Elizabethan Magus" by Peter J. French
- "John Dee's Natural Philosophy: Between Science and Religion" by Nicholas Clulee
- "The Queen's Conjurer: The Science and Magic of Dr. John Dee, Adviser to Queen Elizabeth I" by Benjamin Woolley.

explanation: Augustus Pugin was born on March 1, 1812, in London, England. His father, Auguste Pugin, was a French draughtsman, artist, and writer who had moved to England as a result of the French Revolution. His mother, Catherine Welby, was from a Lincolnshire family. His father's occupation as a draughtsman and artist suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as these professions typically required some level of education and skill. There is no evidence to suggest that the Pugin family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. Augustus Pugin was educated at his father's drawing academy from a young age, indicating that the family had the means to provide him with an education. The family lived in Bloomsbury, London, which was a respectable middle-class area during the 19th century.
sources: "God's Architect: Pugin and the Building of Romantic Britain" by Rosemary Hill; "Pugin: A Gothic Passion" by Paul Atterbury and Clive Wainwright.

explanation: Richard Owen was born in Lancaster, England, in 1804. His father, Richard Owen Sr., was a merchant and his mother, Catherine Longworth, was the daughter of a local shipbuilder. This suggests that his family had a moderate level of wealth and were likely part of the middle class. His father's occupation as a merchant and his mother's family background in shipbuilding indicate that they were not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence level laborers. Owen's early education was provided by his mother until the age of nine, when he was sent to Lancaster Royal Grammar School, a sign of their middle-class status as education was not universally accessible at the time. His family's ability to provide him with an education suggests they had some level of financial stability and were likely part of the middle class.
sources: "Richard Owen: Biology without Darwin" by Nicolaas A. Rupke, "The Life of Richard Owen" by Rev. Richard Owen.

explanation: Joseph Dalton Hooker was born on June 30, 1817, in Halesworth, Suffolk, England. His father, Sir William Jackson Hooker, was a prominent botanist and professor of botany at the University of Glasgow. This suggests that the family had a decent income and a certain level of social standing, as academia was a respected profession. However, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. Joseph's mother, Maria Sarah Turner, came from a family of brewers, which also suggests a middle-class background. Joseph had access to education due to his family background, as his father was a professor and likely provided him with a good education. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Correspondence of Charles Darwin: Volume 15, 1867." Cambridge University Press, 2008. "Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker Traveller and Plant Collector." Antique Collectors' Club, 1999.

explanation: Samuel Richardson was born in 1689 to Samuel and Elizabeth Richardson in Mackworth, Derbyshire, England. His father was a joiner, a skilled craftsman who constructs the wooden components of a building, such as stairs, doors, and window frames. This occupation places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Richardson's parents had five surviving children, of which he was the third. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Richardson's father was able to send him to a local grammar school, indicating some level of disposable income. However, financial constraints prevented Richardson from attending university, a privilege often reserved for the elite class. The family lived in a modest home appropriate for a craftsman's family.
sources: Keymer, Thomas. "Richardson, Samuel (bap. 1689, d. 1761), printer and novelist." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 23 Sep. 2004; Accessed 8 Dec. 2021.

explanation: Thomas Campion was born in London, England around 1567. His father, John Campion, was a clerk of the Court of Chancery, which was a respectable profession in the middle class. However, it's important to note that his access to education was due to his family's financial and social standing, not necessarily his own merit. explanation: John Soane was born in 1753 to a family of moderate means. explanation: Charles Burney was born in Shrewsbury, England in 1726. His father, James Macburney, was a musician and dance master, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not of the elite class, as they did not hold titles or vast wealth, but they were also not of the subsistence class, as they had professional skills and were not laborers or peasants. explanation: John Franklin was born in Spilsby, Lincolnshire, England in 1786. explanation: John Vanbrugh was born into a family of merchants and sugar traders, which places them in the middle class according to the given typology. explanation: Joseph Wright of Derby was born in 1734 to a solidly middle-class family. explanation: Jenny Lind, also known as the "Swedish Nightingale," was born in Stockholm, Sweden, not the United Kingdom, on October 6, 1820. Her parents were not married at the time of her birth, and her father, Niclas Jonas Lind, was a bookkeeper, while her mother, Anne-Marie Fellborg, was a schoolteacher. They were not wealthy, and Lind's early life was marked by poverty. Her parents separated when she was young, and she was raised by her mother in a very modest environment. Her access to education was limited, and she did not receive formal musical training until she was discovered by a maid who heard her sing and arranged for her to study at the Royal Dramatic Theatre's acting school in Stockholm. Her early life housing and living conditions were poor, and she did not have any inherited privileges.
sources:
1. "Jenny Lind: The Swedish Nightingale" by Gladys Denny Shultz, J.B. Lippincott Company, 1962.

explanation: Edmund Gosse was born in London, England in 1849 to Philip Henry Gosse and Emily Bowes. His father, Philip Henry Gosse, was a self-taught naturalist, marine biologist, and author. He was not of aristocratic descent or wealth, but he had a respectable occupation that allowed him to provide for his family. His mother, Emily Bowes, was a translator and the daughter of a wine merchant. The Gosse family was religious and lived a modest lifestyle. Edmund's early education was provided by his parents, particularly his father, who taught him about natural history. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide a basic education, but not enough to afford a formal education at a prestigious institution. The family lived in a house in Islington, a district in Greater London, which suggests that they were not living in poverty, but were also not part of the elite class.
sources: "Father and Son" by Edmund Gosse; "Philip Henry Gosse: Science and Revelation in the 19th Century" by Ann Thwaite; "Edmund Gosse: A Literary Landscape, 1849-1928" by Ann Thwaite.

explanation: Edwin Landseer was born in London, England in 1802. explanation:
John Bowring was born on 17 October 1792 in Exeter, Devon, England. His father, Charles Bowring, was a wool merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The wool trade was a significant part of the British economy during this period, and merchants were typically considered part of the middle class. Bowring's mother, Sarah Jane Anne Bowring, was also from a family of merchants. 

In terms of education, Bowring was educated at a dissenting academy, which was a type of private school for nonconformists who were excluded from the universities of Oxford and Cambridge due to their religious beliefs. This suggests that his family had the means to afford a private education, further supporting their middle-class status.

As for housing and living conditions, there is little specific information available. However, as a merchant family in the late 18th century, it is likely that the Bowrings lived in a comfortable, urban dwelling.

There is no evidence to suggest that Bowring was born into either extreme wealth or poverty. His family's occupation and ability to afford a private education suggest a middle-class background.
sources:
- "John Bowring (1792–1872): The Global Career of a Radical Philanthropist" by Philip Bowring
- "The Bowring Story" by Freda Harcourt
- "The English Middle Class in the Late Eighteenth Century

explanation: Matthew Gregory Lewis was born into a family of considerable social standing in the late 18th century United Kingdom. His father, Matthew Lewis, was the Deputy Secretary at War, a high-ranking government position. His mother, Frances Maria Sewell, was the daughter of a town clerk, another position of relative prestige. This suggests that the family had a significant amount of wealth and social influence at the time of Lewis's birth and throughout his childhood. Furthermore, Lewis was educated at a private boarding school and later at Christ Church, Oxford, indicating that his family had the means to afford a high-quality education. explanation: Andrew Marvell was born in Winestead-in-Holderness, East Riding of Yorkshire, near the city of Kingston upon Hull, the son of a Church of England clergyman also named Andrew Marvell. His father was a vicar of Winestead before moving to Hull where he was appointed master of the Charterhouse. This suggests that Marvell was born into a middle-class family, as his father held a respectable profession, but was not part of the nobility or ruling class. The family's move to Hull, a significant city, also suggests they were not subsistence class. Marvell received a good education, attending Hull Grammar School and later Cambridge, which was likely due to his family's social standing and ability to afford such education. explanation: George MacDonald was born on December 10, 1824, in Huntly, Aberdeenshire, Scotland. His father, George MacDonald Sr., was a farmer, which was a respectable occupation that provided a stable income, placing the family in the middle class. MacDonald's mother, Helen MacKay, came from a family of well-known and respected preachers, further solidifying their middle-class status. Although MacDonald's father died when he was young, the family was not left destitute, indicating some level of financial stability. However, there is no evidence to suggest that MacDonald was born into the elite class or that he inherited significant wealth or privileges.

explanation: John Knox was born in Haddington, Scotland, around 1514. His father, William Knox, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. explanation: Kate Greenaway was born in Hoxton, London, in 1846 to a middle-class family. Her father, John Greenaway, was a draftsman and engraver, while her mother, Elizabeth Greenaway, was a successful milliner and dressmaker. This indicates that her family was involved in skilled professions, which is characteristic of the middle class during the Victorian era. The family's financial situation fluctuated due to her father's unstable income, but they were able to maintain a comfortable lifestyle. Kate was educated at home and later attended various art schools, suggesting that her family had the means to invest in her education. Her early life housing and living conditions were typical of a middle-class family in Victorian England, with the family living in a comfortable home in Islington, a respectable middle-class suburb of London.

explanation:
William Crookes was born on June 17, 1832, in London, England. His father, Joseph Crookes, was a tailor, which was a skilled trade and would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Mary Scott Lewis Crookes, was of Scottish descent. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to provide a decent standard of living for their children. William Crookes was the eldest of 16 children, and the family lived in a relatively comfortable home in London. 

As for education, William Crookes was able to attend the Royal College of Chemistry in London, which suggests that his family had enough resources to afford his education. It is unlikely that he would have been able to attend such an institution if his family was of the subsistence class. 

However, it should be noted that Crookes' father's business failed when he was 16, which would have significantly impacted the family's financial situation. Despite this setback, Crookes was able to continue his education, suggesting that the family had some means of support beyond their father's income.
sources:
- "Sir William Crookes (1832–1919) and the Commercialization of Science" by William H. Brock
- "William Crookes (1832–1919) and the Specter of Spiritualism" by Massimo Polidoro
- "William Crookes - An Extremely Odd Scientist

explanation: Thomas Browne was born in London in 1605, the son of a silk merchant, also named Thomas Browne. His father's occupation places the family within the middle class, as merchants were typically considered part of this social stratum. Browne's father died while he was still young, but left his family well-provided for, indicating a degree of wealth consistent with the middle class. Browne was educated at Winchester College and later at Oxford University, suggesting that his family had the means to afford a good education, a privilege often associated with the middle and upper classes. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and the family's ability to afford a good education for Browne, it is reasonable to infer that they were comfortable.

explanation: Johann Zoffany was born in Germany around 1733. His father, Anton Franz Zauffaly, was a court architect in Germany, which suggests a middle-class background. explanation: Andrew Lang was born on March 31, 1844, in Selkirk, Scotland. His father, John Lang, was the town clerk of Selkirk, and his mother, Jane Plenderleath Sellar, was the daughter of Patrick Sellar, a lawyer and factor. The position of town clerk was a respectable one, indicating that the Lang family was likely part of the middle class. Furthermore, Lang's maternal grandfather's profession as a lawyer suggests a level of education and social standing that would also be associated with the middle class. Lang himself was able to attend prestigious schools such as the Edinburgh Academy, St Andrews University, and Balliol College, Oxford, suggesting that his family had the means to support his education. explanation: William Hazlitt was born on April 10, 1778, in Maidstone, Kent, England. The family was not wealthy, but they were well-respected and had access to education and intellectual stimulation. explanation:

However, it was not his family's wealth or status that allowed him to attend university. Instead, he was able to attend through a fellowship, which was based on merit rather than family background.

His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in 17th century England. They would have lived in a modest home, likely in the town of Romsey. 

In terms of inherited privileges or disadvantages, it appears that Petty was born into a relatively stable and secure middle-class family. explanation: John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh, was born into an aristocratic family in the United Kingdom. His father, John James Strutt, was the 2nd Baron Rayleigh, a title that was part of the British peerage, indicating a high social standing. The Strutt family was wealthy and owned substantial land, including Terling Place, a large estate in Essex where John was born and raised. This wealth and status would have provided John with a privileged upbringing, including access to high-quality education. explanation: John Ray was born in the village of Black Notley in Essex, England. His father, Roger Wray, was a blacksmith, a skilled craftsperson, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. His mother, Elizabeth Wray, was the daughter of a herbalist, which also suggests a middle-class background. Despite not being wealthy, the family had enough resources to provide John with a basic education. He attended the grammar school in Braintree, which indicates that his family had the means to afford schooling, a privilege not available to all during this period. The family's housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the middle class of the time.

explanation: Richard Steele was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1672 to an attorney named Richard Steele. His father had a respectable profession, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. However, Steele's father died when he was only five years old, leaving him in the care of his uncle, Henry Gascoigne, who was a secretary to the Duke of Ormonde. This connection to a noble household might have provided some advantages, but it does not change Steele's birth status. His access to education was also due to his family background; his uncle arranged for him to be educated at Charterhouse School in London and later at Christ Church, Oxford. These were prestigious institutions, but Steele's attendance was due to his uncle's connections rather than inherited wealth or nobility.
sources: "The Life of Sir Richard Steele" by Aitken, George Atherton (1894); "The Cambridge History of English and American Literature in 18 Volumes (1907–21). Volume VIII. The Age of Dryden."

explanation: Josiah Wedgwood was born into a family of potters in Burslem, Staffordshire, England. His father, Thomas Wedgwood, was a potter and his mother, Mary Stringer, was the daughter of a Unitarian minister. The Wedgwood family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were part of the growing middle class of skilled craftspeople in the 18th century England. Josiah's father died when he was nine, leaving his mother with a small pottery business and four children to raise. Despite these hardships, the family was able to provide Josiah with a basic education, and he was apprenticed to his brother Thomas to learn the potter's trade. The family lived in a modest house, but they were not destitute. Josiah did not inherit any significant wealth or privileges, but he did inherit a trade and a modest social standing from his family.
sources: "The Wedgwood Museum", "Josiah Wedgwood: Entrepreneur to the Enlightenment" by Brian Dolan, "The Lunar Men: Five Friends Whose Curiosity Changed the World" by Jenny Uglow.

explanation: Sir Henry Raeburn was born in Stockbridge, an area of Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1756. His father, Robert Raeburn, was a manufacturer and a businessman, which suggests a middle-class background.
