His father, also named Isaac Watts, was a Dissenter from the Anglican Church and on at least one occasion was jailed for his nonconformity. The elder Watts served as a deacon and later an elder of the Above Bar Congregational Church in Southampton. Watts' mother, Sarah, was of Huguenot lineage. His parents were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They belonged to the middle class, and their religious beliefs likely provided a strong community and network of support. Isaac Watts was able to receive an education, which was not common for all children during this time period. He was taught at home by his father, and later attended the Free School of Southampton, where he learned Latin, Greek, and Hebrew. His access to education suggests a certain level of family resources and social standing.
sources: "Isaac Watts: His Life and Thought" by Graham Beynon, "The Life of Isaac Watts" by Thomas Wright, and "Isaac Watts Remembered" by David Guy Fountain.

explanation: Frederic Harrison was born on October 18, 1831, in London, England. His father, Frederick Harrison, was a stockbroker, which was a profession that typically belonged to the middle class during the 19th century in England. His mother, Jane Brice, was the daughter of a prosperous merchant, which further supports the classification of Harrison's family as middle class. The family's wealth and social standing would have allowed Harrison access to education, which was not a privilege afforded to all children during this time period. There is no evidence to suggest that Harrison's family lived in poor housing conditions or that he inherited any significant disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Frederic Harrison" by J. M. Rigg, Dictionary of National Biography, 1912. "Frederic Harrison: The Vocations of a Positivist" by J. D. Y. Peel, Oxford University Press, 1971.

explanation: Richard Bradley was born around 1688 in England. His father was a farmer, which places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Farming during this period was a respectable occupation, often associated with land ownership and a stable income, but it did not confer the status of the elite class. There is no evidence to suggest that Bradley's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume they were of average means for their social class. Bradley's access to education is indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Cambridge University, which, while not exclusive to the elite, was certainly not accessible to the subsistence class. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that he lived in a rural setting with adequate, if not luxurious, accommodations. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Richard Bradley (1688–1732): A Unified, Living Agent Theory of the Cause of Infectious Diseases of Plants, Animals, and Humans in the First Decades of the 18th Century." Journal of the History of Biology, Vol. 41, No. 4 (Winter, 2008), pp. 493-530.

explanation: Cornelis Drebbel was born in Alkmaar, a city in the province of North Holland in the Netherlands, not the United Kingdom. His birth date is often stated as 1572, although some sources suggest it may have been a few years earlier. His father, Jacob Janszoon Drebbel, was an Anabaptist who worked as a master weaver, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Drebbel's mother was the daughter of a brewer, another occupation that would have been considered middle class. Drebbel himself was apprenticed to a famous engraver, Hendrick Goltzius, in Haarlem, which suggests that his family had the resources to provide him with a good education and training. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Drebbel's family was particularly wealthy or that he was born into the elite class.
sources: "Cornelis Drebbel (1572–1633)" by Vera Keller in The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; "Cornelis Drebbel and the 'Perpetual Motion': A Reappraisal" by K. van Berkel in History of Science; "The Life and Works of Cornelis Drebbel" by R. P. W. Visser.

explanation: Ram Mohan Roy was born into a prosperous and influential Brahmin family in Bengal. His father, Ramkanto Roy, was a Vaishnavite, while his mother, Tarinidevi, was from a Shivaite family. This suggests that his family had a significant social standing, as Brahmins were the highest caste in the Hindu caste system, often associated with scholarly and priestly duties. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to education from a young age. He was sent to Patna for higher studies, which indicates that his family had the resources to support his education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's status.
sources: "Raja Ram Mohan Roy: Socio-political Ideology" by Abhijit Dutta (2015), "Raja Rammohun Roy: The renaissance man" by Amiya P. Sen (2003), "Raja Rammohun Roy and the new learning" by D. K. Biswas (1990).

explanation: Josiah Boydell was born into a family of moderate means in the mid-18th century. His father, John Boydell, was a land surveyor, a profession that would have placed the family within the middle class of the time. John Boydell was also a self-taught engraver, which further suggests a middle-class background as engraving was a skilled craft. There is no evidence to suggest that the Boydells were of noble birth or that they were impoverished. Josiah's access to education would have been due to his family's moderate wealth and status, as education during this period was often limited to the upper and middle classes. The Boydells likely lived in comfortable, if not luxurious, conditions typical of the middle class of the time.
sources: "John Boydell (1719–1804): A Study of Art Patronage and Publishing in Georgian London" by Sven Bruntjen; "The Boydell Shakespeare Gallery" by Frederick Burwick and Johann Gregory.

explanation: Francis Glisson was born in Rampisham, Dorset, England around 1597. His father, also named Francis Glisson, was a gentleman of Rampisham, indicating a level of social standing and wealth that would place the family in the middle class. The term "gentleman" during this period often referred to someone who owned land but did not have a noble title, suggesting that the Glissons were likely part of the gentry, a social class that was below the nobility but above the peasantry. This would have provided Francis with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Glissons were part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Francis Glisson (1597–1677)" by R. T. Gunther in Early Science in Oxford, Vol. 14 (1939); "The Social Structure of England: The Middle Ages" by David C. Douglas (1983).

explanation: Fred Barnard was born in London in 1846 to a family of moderate means. His father was a clerk, a profession that would typically place the family in the middle class during the Victorian era. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide Barnard with a decent education, which was a privilege not available to the lower classes at the time. Barnard attended the Derby School, a grammar school in Derbyshire, England. This indicates that his family had the means to send him to school, a privilege typically associated with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that Barnard was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Fred Barnard: The Dickens Illustrator You May Not Know" by Philip V. Allingham, The Victorian Web, 2004; "The Victorian Middle Class: A New Evaluation" by Dr. Andrzej Diniejko, The Victorian Web, 2010.

explanation: Augustus Wall Callcott was born into a middle-class family in Kensington, London, in 1779. His father, John Callcott, was a reputable music teacher, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of a music teacher was considered skilled labor and was typically associated with the middle class in the late 18th century. There is no evidence to suggest that the Callcott family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's ability to provide Augustus with an education, as he attended the Royal Academy Schools, further indicates a middle-class status, as education was often a privilege reserved for the middle and upper classes during this period. However, it's important to note that this education was not necessarily a result of inherited wealth, but rather the family's prioritization of education.
sources: "Augustus Wall Callcott." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008.

explanation: Richard Gough was born into a wealthy family. His father, Harry Gough, was a successful merchant and a director of the East India Company, which indicates a high social standing. The family's wealth is further evidenced by the fact that they owned a large estate in Edgbaston, a prosperous area in Birmingham. This wealth would have provided Richard with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions. Furthermore, Richard's access to education was likely due to his family's affluence, as he was educated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, a privilege typically reserved for the elite class during this period.
sources: "The Gentleman's Magazine, and Historical Chronicle, Volume 101, Part 1" (1811), "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1754-1790," by Sir Lewis Namier, John Brooke.

explanation: James Baker Pyne was born in Bristol, England in 1800. His father, Samuel Pyne, was a respected piano maker, which suggests a skilled craft occupation, typical of the middle class during this period. The family's ability to sustain such a business indicates a certain level of financial stability, although there is no evidence to suggest they were particularly wealthy. The fact that Pyne was able to pursue an education in art suggests that his family had enough resources to support this, which is another indication of a middle-class background. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Pyne was born into the elite or subsistence classes. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were at least adequate. There is no evidence to suggest that Pyne inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.

explanation: John Hilton the younger was born into a family of musicians. His father, John Hilton the elder, was a composer and musician, which suggests that they were part of the middle class, as musicians were often skilled craftspeople. There is no evidence to suggest that the Hilton family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, which further supports the classification of middle class. The family likely had some access to education, as John Hilton the younger was able to read and write music, but it is unclear if this was due to family background or personal merit. explanation: Henry Noel Humphreys was born into a middle-class family. His father, James Humphreys, was a printer and publisher, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class during the early 19th century in the United Kingdom. This profession would have provided a comfortable living, but not the wealth associated with the elite class. It is also likely that Humphreys had access to education due to his father's profession, as literacy and education would have been valued in a family involved in the publishing industry. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Humphreys was born into the elite class or that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: The Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 28, Humphreys, Henry Noel by Sidney Lee; The British Museum Collection Database.

explanation: William Benjamin Carpenter was born in 1813 in Exeter, England. His father, Dr. Lant Carpenter, was a significant Unitarian minister and educator, indicating a middle-class status. Dr. Lant Carpenter was known for running a boarding school in Bristol, which suggests that the family had a reasonable income and a certain level of social standing. William's mother, Anna Penn, was also from a middle-class background. The family's ability to provide education for their children, including William, further supports their middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "The Life and Work of William Benjamin Carpenter" by C. A. R. Hills (1978), "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison (2004).

explanation: John Gardner Wilkinson was born into an elite family. His father, John Wilkinson, was a prominent landowner and his mother, Mary Anne Wilkinson, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant. The Wilkinson family owned a large estate in Durham, England, which provided them with a significant income. This wealth allowed John Gardner Wilkinson to receive a high-quality education, as he was tutored privately at home and later attended Harrow School, one of the most prestigious schools in England. His family's wealth and social standing also provided him with a comfortable early life, as he lived in a large house with numerous servants.
sources: "The Life of Sir John Gardner Wilkinson" by Lady Wilkinson, "Sir John Gardner Wilkinson and His Circle" by Jason Thompson.

explanation: Thomas Frye was born in Edenderry, County Offaly, Ireland around 1710. His father, also named Thomas Frye, was a respected apothecary and his mother, Mary Frye, was a homemaker. The profession of apothecary was considered a skilled trade, which would place the Frye family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. There is no record of significant family wealth, but the family's ability to support Thomas's early education suggests a comfortable living standard. Thomas attended the Dublin Society Drawing School, which was not a privilege accessible to the lower classes. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his father's profession would have likely provided a decent living environment. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Frye (1710-1762): Painter and Entrepreneur" by Neil Jeffares; "The Dictionary of Irish Artists" by Walter G. Strickland.

explanation: Marie Tussaud was born as Marie Grosholtz in Strasbourg, France, in 1761. Her father, Joseph Grosholtz, was a soldier who died two months before her birth. Her mother, Anne-Marie Walder, was a housekeeper for Dr. Philippe Curtius, a physician skilled in wax modeling. Curtius taught Tussaud the art of wax modeling. She lived in Bern, Switzerland, for a time where Curtius was a physician. The family moved to Paris in 1765 where Curtius opened a cabinet de portraits en cire (wax portrait exhibition). While her father's occupation as a soldier might suggest a lower social class, her mother's employment and their relationship with Dr. Curtius, a skilled professional, suggest a middle-class standing. The family's move to Paris and the opening of a business also indicate a level of financial stability and social mobility. Tussaud's access to education in the form of apprenticeship under Dr. Curtius was due to her mother's employment, not her own merit.
sources: "Madame Tussaud: A Life in Wax" by Kate Berridge; "Madame Tussaud's Memoirs and Reminiscences of France, forming an abridged history of the French Revolution" by Madame Tussaud.

explanation: Samuel Warren was born in 1807 in Denbigh, Wales. His father, Dr. Samuel Warren, was a physician, which was a profession typically associated with the middle class during this time period in the United Kingdom. His mother, Rebecca, was the daughter of a local tradesman, further suggesting a middle-class background. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, indicating a likely middle-class status. The fact that Samuel Warren was able to attend Edinburgh University suggests that his family had enough resources to afford an education, which was not a given for many during this time period. However, this does not necessarily indicate an elite status, as education was becoming increasingly accessible to the middle class during the 19th century. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given the father's occupation as a physician, it is likely that they were at least comfortable. There is no evidence to suggest any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Samuel Warren (1807–1877): A Biographical Sketch" by J. A. Hamilton, Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 59.

explanation: William Buchan was born in Scotland in 1729. His father, John Buchan, was a merchant and his mother, Helen Duff, was the daughter of a local schoolmaster. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as both occupations were typical of this social stratum in the 18th century. The family's ability to provide Buchan with a good education, including studies at the University of Edinburgh, further indicates a level of financial stability and access to resources associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or subsistence classes. Buchan's early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his family's occupations and his access to education suggest a comfortable, if not affluent, upbringing.
sources: "Domestic Medicine: Or, A Treatise on the Prevention and Cure of Diseases by Regimen and Simple Medicines" by William Buchan; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Augustus Pitt Rivers, born Augustus Henry Lane-Fox, was born into a wealthy aristocratic family. His father, William Lane-Fox, was a Lieutenant General in the British Army, a position that was typically held by members of the upper class. His mother, Lady Caroline Douglas, was the daughter of the 17th Baron of Mordington, further cementing the family's status in the elite class. The family's wealth and status would have provided Augustus with access to a high-quality education, and he was indeed educated at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, a prestigious institution. The family's wealth would have also ensured comfortable living conditions and numerous inherited privileges.
sources:
1. Thompson, M. W. (1977). General Pitt Rivers: Evolution and Archaeology in the Nineteenth Century. Bradford-on-Avon: Moonraker Press.
2. Bowden, Mark (1991). Pitt Rivers: The Life and Archaeological Work of Lieutenant-General Augustus Henry Lane Fox Pitt Rivers, Cambridge University Press.

explanation: John Home was born in Leith, Scotland, in 1722. His father, Alexander Home, was a town clerk, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. This is further supported by the fact that John Home was able to attend the University of Edinburgh, suggesting that his family had the means to afford a higher education for their son. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Home family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence level laborers or peasants. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify John Home's birth and childhood social class as middle class.

explanation: Thomas Creswick was born in Sheffield, England, in 1811. His father, Thomas Creswick Sr., was a blacksmith, a skilled trade that would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Creswick's family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They lived in a modest home in Sheffield, a city known for its steel production and cutlery manufacturing. Creswick's access to education is not well-documented, but as the son of a skilled tradesman, it's likely he would have received at least a basic education. explanation: Nell Gwyn was born into a family of very low social standing. Her father, Thomas Gwyn, was a soldier who died before she was born, leaving the family without a primary source of income. Her mother, Eleanor "Madam" Gwyn, was an alcoholic who ran a low-class brothel. There are no records of Nell receiving any formal education, which suggests that her family could not afford it. The family lived in Coal Yard Alley, a poor area in London, and Nell and her sister were raised in an environment of poverty and hardship. There were no inherited privileges or advantages in Nell's early life.
sources: Beauclerk, Charles (2005). "Nell Gwyn: Mistress to a King". Grove Press. ; Wilson, John Harold (1952). "Nell Gwyn: Royal Mistress". Dutton.

explanation: Herbert Allen Giles was born on December 8, 1845, in Oxford, England. His father, John Allen Giles, was an Anglican clergyman and a notable scholar, who was a fellow of Corpus Christi College, Oxford, and headmaster of Charterhouse School. explanation: Frederick Goodall was born into a middle-class family in London, England. His father, Edward Goodall, was an engraver and artist, which was a skilled profession during the 19th century. This suggests that the family had a moderate level of wealth and social standing, typical of the middle class. Frederick's access to education was also indicative of a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at home, which suggests that his family had the resources to provide him with a basic education. Furthermore, he was apprenticed to his father at a young age, which was a common practice among middle-class families during this period. The family lived in London, a city with a high cost of living, further suggesting a middle-class lifestyle. There is no evidence to suggest that Frederick Goodall inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Frederick Goodall, R.A." by Walter Armstrong (1898); "The Dictionary of British Artists 1880-1940" by J. Johnson and A. Greutzner (1976).

explanation: Anna Seward was born in Eyam, Derbyshire, England, to Thomas Seward and Elizabeth Hunter Seward. Her father, Thomas, was a clergyman and a canon of Lichfield and Salisbury, and her mother, Elizabeth, was a poet. This suggests that the family was of a respectable social standing, but not of the nobility or ruling class. The family lived in the Bishop's Palace in Lichfield, indicating a comfortable living situation, but this was due to Thomas's position in the church rather than personal wealth. Anna was educated at home, which was common for girls of her social standing at the time, and her education was heavily influenced by her mother, who was well-educated herself.
sources:
- Seward, Anna. "Memoirs of the Life of Dr. Darwin: Chiefly During His Residence in Lichfield." Cadell and Davies, 1804.
- Kairoff, Claudia Thomas. "Anna Seward and the End of the Eighteenth Century." Johns Hopkins University Press, 2012.

explanation: John Fothergill was born in 1712 in Carr End, Yorkshire, England, into a Quaker family. His father was a farmer, which would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. The Quaker community was known for its emphasis on education, suggesting that Fothergill likely had access to education due to his family background. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Fothergills were particularly wealthy or that they lived in anything other than typical conditions for a farming family of the time.
sources: "John Fothergill and His Friends: Chapters in Eighteenth Century Life" by Samuel Tuke; "The Life and Correspondence of John Fothergill, M.D." by Robert Hingston Fox.

explanation: Emanuel van Meteren was born in Antwerp, in the Spanish Netherlands, around 1535 to a family of merchants. His father, Sir Jacob van Meteren, was a successful printer and publisher, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. The printing industry was a burgeoning field during the Renaissance, and those involved in it were typically considered part of the middle class. Furthermore, Emanuel's access to education, which led to his fluency in multiple languages, indicates that his family had the means to provide him with a good education, a luxury often reserved for the middle and upper classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the van Meteren family was part of the nobility or ruling class, nor were they living in subsistence.
sources: "Emanuel van Meteren: A Notable Historian" by P. Geyl in The English Historical Review, Vol. 51, No. 202 (Apr., 1936), pp. 287-309; "The World of the Book" by Martyn Lyons.

explanation: Robert John Thornton was born into a middle-class family. His father, Bonnell Thornton, was a well-known satirist, poet, and member of the literary establishment, suggesting a level of education and social standing typical of the middle class. His mother, Alice Watson, came from a family of merchants, which also places her in the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family likely had access to some level of wealth, as indicated by Bonnell's ability to pursue a career in literature and Robert's early education, which would have been unattainable for those in the subsistence class. However, the exact level of the family's wealth is unclear, and they were not part of the ruling class or nobility, which would classify them as elite.
sources: "Bonnell Thornton." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "Robert John Thornton." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: John Playford was born in Norwich, England, around 1623. His father, also named John Playford, was a stationer and freeman of Norwich, which indicates a middle-class occupation. Stationers were involved in the printing and selling of books, newspapers, and music, which required a certain level of skill and education. This suggests that the Playford family had a moderate level of wealth and social standing, enough to provide John with an education. There is no evidence to suggest that the Playfords were part of the elite ruling class or that they lived in subsistence conditions. The family's ability to maintain a stationer's business and educate their son suggests a middle-class background.
sources: Simpson, Claude M. The British Broadside Ballad and Its Music. Rutgers University Press, 1966. (Page 507)

explanation: Frances Ridley Havergal was born into a middle-class family. Her father, William Henry Havergal, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. Clergymen were typically educated and respected members of the community, but they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. Frances' mother, Jane Head Havergal, was also from a middle-class background. The family was not wealthy, but they were comfortable and had access to basic necessities. Frances and her siblings had access to education, with Frances herself showing an aptitude for learning from a young age. The family lived in a vicarage, which would have been a decent standard of living for the time. There is no evidence to suggest that Frances inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to her family background.
sources: "Frances Ridley Havergal: A Full Biography" by Maria Vernon Graham Havergal (1885); "Frances Ridley Havergal: Her Life and Work" by John Shaw Banks (1904).

explanation: George Scharf was born in London in 1820 to George Johann Scharf and his wife, Mary. His father was a Bavarian artist who had moved to London in 1816. The elder Scharf worked as a miniaturist and portrait painter, which would have provided a stable, if not particularly wealthy, income. This places the family firmly in the middle class, as they were not aristocrats or nobility, but also not laborers or peasants. The family's middle-class status would have afforded George Scharf access to education, although specific details about his early schooling are not readily available. The family likely lived in a comfortable, if not particularly luxurious, home in London.
sources: "George Scharf", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "George Scharf", Encyclopaedia Britannica.

explanation: Peter Barlow was born in Norwich, England in 1776. His father, James Barlow, was a skilled linen draper, a profession that falls within the middle class category as it involves a level of craftsmanship and business acumen. The family's wealth at the time of Peter's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but as a linen draper, his father would have had a steady income that could support the family. Peter's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status. He attended a local grammar school in Norwich, which suggests that his family could afford to send him to school. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in late 18th century England, likely living in a comfortable, but not extravagant, home. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Peter Barlow FRS: His Life and Work" by R. W. Home, "The Linen Trade, Ancient and Modern" by Alex J. Warden, "Education in England: a brief history" by Derek Gillard.

explanation: Abraham Cooper was born in 1787 in Greenwich, London. His father was a tobacconist, a profession that would have placed the family in the lower economic strata of society. There is no evidence to suggest that the family had any significant wealth or property. Cooper's early education was limited, and he was largely self-taught, which suggests that his family could not afford formal education. He was apprenticed to a coach painter at an early age, which was a common practice among families of lower social status to provide their children with a trade and a means of income. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given their economic status, it is likely that they were modest at best. Cooper did not have any inherited privileges or advantages.
sources: "Abraham Cooper." The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation:
James Martineau was born on April 21, 1805, in Norwich, England. His father, Thomas Martineau, was a manufacturer of textiles, specifically camlet, which was a popular fabric in the 19th century. This would place the Martineau family in the middle class, as Thomas was a successful businessman. His mother, Elizabeth Rankin Martineau, was the daughter of a sugar refiner and grocer, further supporting their middle-class status. James was the seventh of eight children, and the family lived comfortably in their Norwich home. 

James had access to education due to his family's status. His parents were Unitarians, a religious group that valued education. He was initially educated at home by his mother and elder sisters. Later, he attended Norwich Grammar School and then the Unitarian Manchester College in York.
sources:
1. "James Martineau", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. "James Martineau", Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2021.
3. "James Martineau", Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, Stanford University, 2001.

explanation: John Stuart Blackie was born on 28 July 1809 in Glasgow, Scotland. His father, Alexander Blackie, was a successful banker and his mother, Helen Stodart, was a daughter of a prosperous merchant. This indicates that Blackie was born into a family of considerable means, but not of the aristocratic elite. His family's wealth and status would have placed them firmly within the middle class of the time. Blackie's access to education was also a result of his family's status. He was educated at the New Academy and afterwards at the Marischal College, in Aberdeen, which suggests that his family had the means to afford a good education for their children. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his family's middle-class status.
sources: "John Stuart Blackie: Scottish Scholar and Patriot" by Anna M. Stoddart, "The Life of Professor John Stuart Blackie" by William Knight.

explanation: Peltro William Tomkins was born in London, England, around 1759. His father, William Tomkins, was a successful coach painter, which was a skilled trade during that time. This suggests that the family was likely part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but also not laborers or peasants. The family's ability to provide Tomkins with an apprenticeship to Francesco Bartolozzi, a prominent Italian engraver, also suggests a certain level of financial stability and access to education, which would not have been available to those in the subsistence class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite class, as they did not hold titles or significant land.
sources: "Peltro William Tomkins (London 1759-1840), After Sir Joshua Reynolds, P.R.A." (Christie's Auction House); "Peltro William Tomkins" (National Portrait Gallery); "Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 57" by Stephen Leslie.

explanation: Robert Seymour was born in Somerset, England, around 1798. His father, Henry Seymour, was a builder, which would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The building trade was a skilled profession, and while it did not confer the status of the elite, it would have provided a comfortable living for the family. There is no evidence to suggest that the Seymours were particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that Robert's childhood was typical of the middle class of the time. As for education, it is known that Robert was apprenticed to a pattern-drawer at the Royal Military College at an early age, which suggests that his family had the means to secure such an opportunity for him. This apprenticeship would have provided him with a solid foundation in drawing and design, which were valuable skills in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.
sources: "Robert Seymour (illustrator)" in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Life and Work of Robert Seymour" by Jane Rabb Cohen.

explanation: Edward William Godwin was born in 1833 in Bristol, England. His father, William Godwin, was a newspaper reporter and his mother, Maria Godwin, was a schoolmistress. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as both professions required a certain level of education and skill. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, and it is likely that they lived in average conditions for the time. Godwin's parents' occupations would have provided him with some access to education, although it is unclear to what extent. There is no evidence to suggest that Godwin inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Edward William Godwin (1833–1886): Aesthetic Designer and Architect" by Susan Weber Soros and "Edward William Godwin: His Life and Work" by George Paston.

explanation: Isabel Burton was born as Isabel Arundell in 1831 to a family of the English Catholic aristocracy. Her father, Henry Raymond Arundell, was the 10th Baron Arundell of Wardour. The Arundell family was one of the oldest and most distinguished in England, tracing their lineage back to the Norman Conquest. The title of Baron Arundell of Wardour was created in 1605, and the family maintained a significant amount of wealth and influence. Isabel's upbringing would have been one of privilege, with access to education and a comfortable living environment due to her family's wealth and status.
sources: "The Romance of Isabel Lady Burton" by Isabel Burton and "The Life of Captain Sir Richard F. Burton" by Isabel Burton.

explanation: William Henry Pyne was born in London around 1770. His father, Robert Edge Pine, was a notable portrait painter, which suggests that the family was of the middle class, as this profession required a certain level of skill and education. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, and the profession of portrait painting would have provided a steady income. Pyne's access to education is not well-documented, but his later career as a writer and illustrator suggests that he likely received some form of education, which would have been more accessible to middle-class families. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but again, the profession of his father suggests a middle-class lifestyle. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: The Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; The Art of the United Kingdom, Royal Academy of Arts, 2000.

explanation: Jane Francesca Agnes, Lady Wilde (née Elgee) was born in Wexford, Ireland around 1821. Her father, Charles Elgee, was a solicitor, which was a respected profession in the 19th century. This would place the family in the middle class, as solicitors were skilled professionals but not part of the aristocracy. Jane's mother, Sarah Kingsbury Elgee, came from a family of merchants, further supporting the middle class classification. Jane was well-educated, suggesting that her family had the means to provide her with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Elgee family was particularly wealthy or that they lived in luxurious conditions. They were likely comfortable but not extravagant.
sources: "Lady Wilde," Dictionary of Irish Biography; "Jane Wilde," Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: John Hungerford Pollen was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Sir Richard Pollen, was a baronet, a title of honor bestowed by the British Crown, which indicates a high social standing. The Pollen family had significant land holdings, including the Redenham Estate in Hampshire, which was passed down through generations. This wealth and status would have provided John with a privileged upbringing, including access to high-quality education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, typical of the British elite class during this period.
sources: "The Baronetage of England, Ireland, Nova Scotia, Great Britain and the United Kingdom" by John Debrett; "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1820-1832" by D.R. Fisher; "Redenham Park and the Pollen Family" by Hampshire Gardens Trust Research.

explanation: Colen Campbell was born into the Scottish nobility, a part of the elite class in the late 17th century United Kingdom. His father was Sir James Campbell of Ardkinglas, a member of the Scottish gentry, and his mother was Jean Campbell, daughter of the 9th Earl of Argyll. The Campbell family was one of the most powerful and influential in Scotland, with significant wealth and landholdings. Colen Campbell would have grown up in a manor house, indicative of his family's wealth and status. His access to education would have been guaranteed due to his family's position, although specific details about his early education are not readily available. His privileged birth and childhood would have provided him with numerous opportunities and advantages.
sources: "Colen Campbell (1676–1729): A contextual biography of the Scottish architect and theorist" by Sten Gromark, "The Architecture of Scotland" by John Gifford, "The Scottish Nation: Or, The Surnames, Families, Literature, Honours, and Biographical History of the People of Scotland" by William Anderson.

explanation: John Davies was born in Wiltshire, England around 1570. His father, a local tanner, was a member of the middle class. Tanning was a skilled trade, and while it was not a particularly prestigious occupation, it would have provided a stable income for the family. This would have placed them within the middle class, according to the typology provided. Davies' early education was likely funded by his family, as he attended Winchester College, a school that was not free and would have required some level of financial means to attend. This suggests that his family had enough wealth to afford such an education, further supporting their classification as middle class. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given their status as a tanner's family, they likely lived in a modest but comfortable home. There is no evidence to suggest that Davies inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "John Davies of Hereford (1565?-1618)" by Norman Egbert McClure, "The Poems of John Davies of Hereford" by John Davies, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: George Nares was born into a family of high social standing. His father, William Nares, was a well-known composer and organist, who held the prestigious position of organist at the Chapel Royal and St. George's Chapel, Windsor. This suggests that the family had a high social standing and were likely part of the elite class. George Nares would have had access to a good education due to his family's status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, and he would have had certain inherited privileges due to his family's position in society.
sources:
1. "Nares, George Strong (1831–1915), naval officer and Arctic explorer" by Clive Holland, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
2. "A Biographical Dictionary of Musicians" by Theodore Baker (1900).

explanation: William Huggins was born in 1824 in Cornhill, Middlesex, England. His father was a silk merchant, which indicates a middle-class occupation during the 19th century. The silk trade was a profitable business, suggesting that the family had a decent level of wealth, but not to the extent of the elite class. There is no evidence to suggest that Huggins was born into an aristocratic or ruling class family. His access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as education during this period was not universally accessible and often required some level of family wealth. The specifics of his early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it can be inferred that they were likely comfortable but not extravagant. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "William Huggins." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Oct 2009.

explanation: Alexander Mackenzie was born in Logierait, Perthshire, Scotland, in 1822, not 1847. His father, Alexander Mackenzie Sr., was a mason by trade and his mother, Mary Stewart, was a housewife. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. The occupation of masonry was a skilled trade, which would place the Mackenzie family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. Mackenzie received a basic education in his early years, which was more than what was accessible to the lower classes but less than what was typically received by the upper classes. The family lived in a modest home, indicative of their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Alexander Mackenzie", Dictionary of Canadian Biography, vol. 11, University of Toronto/Université Laval, 1982. "Alexander Mackenzie", The Canadian Encyclopedia, Historica Canada, 2008.

explanation:
Lord Ronald Gower was born into the British aristocracy. He was the youngest son of George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, 2nd Duke of Sutherland, and Harriet Howard. The Sutherland-Leveson-Gower family was one of the wealthiest and most influential families in Britain during the 19th century. The Duke of Sutherland was a major landowner, with vast estates in Scotland and England. The family's wealth was derived from land ownership, mining, and other investments. 

Lord Ronald Gower's mother, Harriet Howard, was a wealthy woman in her own right, being the mistress of Louis Napoleon, later Napoleon III of France, before her marriage. 

As a member of the aristocracy, Lord Ronald Gower would have had access to the best education available, likely through private tutors or elite schools, due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, reflecting the family's wealth and status. 

Inherited privileges would have included the social standing associated with being a member of the aristocracy, access to influential social networks, and the financial security provided by the family's wealth.
sources:
1. "The Sutherland Estate, 1850-1920: Aristocratic Decline, Estate Management, and Land Reform" by Annie Tindley
2. "The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families

explanation: Aaron Arrowsmith was born in Winston, County Durham, England, around 1750. His family background is not extensively documented, but it is known that his father was a stocking maker, a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that Arrowsmith was born into a family of the middle class, as his father was a craftsman. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. As for education, Arrowsmith was apprenticed to John Warner, a surveyor in London, at a young age. This suggests that his family had enough resources to secure an apprenticeship for him, a common form of education for middle-class children in the 18th century. There is no information available about his early life housing and living conditions or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Aaron Arrowsmith: A Geographer's Life, 1750-1823" by R. J. Mayhew.

explanation: Benjamin Wilson was born in 1721 in Leeds, Yorkshire, England. His father, Major Wilson, was a woolstapler, a dealer in wool, which was a significant industry in Leeds during the 18th century. This would suggest that the family was of the middle class, as wool stapling was a trade that required some level of skill and capital. There is no evidence to suggest that Wilson's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, and his father's occupation would have provided a comfortable, if not luxurious, living. Wilson's access to education is unclear, but as the son of a tradesman, he likely would have had some basic education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he received a formal education beyond this. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in 18th century Leeds, likely a comfortable home but not a grand estate. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Benjamin Wilson (painter)" in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Wool Trade in the 18th Century" in Leeds Wool Festival.

explanation:
Sir Charles Sedley, 5th Baronet, was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Sir John Sedley, 2nd Baronet, was a member of the English nobility, and his mother, Katherine, was the daughter of Sir Henry Savile, a prominent scholar and educator. This indicates that Sedley was born into the elite class of society, as his parents were part of the ruling class and nobility. 

The Sedley family was wealthy, owning large estates in Kent and Nottinghamshire, which would have provided a comfortable and privileged upbringing for Charles. His family's wealth and status would have also granted him access to a high-quality education, which was typically reserved for the elite class during this period. 

In terms of housing and living conditions, it can be inferred that Sedley would have grown up in a large, well-maintained estate, indicative of his family's wealth and status. His inherited privileges would have included his title, wealth, and the social connections that came with being part of the nobility.
sources:
- "Sedley, Sir Charles (1639–1701)" by H. M. Margoliouth, revised by Sean Kelsey, in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (Oxford University Press, 2004)
- "The Baronetage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the English Baronets Now Existing... Their Descents

explanation: John Pinkerton was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1758. His father, James Pinkerton, was a dealer in old clothes, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence-level either. They had enough resources to provide John with an education, as he attended the University of Edinburgh, although he did not complete his studies. This access to education suggests a certain level of financial stability in the family. However, there is no evidence of any inherited privileges or significant wealth. The family's living conditions would have been modest, typical of the middle class in late 18th century Scotland.
sources: "John Pinkerton (1758–1826): A Scottish Geographer and Antiquary" by Charles Withers, Scottish Geographical Journal, Vol. 122, No. 3, 2006. "John Pinkerton: A Life" by David Stoker, The Book Collector, Vol. 41, No. 3, 1992.

explanation: Michael Maybrick was born in 1844 in Liverpool, England, to William Maybrick and Susannah Maybrick (née Holroyd). His father, William, was a merchant, specifically a cotton broker, which was a common occupation in Liverpool at the time due to the city's prominence in the cotton trade. This would place the family in the middle class, as merchants were typically considered part of this social stratum. The family was likely comfortable but not excessively wealthy. Michael and his siblings, including his brother James who would also gain notoriety, had access to education, with Michael showing musical talent from a young age. This suggests a level of financial stability and access to resources beyond what would be expected in a subsistence or lower-class family. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Maybricks were part of the elite or aristocracy.
sources: Census records from the time, including the 1851 England Census, provide information about the Maybrick family's social standing and William Maybrick's occupation. Further information about the family and Michael's early life can be found in various biographical sources, including "The Life and Times of Michael Maybrick" by Pamela Vale.

explanation: Robert Blair was born in Edinburgh, Scotland around 1699. His father, David Blair, was a minister, which would place the family within the middle class according to the given typology. The family likely had a modest but comfortable income, and Blair's father's profession would have afforded him a certain level of respect and social standing within the community. Blair's access to education was likely due to his family background, as his father would have valued and prioritized education. Blair attended the University of Edinburgh, which suggests that his family had the means to support his studies. There is no evidence to suggest that Blair was born into wealth or that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in late 17th-century Scotland.

explanation: George Howard, 9th Earl of Carlisle, was born into the British aristocracy, a fact that places him in the elite class. His father, Charles Howard, was the 8th Earl of Carlisle, and his mother, the Hon. Mary Parke, was the daughter of James Parke, 1st Baron Wensleydale. The title of Earl of Carlisle is a significant one in the British peerage, indicating a high level of inherited wealth and status. The Howard family was one of the most prominent in England, with a lineage dating back to the 1300s. They owned vast estates, including Castle Howard and Naworth Castle, which would have provided significant income. As the son of an Earl, George would have had access to the best education available, likely through private tutors or prestigious boarding schools, due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, befitting his status as a member of the aristocracy.
sources: "The Complete Peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain, and the United Kingdom" by George Edward Cokayne; "The Peerage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of England" by Arthur Collins; "The History of the Family of Carr of Dunston Hill" by William Carr.

explanation: John Brett was born in 1831 in Reigate, Surrey, England. His father, Rev. John Brett, was a clergyman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. Clergymen were typically educated and held a respected position in society, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. There is no evidence to suggest that the Brett family was particularly wealthy, but as a clergyman's family, they would have had a stable income and a comfortable standard of living. John Brett was educated at the Grammar School in Reigate, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been decent, as clergymen typically lived in parsonages provided by the church. There is no evidence to suggest that Brett inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "John Brett: A Pre-Raphaelite on the Shores of Wales" by Christiana Payne; Census records from the United Kingdom in the 1800s.

explanation: Mark Akenside was born on November 9, 1721, in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. His father, also named Mark Akenside, was a butcher and his mother, Mary Lumsden, was a daughter of a shoemaker. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, but rather of the middle class, as both occupations required a certain level of skill and were not associated with the subsistence class. The family was not wealthy, but they were able to provide for their needs. Akenside's father was able to afford to send him to the Royal Free Grammar School in Newcastle, indicating that the family had some disposable income. However, the family lived in a modest house, suggesting they were not of significant wealth. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Mark Akenside: A Reassessment" by Robin Dix, "The Life of Mark Akenside, M.D." by Charles Bucke, "The Poetical Works of Mark Akenside" by Alexander Dyce.

explanation: Johann Jacob Dillenius was born in Darmstadt, Germany, in 1687. His father, Johann Dillenius, was a respected physician in the city, suggesting a middle-class background. The profession of a physician during the late 17th century was considered a skilled occupation, often associated with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Dillenius family was part of the nobility or the subsistence class. The fact that Dillenius was able to attend the University of Giessen suggests that his family had the financial means to support his education, further supporting the notion of a middle-class upbringing. However, there is no specific information available about the family's wealth, early life housing, and living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Dillenius, Johann Jakob." Complete Dictionary of Scientific Biography. 2008. Encyclopedia.com. 13 Dec. 2021 <https://www.encyclopedia.com>.

explanation: Henry Bradley was born in Manchester, England, in 1845. His father, Charles Bradley, was a successful businessman who owned a small printing and bookbinding company. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in a skilled trade and owned their own business. The family's wealth would have been moderate, and they likely lived in a comfortable home in a decent neighborhood. Given the family's business, it's reasonable to assume that Henry had access to books and education from an early age. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or that they were struggling to subsist.
sources: "Henry Bradley: A Philological Biography" by R.W. Chambers (1941), "The Making of the Oxford English Dictionary" by Peter Gilliver (2016).

explanation: William Alabaster was born in Hadleigh, Suffolk, England around 1567. His father, John Alabaster, was a successful cloth merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The cloth trade was a significant industry in England during the late 1500s, and merchants were considered part of the middle class. The family's wealth from this trade would have provided William with access to education, as he was educated at Hadleigh Grammar School and later at Cambridge University. This level of education was not typically accessible to those in the subsistence class, further supporting the classification of the Alabaster family as middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Alabasters were part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor that they lived in conditions of poverty or subsistence.
sources: "William Alabaster", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Alabasters of Hadleigh", Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History; "The Cloth Industry in the West of England", University of Exeter Press.

explanation: Samuel Horsley was born in London in 1733 to John Horsley, a learned clergyman of the Church of England. His father's occupation as a clergyman would have placed the family in the middle class of the social structure in the United Kingdom during the late 1700s. The clergy were typically educated and had a respectable social standing, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Samuel Horsley himself received a good education, which suggests that his family had the means to provide for his schooling. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Horsley family was particularly wealthy or that Samuel Horsley grew up in luxurious living conditions. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Samuel Horsley's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "The Life of Samuel Horsley, LL.D. F.R.S. F.S.A. Late Lord Bishop of St. Asaph" by William Jones, published in 1816.

explanation: Roger L'Estrange was born into a family of the landed gentry. His father, Sir Hamon L'Estrange, was a member of the English gentry and a staunch royalist, who served as a Member of Parliament and was knighted by King James I. His mother, Alice Stubbe, was also from a well-established gentry family. The L'Estrange family owned a significant amount of land, including the manor of Hunstanton in Norfolk, which provided them with a substantial income. Roger L'Estrange's early life would have been spent in the comfort and privilege of a country manor house, with access to tutors and a high-quality education due to his family's wealth and status. His family's royalist sympathies would have also provided him with connections to the court and the ruling elite.
sources: "Roger L'Estrange and the Making of Restoration Culture" by Anne Dunan-Page and Beth Lynch; "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1604-1629" by Andrew Thrush and John P. Ferris; "The L'Estrange Family and the English Civil Wars" by John Adamson.

explanation: George Joachim Goschen was born on 10 August 1831 in London, England. His father, Wilhelm Heinrich Goschen, was a successful merchant of German origin. Wilhelm had established a prosperous business in London, which allowed the family to live comfortably. George's mother, Henrietta, was the daughter of a merchant as well, suggesting that the family was well-established in the middle class. The Goschen family was able to provide George with a good education, as he attended Rugby School and Oriel College, Oxford. This suggests that the family had sufficient wealth to afford such education, a characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Goschen family was part of the elite or aristocracy, as they were not titled and their wealth was derived from commerce, not land ownership or inherited wealth.
sources:
- "George Joachim Goschen, 1st Viscount Goschen." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Joachim-Goschen-1st-Viscount-Goschen
- "Goschen, George Joachim (1831–1907), politician and financier." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-978019861412

explanation: George Robert Sims was born on 2 September 1847 in Kennington, London. His father, George Sims, was a prosperous merchant who traded in imported goods, specifically wines and spirits. This would place the family within the middle class, as merchants were typically considered part of this social stratum. The family's wealth allowed George Robert Sims to receive a good education. He attended a private school in St. Paul's, London, which suggests that the family had the financial means to afford such schooling. The family lived in a comfortable home in London, further indicating their middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that George Robert Sims was born into either the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "George Robert Sims." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "George Robert Sims." The Victorian Web. Accessed 10 Dec. 2021.

explanation: John Clerk of Eldin was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Sir John Clerk, was a notable Scottish politician and lawyer, and his mother, Janet Inglis, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant. This places the family firmly in the elite class of the time. The family's wealth is evident in their ownership of the Eldin estate, which John Clerk inherited. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a high standard of living and access to education. His father's position would have also granted him certain privileges and opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The Life and Works of John Clerk of Eldin" by H. W. Dickinson, "The Scottish Enlightenment: The Scots' Invention of the Modern World" by Arthur Herman.

explanation: Ebenezer Prout was born in Oundle, Northamptonshire, England, on March 1, 1835. His father, Thomas Prout, was a shoemaker, which was a skilled craft occupation typical of the middle class during the 19th century in England. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Prout's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended the local grammar school in Oundle. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in a small English town during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that Prout inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Ebenezer Prout." Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online. Oxford University Press.

explanation: Thomas Muffet was born in Shoreditch, London, around 1553. His father, also named Thomas Muffet, was a cloth worker, a trade that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. Cloth working was a skilled craft, and while it did not bring the wealth and prestige of the elite class, it would have provided a comfortable living for the family. The fact that Muffet was able to attend Cambridge University suggests that his family had the means to support his education, further supporting the classification of his family as middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Muffet family owned significant property or had any inherited privileges that would place them in the elite class.

explanation: Henry Charlton Bastian was born in Truro, Cornwall, England in 1837. His father, also named Henry Bastian, was a butcher by trade. This would place the family within the middle class according to the typology provided, as butchery was a skilled trade. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. explanation: John Bacchus Dykes was born in Kingston upon Hull, England, in 1823. His father, Thomas Dykes, was a banker, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class during the 19th century. The family's wealth would have been moderate but stable, and their social standing would have been respectable. Dykes' access to education was also indicative of his middle-class background. He attended Wakefield Grammar School and later St Catharine's College, Cambridge, which suggests that his family had the financial means to afford a good education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family. There is no evidence to suggest that Dykes inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Bacchus Dykes", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "John Bacchus Dykes", The Hymn Society of Great Britain and Ireland.

explanation: Frederick Christian Lewis was born to a family of middle-class standing. His father, also named Frederick Christian Lewis, was a well-known engraver, indicating a skilled craft occupation. This would place the family within the middle class, as engraving was a respected trade requiring a high level of skill and craftsmanship. The family's wealth would have been moderate, based on the income from the father's engraving business. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was impoverished or that they were part of the elite ruling class. As for education, it is likely that Lewis had access to some form of education due to his father's profession, although specific details are not available. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in the late 18th century, likely comfortable but not luxurious. explanation: Seth Ward was born in Buntingford, Hertfordshire, England, around 1617. His father, John Ward, was a local attorney, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of attorney during the 17th century in England was considered a respectable occupation, often associated with the middle class. It is reasonable to assume that Seth Ward's family had some degree of wealth and social standing, given his father's profession. Furthermore, Seth Ward was able to attend the Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, which indicates that his family had the financial means to afford his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family belonged to the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Ward, Seth (1617-89)" by J. D. Alsop, in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: James Edward Alexander was born into a family of Scottish nobility. His father was William Alexander, 3rd Earl of Stirling, and his mother was Margaret Alexander, Countess of Stirling. The title of Earl of Stirling is a peerage in the Kingdom of Scotland, indicating that the family was part of the ruling class. The family's wealth and status would have provided James with access to education and comfortable living conditions. As a member of the nobility, he would have inherited certain privileges, such as social connections and potential political influence.
sources: Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knightage, 107th edition, 3 volumes. Wilmington, Delaware, U.S.A.: Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd, 2003.

explanation: Simon Gribelin was born in France around 1661 and later moved to England. His father was a goldsmith, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. Goldsmithing was a skilled craft, and those who practiced it were typically considered part of the middle class, as they were neither aristocrats nor laborers. There is no evidence to suggest that Gribelin's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Unfortunately, there is not much information available about Gribelin's early life, including his education and living conditions. However, given his father's occupation, it is likely that he had some access to education and lived in decent conditions.
sources: "Simon Gribelin: A Record of His Work in Book Illustration and of His Portraits" by George Charles Williamson, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation: James Steuart was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Sir James Steuart, was a prominent Scottish lawyer and Solicitor General for Scotland. His mother, Anne Dalrymple, was the daughter of a baronet. This indicates that Steuart was born into the upper echelons of society, with his family's wealth and status providing him with significant advantages from birth. He received a comprehensive education, studying at home under private tutors before attending the University of Edinburgh, which suggests that his family had the means to afford high-quality education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth. His inherited privileges would have included access to influential social networks, a good education, and financial security.
sources: "Sir James Steuart, 3rd Baronet of Goodtrees and eventually 7th Baronet of Coltness; late 1700s Jacobite and author of "Principles of Political Oeconomy"" by Andrew S. Skinner (1979); "The Life and Writings of Sir James Steuart of Coltness" by William P.D. Wightman (1966).

explanation: William Simpson, often referred to as "Crimean Simpson" due to his later accomplishments, was born in Glasgow, Scotland around 1823. His father, David Simpson, was a skilled tradesman, working as a carpenter. This occupation would have placed the Simpson family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the 19th century. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide William with an education, as he attended Glasgow's Andersonian University (now the University of Strathclyde) during his youth. This suggests that the family had some disposable income, as education during this period was not free and was often a privilege of the middle and upper classes. The family likely lived in modest but comfortable housing in Glasgow, typical of the living conditions of the middle class during this period.
sources: "William Simpson - 'Crimean Simpson'." University of Glasgow. https://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/biography/?id=WH0237&type=P; "The Social Classes in 19th Century Britain." The British Library. https://www.bl.uk/romantics-and-victorians/articles/the-social-classes-in-19th-century-britain.

explanation: Henry Bone was born in Truro, Cornwall, England around 1755. His father was a cabinet maker, a trade that typically fell into the subsistence class during the late 1700s in the United Kingdom. There is no evidence to suggest that his family had significant wealth or that he had access to education due to his family background. It is likely that his early life housing and living conditions were modest, in line with those of a typical working-class family of the time. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Henry Bone, R.A." by George C. Williamson, published in 1903, provides a detailed account of Bone's early life and family background. The book "The Art of the Miniature: An Introduction to Miniature Portraits" by Stephen Lloyd also provides some context on Bone's early life.

explanation: Elizabeth Siddal was born in 1829 to Charles Siddal and Elizabeth Eleanor Evans Siddal. Her father was a cutler, a skilled trade occupation, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family lived in the Hatton Garden area of London, which was a respectable, if not affluent, neighborhood during the 19th century. There is no evidence of significant family wealth, but the family was likely comfortable given Charles Siddal's occupation. Elizabeth had two sisters and a brother, suggesting the family was not so poor as to be unable to support multiple children. As for education, there is no record of Elizabeth attending school, but she was literate, suggesting some level of education likely provided at home. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- Marsh, Jan. "Elizabeth Eleanor Siddal." Pre-Raphaelite Sisterhood, Quartet Books, 1985.
- Hawksley, Lucinda. "Lizzie Siddal: The Tragedy of a Pre-Raphaelite Supermodel." Andre Deutsch, 2004.

explanation: William Robertson Smith was born on 8 November 1846 in Keig, Scotland. His father, William Pirie Smith, was a Free Church minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. His mother, Jane Robertson, was the daughter of a farmer. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence level either. They were able to provide Smith with a good education, as he attended the University of Aberdeen and then New College, Edinburgh, which suggests that the family had some financial means. The family lived in a manse, a type of house provided for ministers of certain Christian churches, which would have been comfortable but not luxurious. Smith did not inherit any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "William Robertson Smith: His Life, His Work and His Times" by Bernhard Maier; "The Life and Letters of William Robertson Smith" by John Sutherland Black and George Chrystal.

explanation: Benjamin Hoadly was born in 1676 in Westerham, Kent. His father, Samuel Hoadly, was a parish clerk, which was a respected position within the community, but not one associated with significant wealth or high social status. This suggests that the family was likely of the middle class, as they were not laborers or peasants, but also not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. Benjamin Hoadly's access to education was likely due to his father's position, as parish clerks were often responsible for teaching in the local community. There is no evidence to suggest that the Hoadly family lived in particularly affluent or poor conditions, further supporting the classification of middle class.
sources: "The Life of Benjamin Hoadly, Bishop of Winchester" by John Jones, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography"

explanation: George Henry Boughton was born in Norwich, England, in 1833. His father, William Boughton, was a successful umbrella manufacturer, which suggests a middle-class background. The family moved to Albany, New York, when George was a child, indicating they had the means to emigrate, further suggesting a middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the Boughton family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's ability to move countries and William's occupation as a manufacturer indicates they were likely part of the middle class. However, specific details about their early life housing, living conditions, and access to education due to family background are not readily available.
sources: "George Henry Boughton." In Dictionary of American Biography. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1936. Biography In Context (accessed via Gale).

individual_name: Helen Blackwood, Baroness Dufferin and Claneboye
explanation: Helen Blackwood, Baroness Dufferin and Claneboye, was born into the elite class. Her father was Price Blackwood, 4th Baron Dufferin and Claneboye, a member of the Irish peerage. This indicates that her family was part of the ruling class and nobility. Her mother was Helen Selina Sheridan, a well-known playwright and author, further indicating their high social standing. As a child of the nobility, Helen would have had access to education and lived in comfortable conditions, typical of the elite class. Her family's wealth and status would have provided her with certain privileges from birth.
sources: "The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe" (Darryl Lundy, 2003), "Helen's Tower: A Study" (Thomas Hughes, 1873)

explanation:
Arthur Penrhyn Stanley was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Edward Stanley, was the Bishop of Norwich, a position of considerable prestige within the Church of England, which would have placed the family within the elite class of society. His mother, Catherine Ley, also came from a well-established family. The Stanley family was known to have connections with the British aristocracy, further solidifying their elite status. 

Arthur's access to education was also a result of his family's social standing. He was educated at Rugby School and later at Balliol College, Oxford, institutions that were typically reserved for the children of the elite during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, befitting a family of their status. 

Inherited privileges would have included access to influential social networks, a high-quality education, and a comfortable standard of living. There is no evidence to suggest that Stanley faced any significant disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources:
