explanation: Richard Jefferies was born on November 6, 1848, in Swindon, Wiltshire, England. His father, James Luckett Jefferies, was a farmer and a miller, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. His mother, Elizabeth Gyde, came from a family of shoemakers. The family lived in a farmhouse known as Coate, which was owned by Richard's grandmother. This suggests that the family had some level of wealth and property, further supporting their classification as middle class. Richard received his early education at a local school, indicating that his family could afford to send him to school, a privilege not available to all children at the time. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Jefferies family was part of the elite or ruling class.
sources: "Richard Jefferies: His Life and Work" by Samuel J. Looker, "The Story of My Heart" by Richard Jefferies, "Richard Jefferies: A Bibliographical Study" by Hugoe Matthews and Phyllis Treitel.

explanation: Matthew Digby Wyatt was born in Rowde, Wiltshire, England in 1820. His father, Matthew Wyatt, was a solicitor, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the 19th century in England. The family was not of noble birth or aristocratic lineage, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The profession of solicitor would have provided a comfortable living, but not the level of wealth associated with the elite class. Wyatt's access to education, including his studies at the Bristol College School, would have been facilitated by his family's middle-class status. However, specific details about the family's wealth, early life housing, and living conditions are not readily available.
sources: "Matthew Digby Wyatt." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/30102, accessed 5 Dec 2021]

explanation: John Byron was born into the British nobility, which places him in the elite class. His father, William Byron, was the 4th Baron Byron, a title that was passed down through the family. This title indicates a high social standing and significant wealth. The Byron family was one of the oldest and most distinguished in Nottinghamshire, owning Newstead Abbey, a large estate that had been in the family since the 16th century. As a member of the aristocracy, John Byron would have had access to education and lived in comfortable conditions. His birth and childhood circumstances were characterized by inherited privilege.
sources:
- "Byron, John (1723-1786), of Newstead Abbey, Notts." History of Parliament Online. 
- Moore, Doris Langley. "Byron: The Years of Fame." Penguin Books, 1961.

explanation:
Edward Stanley, 15th Earl of Derby, was born into the British nobility, a part of the elite class of the society. His father was Edward Smith-Stanley, 14th Earl of Derby, a prominent British statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom three times. His mother was Emma Caroline Bootle-Wilbraham, daughter of Edward Bootle-Wilbraham, 1st Baron Skelmersdale. The Stanley family was one of the oldest and most influential families in the British aristocracy, with a lineage dating back to the 15th century. 

At the time of Edward's birth, his family was wealthy and held significant political influence. They owned substantial estates, including Knowsley Hall in Lancashire and Stanley House in London. Edward's birth into the Stanley family would have afforded him numerous privileges, including access to high-quality education and comfortable living conditions.
sources: 1. "The Complete Peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain and the United Kingdom, Extant, Extinct or Dormant", by G. E Cokayne; with Vicary Gibbs, H.A. Doubleday, Geoffrey H. White, Duncan Warrand and Lord Howard de Walden, editors, new ed., 13 volumes in 14 (1910-1959; reprint in 6 volumes, Gloucester, U.K.: Alan Sutton Publishing, 2000), volume

explanation: Edward Stillingfleet was born in Cranborne, Dorset, England in 1635. His father, also named Edward Stillingfleet, was a steward to the Earl of Salisbury, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. Stewardship was a position of trust and responsibility, often held by educated men, and would have provided a comfortable living for the family. Edward's mother, Sarah, was the daughter of a vicar, further suggesting a middle-class background. Edward was the youngest of five children, and the family lived in a house provided by the Earl of Salisbury, indicating a stable and comfortable living situation. Edward's early education was provided by his father, which suggests that the family had the resources and knowledge to provide for their children's education.
sources: "Edward Stillingfleet", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Edward Stillingfleet: 17th Century Anglican Apologist", Churchman 103/4 1989; "Edward Stillingfleet", The British Library.

explanation: John Lockwood Kipling was born in Pickering, North Yorkshire, England, in 1837. His father, Reverend Joseph Kipling, was a Methodist minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. His mother, Frances Lockwood, was also from a middle-class background. The family was not wealthy, but they were not living in poverty either. John Lockwood Kipling had access to education due to his family background. He attended the Wesleyan academy in Woodhouse Grove, Bradford, where his father was a headmaster. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family of the time. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Lockwood Kipling: Arts & Crafts in the Punjab and London" by Julius Bryant and Susan Weber; "Rudyard Kipling: A Life" by Harry Ricketts.

explanation: Andrew Geddes was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1783. His father, David Geddes, was a prosperous merchant and his mother, Janet, was the daughter of a successful farmer. This suggests that the Geddes family was part of the middle class, as they were neither aristocrats nor laborers. The family's wealth allowed Andrew to receive a good education. He was educated at the Royal High School and the Trustees’ Academy in Edinburgh, indicating that his family had the means to afford a quality education. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it is likely that they were comfortable. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Andrew Geddes 1783-1844: Painter-printmaker: A man of pure taste" by Helen Smailes (2001); "The Dictionary of Scottish Painters: 1600 to the Present" by Paul Harris and Julian Halsby (2010).

explanation: John Lingard was born in 1771 in Winchester, England. His father, John Lingard, was a carpenter, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. This is because carpentry was a skilled trade, and skilled tradespeople were considered part of the middle class in the late 18th century. Lingard's mother, Elizabeth Rennell, was the daughter of a farmer, which also suggests a middle-class background. Lingard was educated at the English College, Douai, in France, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education. However, it's important to note that Lingard's education was also funded by the college itself, which provided scholarships to promising students from less wealthy backgrounds. Therefore, while Lingard's family was not wealthy, they were not subsistence-level either.
sources: "John Lingard: The Historian as Apologist" by Patrick N. Allitt; "John Lingard and the Pursuit of Historical Truth" by Edwin Jones.

explanation: Thomas Attwood was born in 1783 in Halesowen, then a village in Shropshire, England. His father, Matthias Attwood, was a banker and a businessman, which indicates that the family was of a middle-class background. The fact that Matthias was a banker suggests that the family had a reasonable amount of wealth, and were not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Thomas Attwood was educated at Halesowen Grammar School, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education - a privilege not available to all during this period. The family's ability to provide Thomas with an education, along with their occupation, suggests that they were part of the middle class.
sources: "Thomas Attwood: Britain's First Democratic Leader" by Chris Upton; "The Life and Times of Thomas Attwood" by Peter Cadogan.

explanation:
George Saintsbury was born on 23 October 1845 in Southampton, England. His father, Thomas Saintsbury, was a wine merchant, which was a respectable occupation within the middle class during the Victorian era. This would have provided the family with a comfortable living, but not to the extent of the elite class. His mother, Mary Ann Saintsbury, was a homemaker. George was the youngest of six children. 

The family's middle-class status is further evidenced by George's access to education. He attended King Edward VI School, a grammar school in Southampton, and later studied at Merton College, Oxford. While it's not clear if his family's wealth specifically enabled his education, it's likely that their middle-class status made it more accessible. 

There is no evidence to suggest that the Saintsbury family lived in particularly opulent or impoverished conditions, which further supports the classification of George's birth and childhood social class as middle class.

explanation: Marc Isambard Brunel was born on April 25, 1769, in Hacqueville, Normandy, France. His father, Jean Charles Brunel, was a prosperous farmer and landowner, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology. Marc Isambard Brunel received a good education, attending a seminary in Rouen, which suggests his family had the means to provide for his education. There is no evidence to suggest that the family lived in poor housing conditions or that Brunel had any inherited disadvantages due to his birth and childhood circumstances.
sources: "Marc Isambard Brunel." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Marc-Isambard-Brunel

explanation: Sir Astley Paston Cooper was born in 1768 in Norfolk, England. His father, Dr. Samuel Cooper, was a clergyman, and his mother, Maria Susanna Bransby, was the daughter of a reverend. This suggests that the family was part of the educated middle class. The profession of clergyman was a respectable one in the 18th century, often held by individuals with a university education. It is also known that Astley Cooper was educated at home by his parents before being sent to school in London, indicating that the family had the resources to provide him with a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or ruling class, as they did not hold titles or vast wealth. Similarly, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the subsistence class, as they were not laborers or peasants and had access to education and a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Sir Astley Paston Cooper, 1st Baronet." Encyclopædia Britannica. "Astley Cooper." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Eliza Lynn Linton was born in Keswick, Cumberland, England, in 1822. Her father, the Reverend J. Lynn, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which suggests a middle-class background. Clergymen were typically considered part of the middle class in the 19th century, as they were educated and held a respected position in society, but they were not part of the aristocracy. Eliza was the youngest of twelve children, which suggests that the family was not extremely wealthy, but they were likely comfortable. She was educated at home by her mother, which was common for middle-class girls during this period. The family lived in a parsonage, which would have been a comfortable home, but not a grand estate.
sources: "Eliza Lynn Linton: The Girl of the Period" by Deborah Meem; "Victorian England: Aspects of English and Imperial History 1837-1901" by Lawrence James.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Matthew Locke, born circa 1632, are not well-documented. There is little to no information available about his parents' occupations, family wealth, access to education, early life housing and living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages. While he is known to have been a chorister at Exeter Cathedral and later a composer, the circumstances leading to these opportunities are unclear. It is therefore not possible to classify his birth and childhood social class with reasonable confidence.
sources: The primary sources that could potentially provide this information would be parish records, census data, or other historical documents from the time and place of Locke's birth and childhood. However, such records from the early 17th century are often incomplete or have not survived. Further research would be needed in local archives or through historical societies in the region where Locke was born.

explanation: Jan Siberechts was born in Antwerp, Belgium, not the United Kingdom, around 1627. His father, also named Jan Siberechts, was a sculptor, which indicates that the family belonged to the artisan class, a subset of the middle class. The Siberechts family was likely not wealthy, but they had enough resources to provide Jan with an education in the arts. Jan was trained by his father and later by the painter David Ryckaert II. This access to education suggests a certain level of financial stability, as does the family's ability to support Jan's artistic career. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Siberechts family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Jan Siberechts (1627–1703): A 17th-century Flemish Landscape and Genre Painter in England" by Julia Lloyd Williams; "Flemish Art and Architecture, 1585-1700" by Hans Vlieghe.

explanation: Rhoda Broughton was born into an elite family in the United Kingdom around 1840. Her father, Delves Broughton, was a clergyman, which was a position of high social standing during this period. Her mother, Jane Bennett, was the daughter of a wealthy landowner. This indicates that Rhoda was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. Furthermore, Rhoda's access to education, which was likely due to her family's wealth and status, suggests that she was part of the elite class. She was educated at home by a governess, a privilege typically reserved for the upper classes during this period. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable, as they would have had the means to afford a large home and servants.
sources: "Rhoda Broughton" by Julia Courtney (1996), "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" (2004)

explanation: William Withering was born in 1741 in Wellington, Shropshire, England. His father, Edmund Withering, was an apothecary, which was a skilled profession in the medical field, indicating a middle-class status. His mother, Sarah Hector, was the daughter of a wealthy farmer, suggesting some level of financial stability and access to resources. Withering was able to attend Edinburgh University to study medicine, which indicates that his family had the means to support his education. This suggests that his family was not subsistence level, but rather middle class, as they had the financial means to support his education and his father held a skilled profession.
sources: "William Withering of Birmingham (1741-1799): The Life and Times of a Lunar Man" by Richard J. Haines, "William Withering and the Purple Foxglove: A Bicentennial Tribute" by Jerry K. Strosnider and Richard J. Haines.

explanation: Sidney Colvin was born into a middle-class family in 1845. His father, Bazett David Colvin, was a civil servant, serving as an East India Company official, which was a respectable and stable occupation during the 19th century in the United Kingdom. His mother, Mary Steuart, was the daughter of a solicitor. This suggests that the family had a stable income and a decent social standing, typical of the middle class. The Colvin family's ability to provide Sidney with a good education, as he attended Trinity College, Cambridge, further indicates their middle-class status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's living conditions and privileges are not well-documented, but their occupations and ability to provide education suggest a comfortable middle-class lifestyle.
sources: "Sidney Colvin", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Sidney Colvin", Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Nikolay Ogarev was born into a wealthy aristocratic family in Russia, not the United Kingdom. His father, Alexey Ivanovich Ogarev, was a wealthy landowner and a high-ranking state official, which placed the family in the elite social class. The family's wealth and status provided Nikolay with access to a high-quality education, which was a privilege not available to those of lower social classes. He was educated at home by private tutors before attending Moscow University. The family's wealth also ensured that Nikolay lived in comfortable housing conditions during his early life.
sources: "Nikolay Platonovich Ogarev" by J. N. Westwood, published in The Slavonic and East European Review, Vol. 36, No. 87 (Jun., 1958), pp. 402-417.

explanation: August Wilhelmj was born in Usingen, Germany, not the United Kingdom. His father was a music director, which suggests that the family was of the middle class, as this was a skilled profession typically associated with this social stratum. There is no evidence to suggest that the Wilhelmj family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to infer that they were of average means for their time and place. Wilhelmj's early access to music education, which was likely facilitated by his father's profession, also indicates a middle-class upbringing, as such opportunities were typically not available to the lower classes. However, there is no specific information available about Wilhelmj's early life housing and living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "August Wilhelmj." Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online. Oxford University Press.

explanation: James Rennell was born in Chudleigh, Devon, England in 1742. His father, John Rennell, was an army officer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1700s. Unfortunately, his father died when Rennell was very young, and his mother was left with limited resources. Despite these circumstances, Rennell was able to attend the King's School in Ottery St Mary, suggesting that the family had some means and valued education. However, the family's financial situation was not stable, and Rennell was forced to join the navy at the age of 14 to support himself and his family. This suggests that while the family was middle class, they were not wealthy and faced financial hardship.

explanation: William Barnes was born in Rushay, Dorset, England, in 1801. His father, John Barnes, was a farmer, which was a respectable occupation at the time, indicating a middle-class status. His mother, Grace Scott Barnes, came from a family of yeomen, which were landowning farmers, further supporting a middle-class classification. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. William Barnes had access to education, as he attended the local grammar school, which was typically a privilege of the middle and upper classes. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a farming family in rural England during this period.
sources: "William Barnes: A Dorset Poet" by Bernard Jones; "The Life of William Barnes: Poet and Philologist" by Lucy Baxter.

explanation: Thomas Farnaby was born in London around 1575. His father was a merchant tailor, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class of the time. This is further supported by the fact that Farnaby was able to attend the Merchant Taylors' School, which was founded by the Merchant Taylors' Company, a guild of tailors and linen-armourers. Admission to this school was generally restricted to the sons of freemen of the company, indicating that Farnaby's family had a certain level of social standing and wealth. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "The History of the Worthies of England" by Thomas Fuller, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Leslie Stephen and Sidney Lee, "The Merchant Taylors' School for Boys: A History of the School" by John Roach.

explanation: Philip Miller was born in Deptford, Kent, England, around 1691. His father was a Scottish gardener, which suggests a middle-class background, as gardening was a skilled trade during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, but the fact that his father was a tradesman implies a certain level of financial stability. It's also worth noting that Miller was able to receive an education in botany, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with some form of schooling. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Philip Miller/ Miller, Philip (1691-1771), gardener and botanical author" by Ray Desmond, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation:
Anthony Ashley-Cooper, the 7th Earl of Shaftesbury, was born into the British aristocracy. His father, Cropley Ashley-Cooper, was the 6th Earl of Shaftesbury, and his mother, Lady Anne Spencer, was the daughter of George Spencer, 4th Duke of Marlborough. The Ashley-Cooper family was one of the oldest and most prestigious in England, with a lineage dating back to the 12th century. The title of Earl of Shaftesbury was created in 1672, and by the time of Anthony's birth in 1801, the family had amassed significant wealth and influence. 

Anthony was born in London and raised in the family's grand estate, St Giles House in Dorset. As a member of the aristocracy, he had access to the best education money could buy. He was tutored privately at home before attending Harrow School and Christ Church, Oxford. His education was not a result of his own merit but a privilege of his birth.

The Ashley-Cooper family's wealth and status would have provided Anthony with numerous advantages in his early life, including a comfortable home, access to high-quality education, and connections to influential people. His birth and childhood circumstances place him firmly within the elite class of the late 18th and early 19th century British society.
sources: 1. "Anthony Ashley Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury." Encyc

explanation:
William Bradford was born in Austerfield, Yorkshire, England, around 1590. His family was of the yeoman class, a social group in England that owned and cultivated their own land. His father, William Bradford Sr., was a farmer and his mother, Alice Hanson Bradford, came from a family of merchants. Bradford's family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were able to provide a comfortable life for their son. However, Bradford's early life was marked by tragedy. His father died when he was just one year old, and his mother passed away when he was seven. After the death of his parents, Bradford lived with his uncles.

In terms of education, Bradford likely had limited formal education. However, his family background did allow him some access to religious texts, and he was a keen reader from a young age. This early exposure to religious literature would later influence his decision to join the Separatist Church.

Bradford's early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the yeoman class. He did not inherit any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources:
- Bradford, William. "Of Plymouth Plantation, 1620-1647." New York: Random House, 1981.
- Philbrick, Nathaniel. "Mayflower: A Story of Courage, Community, and War." New York: Viking, 2006.
-

explanation: Méric Casaubon was born in Geneva, Switzerland, in 1599 to Florence Estienne and Isaac Casaubon. His father, Isaac, was a renowned Huguenot scholar and teacher, indicating a middle-class background. Isaac was a professor of Greek and held a position at the University of Geneva, which suggests that the family had access to education and a certain level of social standing. However, there's no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or ruling class. The family moved to England in 1610 when Isaac was invited by King James I to become a royal librarian, a prestigious position but not one that would necessarily elevate the family to the elite class. The family's wealth at the time of Méric's birth and childhood is not well documented, but given Isaac's profession, it's reasonable to assume they were not living in poverty.
sources: "Isaac Casaubon, 1559-1614" by Mark Pattison (1892), "The Library of Isaac Casaubon" by Paul Botley (2010), "Méric Casaubon (1599–1671): A Life" by Alex D.D. Craik (2018).

explanation: John Downman was born in Ruabon, Denbighshire, Wales, around 1750. His father, John Downman, was a solicitor, which was a respected profession that required a certain level of education and skill, suggesting a middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the Downman family was part of the elite aristocracy or that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that John Downman was able to study at the Royal Academy in London also suggests that his family had the means to support his education, which was not a privilege available to all in the late 1700s. However, there is also no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or influential beyond their local community.
sources: "John Downman, A.R.A." (1892) by George C. Williamson, an authoritative biography of the artist; "The Dictionary of National Biography" (1885-1900) by Leslie Stephen and Sidney Lee, which includes a detailed entry on John Downman.

explanation: Samuel Ferguson was born in Belfast, Ireland, in 1810. His father, John Ferguson, was a successful banker, which suggests a middle-class background. The family's financial stability would have provided Samuel with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. Samuel was educated at the Royal Belfast Academical Institution, indicating that his family had the means to afford a good education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Fergusons were part of the elite or aristocracy, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Sir Samuel Ferguson in the Ireland of His Day" by Lady Ferguson (his wife), "Samuel Ferguson: The Literary Achievement" by Eve Patten, and "The Oxford Handbook of Modern Irish Poetry" by Fran Brearton and Alan Gillis.

explanation: Richard Porson was born in East Ruston, near North Walsham in Norfolk, England. His father, Huggin Porson, was a weaver, which was a skilled craft occupation, and his mother, whose maiden name was Spurrell, was the daughter of a farmer. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Porson's early education was funded by a local landowner, Mr. Norris, who recognized his potential. This suggests that while the family had some access to education, it was not a given due to their social standing. The family lived in a modest house in East Ruston, indicative of their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Life of Richard Porson, M.A. Professor of Greek in the University of Cambridge from 1792 to 1808" by John Selby Watson (1861); "Richard Porson: A Biographical Essay" by William Munk (1870).

explanation: Samuel Webbe was born in England around 1740. His father was a cabinet maker, a skilled trade that would likely place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. There is little information available about Webbe's mother or any potential siblings. Webbe's father died when he was young, and he was sent to live with an uncle who was a linen-draper, another middle-class occupation. His uncle provided him with a basic education, which would have been more accessible to middle-class families than those in the subsistence class. There is no evidence to suggest that Webbe was born into wealth or that he had any inherited privileges or disadvantages. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but based on his family's occupations, it can be inferred that they were likely modest but comfortable.
sources: "Samuel Webbe", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Samuel Webbe", Grove Music Online.

explanation: Sir George Beaumont, 7th Baronet, was born into an aristocratic family, which places him in the elite class according to the given typology. His father, Sir George Howland Beaumont, 4th Baronet, was a member of the British nobility, which indicates a high social standing. The Beaumont family was wealthy, owning several estates, including the Coleorton Hall in Leicestershire, which would have provided a comfortable living environment. As a member of the aristocracy, Beaumont would have had access to education due to his family background. He was educated at Eton College, a prestigious school in England, which further supports his classification in the elite class. Beaumont's inherited privileges would have included wealth, social status, and access to education.
sources: "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1790-1820," by R. Thorne; "Eton College Register, 1753-1790," edited by Sir H. C. Maxwell Lyte.

explanation: John Speed was born in Farndon, Cheshire, England around 1552. His father, also named John Speed, was a tailor by trade, which was a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that the Speed family belonged to the middle class, as tailoring was a skilled trade typically associated with this social stratum. There is no evidence to suggest that the Speed family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. As for education, it is known that Speed was later apprenticed to a merchant tailor in London, which suggests that his family had the resources to secure such an apprenticeship, a common practice among the middle class. However, there is no record of Speed receiving a formal education in his early years, which was not uncommon for children of his social class during this period.
sources: "John Speed: The Man Behind the Maps" by Nigel Nicolson; "The History of Britain" by John Speed; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: John Obadiah Westwood was born in Sheffield, England, in 1805. His father, also named John Westwood, was a die sinker, a skilled craftsperson who created dies for stamping designs onto coins and medals. This occupation would place the family in the middle class, as it required a high level of skill and precision. There is no evidence to suggest that the Westwood family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it can be inferred that they lived a comfortable, middle-class lifestyle. Westwood's father's occupation would have provided the family with a steady income, and they likely lived in a home appropriate for a family of their social standing. Westwood's access to education would have been due to his family's middle-class status, as education during this time was often reserved for the middle and upper classes. There is no evidence to suggest that Westwood inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Obadiah Westwood." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: William Jackson of Exeter, often referred to as Jackson of Exeter, was born in 1730 in Exeter, Devon, England. His father, John Jackson, was a glover by trade, which was a skilled craft occupation during the time, indicating a middle-class status. There is no evidence suggesting that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, suggesting a relatively stable economic situation. Jackson's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he was known to have attended the Cathedral School in Exeter, a privilege not typically afforded to those of lower social classes. The family's living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in the 1700s, likely living in a modest but comfortable home in the city of Exeter. There is no evidence to suggest that Jackson inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians", "The Biographical Dictionary of Musicians", "The Musical Times".

explanation: Hugh Miller was born on 10 October 1802 in Cromarty, Scotland. His father, Hugh Miller Sr., was a ship's captain who was lost at sea when Miller was only five years old, leaving the family in a precarious financial situation. His mother, Harriet Wright, was left to raise him and his siblings on her own, relying on the support of relatives and the small income she could earn from keeping a cow and selling the milk. Miller's education was limited; he attended a local parish school intermittently until the age of 17. His family's financial struggles meant that he had to start working at a young age, first as a herdsman and later as a stonemason's apprentice. The family lived in a small cottage, and Miller's early life was marked by hardship and poverty.
sources: "Hugh Miller: Stonemason, Geologist, Writer" by Michael A. Taylor and Hugh S. Torrens; "The Life and Letters of Hugh Miller" by Peter Bayne; "Hugh Miller: Outrage and Order" by Lyall Anderson.

explanation: Alfred Waterhouse was born on 19 July 1830 in Aigburth, Liverpool, England. His father, also named Alfred Waterhouse, was a wealthy cotton broker, which places the family in the middle class according to the specified typology. The family's wealth allowed Alfred to receive a good education. He was initially educated at the Royal Institution School in Liverpool, and later at Grove Park School in Wrexham, North Wales. This level of education was typically accessible to middle class families during this period. The family's wealth also provided a comfortable living condition for Alfred during his early life. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Waterhouse family held any inherited privileges or titles that would classify them as part of the elite class.
sources: "Alfred Waterhouse, 1830–1905: Biography and Bibliography" by Colin Cunningham and Prudence Waterhouse; "The Royal Institution of Liverpool" by Peter Cunningham.

explanation:
Albert Venn Dicey was born on February 4, 1835, in Lutterworth, Leicestershire, England. His father, Thomas Edward Dicey, was a journalist and proprietor of the Northampton Mercury newspaper, and his mother was Anne Mary Stephen Dicey. The Dicey family was well-established and respected, with a history of involvement in the printing and publishing industry. Thomas Edward Dicey was also a senior partner in the printing firm of Clarendon Press. This indicates that the Dicey family was of the middle class, as they were engaged in a skilled profession and owned a business. 

Albert Venn Dicey's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class background. He was educated at King's College School in London and later at Balliol College, Oxford. His education at these prestigious institutions was likely facilitated by his family's resources and social standing.

In terms of early life housing and living conditions, there is no specific information available. However, given his father's profession and business ownership, it can be inferred that Dicey's living conditions were comfortable and typical of the middle class during that period.

explanation: James Fergusson was born in Ayr, Scotland, in 1808 to William Fergusson, a medical doctor, and his wife, Jean Rankine. His father's profession as a doctor indicates that the family was likely part of the middle class, as medicine was a respected profession that required a high level of education and skill. The family's ability to provide James with a good education, including attendance at the University of St. Andrews, further suggests a middle-class background. explanation: James Sowerby was born in 1757 to a family of modest means. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, suggesting a stable, middle-class existence. explanation: Horatius Bonar was born into a family of considerable standing in Scotland. His father, James Bonar, was a Solicitor of Excise for Scotland and thus held a respectable professional position. This would suggest that the family was of the middle class, as James Bonar's occupation was neither of the aristocracy nor of the subsistence class. The Bonar family was also known for its strong religious beliefs, and Horatius and his brothers were educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh, indicating that they had access to education due to their family background. The family's ability to provide such education suggests a level of wealth consistent with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that Horatius Bonar was born into either extreme poverty or extreme wealth, and his family's professional and religious standing would have afforded him certain privileges, such as education, but not to the extent of the elite class.
sources: "Horatius Bonar and the Hymns of Faith and Hope" by Robin A. Leaver; "Horatius Bonar: His Letters and Journals" by his daughter Marjoribanks Bonar.

explanation:
Frederick Denison Maurice was born in 1805 in Normanton, Suffolk, England. His father, Michael Maurice, was a Unitarian minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. His mother, Priscilla Hurry, was the daughter of a merchant, further supporting the middle class classification. The family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they laborers or peasants. 

As the son of a minister, Maurice would have had access to education, but not because of wealth or inherited privilege. His father's occupation would have provided a modest but stable income, and the family would have lived in housing appropriate for a minister's family, likely a parsonage. 

However, it should be noted that Maurice's family was disowned by their extended family due to their Unitarian beliefs, which would have limited their social connections and potential inherited advantages.
sources:
- "Frederick Denison Maurice: Rebellious Conformist" by David Newsome
- Oxford Dictionary of National Biography: "Maurice, Frederick Denison" by Geoffrey Wainwright
- "The Life of Frederick Denison Maurice: Chiefly Told in His Own Letters" by Frederick Denison Maurice, his son.

explanation: Joseph Cundall was born in Norwich, England, in 1818. His father, Robert Cundall, was a successful merchant, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. The middle class in the 19th century England typically included merchants, skilled craftspeople, and professionals. The fact that Robert Cundall was a merchant suggests that the family had a stable income and were likely able to afford a comfortable lifestyle, including a decent home and education for their children. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Cundalls were part of the elite or ruling class, nor that they were struggling to subsist. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Joseph Cundall's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Joseph Cundall: A Victorian Publisher" by Patricia J. Barnes, "The Victorian Middle Class: A Social History" by David Roberts.

explanation: Charles Wyville Thomson was born in Bonsyde, Linlithgow, Scotland, on March 5, 1830. explanation: James Thomson was born in 1834 in Cheetham Hill, Manchester, England. His father, John Thomson, was a successful engineer and businessman, who owned a spinning factory. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in commerce and had a certain level of wealth. However, they were not part of the elite, as they did not have titles or vast landholdings. James Thomson's mother, Elizabeth Thomson, was a housewife, which was typical for women of the middle class during this period. The family's wealth allowed James to receive a good education, as he attended private schools in Manchester and later studied engineering at the University of Glasgow. The family lived in a comfortable home in Manchester, indicating that they had a certain level of wealth and stability.
sources: "James Thomson (engineer)" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "James Thomson: A Great Victorian Engineer and Scientist" by Crosbie Smith; Census records from the United Kingdom in the 1800s.

explanation: Thomas Brassey, 1st Earl Brassey, was born into a middle-class family. His father, Thomas Brassey, was a prominent civil engineer and railway contractor, which would have placed the family in the middle class, as these were skilled professions. The Brassey family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, which rules out the elite classification. They were also not laborers or peasants, which rules out the subsistence classification. The family's wealth would have been significant due to Thomas Brassey's successful career, providing a comfortable upbringing for the young Thomas. As for education, the young Thomas Brassey was educated at Rugby and University College, Oxford, which suggests that the family had the means to afford a good education for their children. The family's housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given the father's successful career. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: William Allingham was born in Ballyshannon, County Donegal, Ireland, in 1824. His father, William Allingham Sr., was a bank manager, which suggests a middle-class status. explanation: Grinling Gibbons was born in Rotterdam, Netherlands, to English parents. His father, James Gibbons, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The family moved back to England around 1667. There is no evidence to suggest that the Gibbons family was particularly wealthy or impoverished; they were likely comfortable but not affluent. As for education, Grinling Gibbons was apprenticed to a master carver, which suggests that his family had enough resources to secure this apprenticeship for him. This was a common practice among middle-class families of the time. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it's reasonable to assume they were adequate. There's no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: John Mason Neale was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Cornelius Neale, was a clergyman, which was a respected position in society during the 19th century. Neale's early education was provided by private tutors, indicating that his family had the means to afford a high-quality education. explanation:
William Hayley was born in Chichester, England, in 1745 to a well-off family. His father, Thomas Hayley, was a wealthy merchant who had made his fortune in the West Indies trade. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had significant wealth and social standing due to commerce. William Hayley's mother, Mary Yates, was also from a prosperous family. 

The wealth of the Hayley family allowed William to receive a good education. He was educated at Eton and at Trinity Hall, Cambridge, which were prestigious institutions accessible primarily to the middle and upper classes. 

The family's wealth also provided William with a comfortable early life. He lived in a large house in Eartham, a village in West Sussex, which suggests a high standard of living. 

However, there is no evidence to suggest that Hayley was born into the elite class. His family's wealth came from trade, not land or titles, and there is no indication that they were part of the ruling class or nobility.

explanation: William Cave was born in Pickwell, Leicestershire, England, in 1637. His father, John Cave, was a rector of Pickwell, indicating a middle-class status as a professional in the religious sector. The family's ability to provide William with an education also suggests a certain level of financial stability and social standing. William attended Oakham and Stamford schools before being admitted to St John's College, Cambridge, in 1653. This level of education was not typically accessible to those of lower social classes in the 17th century. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Cave family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Their lifestyle and occupations align more closely with the middle class of the time.

explanation: Joseph Farington was born in Leigh, Lancashire, England in 1747. His father, William Farington, was a vicar of Leigh, which would have placed the family in the middle class. The role of a vicar, while not as prestigious or wealthy as the nobility, was a respected position within society, often associated with education and a certain level of comfort. The family was not of the aristocracy, but they were not laborers or peasants either. Joseph Farington was one of seven children, and his family could afford to send him to the Manchester Grammar School, a sign of their middle-class status. The ability to afford education for their children was not a privilege available to the lower classes at the time.
sources: "The Diary of Joseph Farington" edited by Kenneth Garlick, Angus Macintyre, Kathryn Cave; "Joseph Farington and His Circle" by Brian Allen.

explanation: John Harington was born into the English nobility. His father, John Harington of Stepney, was a courtier and poet, and his mother, Isabella Markham, was a gentlewoman of the Privy Chamber to Queen Elizabeth I. This indicates that the family had a high social standing and access to the royal court. The Harington family was also wealthy, owning substantial properties in Somerset and elsewhere. John Harington was educated at Eton College and King's College, Cambridge, which were exclusive institutions typically only accessible to the elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable and privileged, reflecting his family's wealth and status.
sources: "The Letters and Epigrams of Sir John Harington: Together with the 'Prayse of Private Life'", by Norman Egbert McClure; "The Life and Works of John Harington", by Ruth Hughey.

explanation: Valentine Cameron Prinsep was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Thoby Prinsep, was a successful businessman who had made his fortune in the East India Company. His mother, Sara Monckton Pattle, was from a well-connected family. The Prinseps were known for their wealth and their social connections, which included many prominent figures of the Victorian era. Valentine was one of eight children, and the family lived in a large house in Kensington, London, indicating a high level of wealth and comfort. His family's wealth and social standing would have given him access to a high level of education and other opportunities.
sources:
- "Valentine Cameron Prinsep." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 
- "The Prinsep Family of Little Holland House." The Victorian Web. 
- "Val Prinsep: A Pre-Raphaelite Painter in Victorian London." The British Newspaper Archive.

explanation: John Aikin was born in 1747 in Kibworth Harcourt, Leicestershire, England. His father, also named John Aikin, was a Unitarian scholar and theological tutor, indicative of a middle-class profession during that period. His mother, Susanna Jennings, came from a family of dissenting ministers, which further suggests a middle-class background. The Aikin family was well-respected and had access to education, as evidenced by John Aikin's early education at the Warrington Academy, a dissenting academy where his father taught. This access to education suggests a certain level of family wealth and social standing, characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Aikin family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's religious dissent from the Church of England may have limited their social mobility, but it did not appear to significantly impact their economic status or living conditions.
sources: "John Aikin." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008. "The Aikin Family Papers." John Rylands Library, University of Manchester.

explanation: Thomas Frognall Dibdin was born in Calcutta, India, in 1776 to Thomas Dibdin, a captain in the East India Company's service, and his wife, who was the daughter of a London merchant. The East India Company was a significant entity in the British Empire, and a captain's position would have provided a comfortable income, placing the Dibdin family in the middle class. However, Dibdin's father died when he was very young, and his mother returned to England, where she struggled to provide for her children. Despite these financial difficulties, Dibdin was able to attend St. John's College, Oxford, suggesting that the family still had some resources or connections to secure his education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable initially in India, but likely more modest in England after his father's death.
sources: "The Bibliographical Decameron" by Thomas Frognall Dibdin; "Thomas Frognall Dibdin, 1776-1847: A Bibliography" by Robert C. W. Cox; "The Life and Correspondence of Thomas Frognall Dibdin" by Nicholas A. Basbanes.

explanation: John Britton was born in Kington St. Michael, Wiltshire, England in 1771. His parents were not of high social standing or wealth. His family's living conditions were modest, and he did not inherit any significant privileges or advantages due to his family background.

explanation: Jonathan Richardson was born in 1667 to a father who was a tanner by trade. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: George Alexander Macfarren was born in London in 1813. explanation: William Brockedon was born in Totnes, Devon, England in 1787. explanation: Alexander Cruden was born in Aberdeen, Scotland around 1699. His father, William Cruden, was a merchant and burgess of Aberdeen, indicating a middle-class status. explanation: James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose, was born into a family of the Scottish nobility. His father, John Graham, was the 4th Earl of Montrose, a title that had been in the family since the 15th century. As a child, James Graham would have grown up in a privileged environment, with access to the best education of the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status. His birth and childhood social class was clearly that of the elite.

explanation: Conyers Middleton was born to William Middleton, a lawyer, and his wife Sarah Conyers. explanation: Elizabeth Carter was born in Deal, Kent, England in 1717. explanation: Mary Astell was born in Newcastle upon Tyne in 1666 to Peter and Mary Astell. In terms of housing and living conditions, it can be inferred that the Paget family lived in decent conditions, as Samuel Paget's occupation as a shipwright would have provided a stable income. explanation: Olaudah Equiano, also known as Gustavus Vassa, was not born in the United Kingdom, but in what is now Nigeria, in West Africa. He was born into the Ibo tribe around 1745. Equiano's early life was marked by hardship. At around the age of 11, he and his sister were kidnapped by local slave traders and sold into slavery. This traumatic event marked the end of his life in Africa and the beginning of his life as a slave, which would take him across the Atlantic to the Americas. As a slave, Equiano would have been considered part of the subsistence class, as he had minimal resources and was forced to labor for others. His access to education would have been limited, if not non-existent, during his early years as a slave. His living conditions would have been poor, and he would have faced numerous disadvantages due to his status as a slave.

explanation: Edward Dowden was born on May 3, 1843, in Cork, Ireland, which was part of the United Kingdom at the time. His father, John Wheeler Dowden, was a merchant and his mother, Elizabeth (née Lett) Dowden, was a homemaker. The occupation of his father indicates that the family belonged to the middle class, as merchants were typically part of this social stratum during the 19th century. The family's ability to provide Edward with a good education also suggests a level of financial stability and access to resources associated with the middle class. Edward attended Queen's College in Cork, which indicates that his family had the means to afford a higher education for their son. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but the occupation of Edward's father and Edward's access to education suggest a comfortable, middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Edward Dowden: A Critical Edition of the Complete Poetry" by Wayne Chapman; "Edward Dowden" by Desmond MacCarthy; "The Life of Edward Dowden" by Elizabeth Dickinson West.

explanation: Marcus Stone was born into a middle-class family in London in 1840. His father, Frank Stone ARA, was a well-known painter and a friend of Charles Dickens. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence level, as Frank Stone's occupation as a painter would have provided a stable income. Marcus Stone's access to education would have been influenced by his family background. As the son of a painter, he likely would have received some artistic training from his father. His family's connections to the artistic community in London may also have provided additional educational opportunities. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, reflecting their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Marcus Stone R.A." Royal Academy of Arts. https://www.royalacademy.org.uk/art-artists/name/marcus-stone-ra; "Frank Stone ARA." Art UK. https://artuk.org/discover/artists/stone-frank-18001859.

explanation: Henry Mayhew was born in London in 1812 to Joshua Mayhew and his wife Mary Ann. His father, Joshua, was a solicitor and thus belonged to a professional occupation, which was characteristic of the middle class during this period. The family was not of aristocratic lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. Henry Mayhew's access to education also indicates a middle-class background. He attended Westminster School, a prestigious institution, but this was likely due to his family's ability to afford the fees rather than any inherited privilege. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it is reasonable to assume they were comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "London Labour and the London Poor" by Henry Mayhew; "The Unknown Mayhew: Selections from the 'Morning Chronicle', 1849-50" by E.P. Thompson and Eileen Yeo; "Henry Mayhew" by Christopher Hibbert in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: John Varley was born in Hackney, a district in London, in 1778. His father, Richard Varley, was a silversmith by trade, which was a skilled craft occupation typically associated with the middle class during this period. His mother, Martha Varley, was a homemaker. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either, suggesting a middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that Varley had access to formal education due to his family background, but he did receive some training in his father's trade. The family lived in a modest house in Hackney, which was a relatively prosperous area of London at the time. There is no evidence to suggest that Varley inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Varley, 1778–1842, British" by Lyles, Anne (Tate Gallery, 1990); "John Varley of the 'Old Society'" by Witt, David (The Burlington Magazine, 1969).

explanation: Thomas Traherne was born in Hereford, England, around 1636. His father, Philip Traherne, was a shoemaker, which was a skilled trade and would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother's name and occupation are not recorded, but it's likely she also came from a similar social background. Traherne's family was not wealthy, but they were able to provide him with an education. He attended Hereford Cathedral School, a grammar school that was free for local boys, which suggests his family had some standing in the community. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as the son of a skilled tradesman, it's likely he lived in relatively comfortable circumstances for the time. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Traherne: A Critical Biography" by Julia Smith (Princeton University Press, 2013), "The Poetical Works of Thomas Traherne" by Bertram Dobell (1903)

explanation: Elizabeth Fry was born on May 21, 1780, in Norwich, England, to John Gurney and Catherine Barclay Gurney. Her family was part of the Quaker community, which was known for its middle-class status during the late 18th century. Her father, John Gurney, was a partner in Gurney's Bank, indicating a level of wealth and stability that would place them in the middle class. The Gurney family was also known for their philanthropy, which was a common practice among the Quaker community and further suggests their middle-class status. Elizabeth was one of 12 children, indicating that the family had enough resources to support a large family. She received an education, which was not common for all women at the time, further indicating her family's middle-class status.
sources: "Elizabeth Fry." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., February 4, 2021. "Elizabeth Fry." Quakers in the World. The Quakers of Britain, n.d. "Gurney's Bank." Norwich HEART. Norwich Heritage Economic and Regeneration Trust, n.d.

explanation: Horace Lamb was born in Stockport, England, in 1849. His father, John Lamb, was a warehouseman, a job that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. The family was not of noble lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. John Lamb's job would have provided a stable income for the family, allowing them to live comfortably. Horace Lamb's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Stockport Grammar School, a well-regarded institution that would have required some level of financial means for attendance. His early life housing and living conditions, while not luxurious, would have been comfortable and secure, typical of a middle-class family in the 19th century. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Sir Horace Lamb," by H. Bateman in Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society, Vol. 1 (Nov., 1955), pp. 147-160; "Horace Lamb," by J. Larmor in Obituary Notices of Fellows of the Royal Society, Vol. 4, No. 12 (Dec., 1941), pp. 267-282.

explanation: John Baskerville was born in Wolverley, Worcestershire, England, around 1706. His father, John Baskerville Sr., was a farmer, which would place the family within the middle class according to the typology provided. Farming during this period was a respectable occupation that provided a stable income, but it did not confer the wealth or social standing associated with the elite class. There is no evidence to suggest that Baskerville's family was particularly wealthy or that he had access to a high level of education due to his family background. However, he did attend a free school in Birmingham, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a basic education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family of the time. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Baskerville, Type-Founder and Printer, 1706-1775" by Josiah Henry Benton (1914); "John Baskerville: A Memoir" by Ralph Straus (1971).

explanation:
Lancelot Brown, more commonly known as Capability Brown, was born in 1716 in Kirkharle, Northumberland, England. His parents, William Brown and Ursula Hall, were land agents and yeoman farmers, a position that would place them in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. This class was typically composed of merchants, artisans, skilled craftspeople, landowners, and teachers. 

Brown's family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were able to provide a decent living for their children. Brown's father was responsible for the management of the Kirkharle estate, which provided the family with a stable income. 

As for education, Brown received a basic education at Cambo School. His family's status and income would have allowed for this level of education. 

In terms of housing and living conditions, Brown would have lived in a comfortable, if not luxurious, home due to his father's position as a land agent. 

There is no evidence to suggest that Brown was born with any inherited privileges or disadvantages. His family's position in society would have provided him with a stable upbringing, but not one of privilege or disadvantage.
sources:
- Stroud, D. (1975). Capability Brown. Faber & Faber.
- Turner, R. (1985). Capability Brown and the Eighteenth-century English Landscape. Phillimore.
- Willis, P. (2016).

explanation: Joseph Michael Gandy was born in 1771 in London, England. His father, Thomas Gandy, was a London pavior and bricklayer, a skilled trade that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The Gandy family was not part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. Joseph Gandy's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he was able to study at the Royal Academy Schools, a prestigious institution that would have required some level of financial means to attend. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Gandy family was particularly wealthy or that Joseph Gandy inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Joseph Gandy 1771–1843," Tate Gallery, London; "Joseph Gandy: An Architectural Visionary in Georgian England," Brian Lukacher, Thames & Hudson, 2006.

explanation: John Atkinson Grimshaw was born in Leeds, England, in 1836. His father, David Grimshaw, was a policeman. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either, suggesting a middle-class background. Grimshaw's parents were strict Baptists, and he initially followed his father's wishes by working as a clerk for the Great Northern Railway. It was not until his early twenties that he decided to pursue a career as an artist, against his parents' wishes. This suggests that Grimshaw had some access to education and was not forced into manual labor at a young age, which is another indication of a middle-class upbringing. However, his family was not part of the elite class, as they did not possess significant wealth or hold high social status.
sources: "John Atkinson Grimshaw: A Biography" by Alexander Robertson, "The Victorian Artist: Artists' Lifewritings in Britain, c. 1870-1910" by Julie F. Codell.

explanation: Alexander Nasmyth was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1758. His father, Michael Nasmyth, was a member of the Incorporation of Hammermen, a guild for metalworkers, and served as Deacon of the Hammermen, a position of some prestige within the guild. This suggests that the Nasmyth family was part of the skilled craftspeople class, which falls under the middle class category in the given typology. Alexander Nasmyth's mother, Barbara Foulis, was the daughter of a successful Edinburgh bookseller, further supporting the classification of Nasmyth's family as middle class. Nasmyth's parents were able to provide him with a good education, as he attended the Trustees’ Academy, a well-regarded school for the arts in Edinburgh. This access to education suggests a level of family wealth and social standing consistent with the middle class.
sources: "Alexander Nasmyth, 1758 - 1840. Landscape and portrait painter" (National Galleries Scotland); "The Incorporation of Hammermen of Edinburgh" (The Hammermen of Edinburgh); "Nasmyth, Alexander" (Oxford Dictionary of National Biography).

explanation: Elizabeth Montagu was born into a wealthy family. Her father, Matthew Robinson, was a landowner with estates in Yorkshire. Her mother, Elizabeth Drake, was also from a wealthy background. The Robinson family was well-established and had significant social standing. Elizabeth was one of ten children, and her family's wealth allowed her access to a good education, which was not common for women at the time. She was educated at home by a governess and had access to her family's extensive library. Her family's wealth and social standing would have provided her with a comfortable early life and living conditions.
sources: "Elizabeth Montagu, the Queen of the Bluestockings: Her Correspondence from 1720 to 1761" by Emily J. Climenson; "The Bluestockings: Women of Reason from Enlightenment to Romanticism" by Elizabeth Eger.

explanation: Johanna Kinkel (née Mockel) was born on July 8, 1810, in Bonn, Germany, not the United Kingdom. Her father, Johann Mockel, was a respected physician in Bonn, which suggests a middle-class background. The family's financial situation would have been stable, and they would have had a comfortable living condition. As a child, Johanna received a good education, which was not common for girls at the time, indicating that her family had the resources to provide her with this opportunity. She was taught music by her mother and later attended a private girls' school. This access to education further supports the classification of her family as middle class.
sources: "Johanna Kinkel" by Monica Klaus in the Neue Deutsche Biographie (1987), "Johanna Kinkel: A Musical Life" by Joachim Reiber (1997).

explanation: John Boyle, 5th Earl of Cork, was born into the aristocracy of the United Kingdom. His father, Charles Boyle, 4th Earl of Orrery, was a nobleman, and his mother, Lady Elizabeth Cecil, was the daughter of John Cecil, 6th Earl of Exeter. This indicates that Boyle was born into a family of high social standing, with both his parents being members of the nobility. The family's wealth at the time of his birth and during his childhood would have been substantial, given their aristocratic status. Boyle would have had access to education due to his family background, as it was common for children of the nobility to receive a high level of education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, as befitting his family's status. Boyle would have inherited a number of privileges due to his birth, including a title and the wealth associated with it.
sources: "The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe" by Darryl Lundy; "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1715-1754" by Romney Sedgwick.

explanation: Thomas Banks was born in 1735 in Lambeth, London, to William Banks, a land surveyor, and his wife Sarah. His father's occupation as a land surveyor suggests that the family was not part of the elite aristocracy, but rather belonged to the middle class. Land surveying was a skilled profession, often associated with the middle class during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that Banks' family was particularly wealthy, but they were likely comfortable enough to provide him with an education, as he was apprenticed to a sculptor at a young age. This indicates that his family had the means to support his training, which was often a sign of middle-class status. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it is reasonable to assume that they were adequate. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Banks 1735-1805", Tate Gallery, London; "Thomas Banks: Britain's First Modern Sculptor", Susan Beattie.

explanation: Jacques Abbadie was born in Nay, Béarn, France, not the United Kingdom, around 1654. His father, Paul Abbadie, was a Protestant minister, which would place the family within the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The Protestant ministry was a respected profession, but it did not confer the same level of wealth or prestige as the nobility. There is no evidence to suggest that the Abbadie family was particularly wealthy, but Jacques' father's occupation would have provided them with a comfortable living and access to education. Jacques himself was educated at the Protestant Academy of Saumur and the University of Sedan, suggesting that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, this does not necessarily mean that they were wealthy, as education was highly valued in Protestant communities and families often made sacrifices to ensure their children were educated. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a minister's family, they would have likely lived in a parsonage or similar accommodation. There is no evidence to suggest that Jacques inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Jacques Abbadie: A Historical Study" by Thomas Hamilton; "The Huguenots in France and America" by Hannah Adams.

explanation: Thomas Wright was born in Byers Green, County Durham, England in 1810. His father, John Wright, was a local schoolmaster, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class. The profession of a schoolmaster, especially in the 19th century, was a respectable occupation that required a certain level of education and literacy, and it was associated with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that Wright's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, but the fact that his father was a schoolmaster suggests that they had a stable income and a decent standard of living. Furthermore, Wright's access to education was likely due to his father's profession. He was educated at home by his father before attending the University of Durham. This suggests that his family valued education and had the resources to provide it, which is another characteristic of the middle class.
sources: "Thomas Wright (1810–1877): A Life Dedicated to the Study of History." Durham University Journal, 1997. "The Life and Works of Thomas Wright (1810–1877): The Culture and Context of an Antiquarian." The Antiquaries Journal, 2011.

explanation: William Francis Patrick Napier was born into the Napier family, a prominent Scottish family with a long history of military service. His father, Colonel George Napier, was a respected military officer, and his mother, Lady Sarah Lennox, was the daughter of Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond, making her a direct descendant of King Charles II of England. This places Napier firmly within the elite class of his time, as he was born into a family with both wealth and noble connections. His access to education was also likely due to his family background, as it was common for children of the elite to receive a high level of education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status.
sources: "The Life and Opinions of General Sir Charles James Napier, G.C.B." by William Francis Patrick Napier, "The Napiers: History of a Great Scottish Family" by Mark Napier.

explanation: Edward Caird was born on 23 March 1835 in Greenock, Scotland. His father, John Caird, was a shipbuilder, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class during the 19th century. Shipbuilding was a skilled trade, and the Caird family would have enjoyed a comfortable lifestyle as a result of John's profession. Edward was the third of seven children, indicating that the family had enough resources to support a relatively large family. Furthermore, Edward's access to education also suggests a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at the University of Glasgow and Balliol College, Oxford. While it's not clear whether his family's wealth directly enabled his education, it is likely that his middle-class background played a role in his educational opportunities.
sources: "Edward Caird (1835–1908)" by David Boucher, in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; "Caird, Edward (1835–1908), philosopher and theologian" by David Boucher, in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Frederick Walker was born in the mid-19th century in the United Kingdom. His father, John Walker, was a skilled craftsman, specifically a blacksmith, which was a respected trade during that time period. This would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, but they would have been able to live comfortably on the income from John's trade. Frederick's mother, Mary Walker, did not work outside the home, which was typical for women of the middle class during this period.
